editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: THE AVTHOVR TO THE Reader.
div.p: REader, loe-heere a well-meaning Booke. It doth at the fir≈øt entrance fore-warne thee, that in contriving the ≈øame, I have propo≈øed vnto my ≈øelfe no other than a familiar and private end‚ñ™ I have no re≈øpect or con≈øideration at all, either to thy ≈øervice, or to my glory: my forces are not capable of any ≈øuch de≈ø≈øeigne. I have vowed the ≈øame to the particular commodity of my kinsfolks and friends: to the end, that lo≈øing me (which they are likely to do ere long) they may therein finde ≈øome lineaments of my conditions and humours, and by that meanes re≈øerve more whole, and more lively fo≈øter the knowledge and acquaintance they have had of me. Had my intention been to fore≈øtall and purcha≈øe the worlds opinion and favour, I would ≈øurely have adorned my ≈øelfe more quaintly, or kept a more grave and ≈øolemne march. I de≈øire therein to be delineated in mine owne genuine, ≈øimple and ordinarie fa≈øhion, without contention, arte or ≈øtudie, for it is my ≈øelfe I pourtray. My imperfections ≈øhall therein be read to the life, and my naturall forme di≈øcerned, ≈øo farre-forth as publike reverence hath permitted me. For if my fortune had been to have lived among tho≈øe nations, which yet are ≈øayd to live vnder the ≈øweet libertie of Natures fir≈øt and vncorrupted lawes, I a≈ø≈øure thee, I would mo≈øt willingly have pourtrayed my ≈øelfe fully and naked. Thus gentle Reader my ≈øelfe am the ground-worke of my booke: It is then no rea≈øon thou ≈øhoulde≈øt employ thy time about ≈øo frivolous and vaine a ≈øubject. Therefore farewell. From Montaigne, the fir≈øt of March. 1580.

div.p:
THE mo≈øt v≈øuall waie to appea≈øe tho≈øe minds we have offended when revenge lies in their hands, and that we ≈øtand at their mercie, is by ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to move them to commi≈øeration and pitty: Nouerthele≈ø≈øe, courage, con≈øtancie, and re≈øolution (meanes altogether oppo≈øite) have ≈øometimes wrought the ≈øame effect. Edward the blacke Prince of Wales (who ≈øo long governed our Countrie of Guienne, a man who≈øe conditions and fortune were accompanied with many notable parts of worth and magnanimity) having bin grievou≈øly offended by the Limo≈øins, though he by main forcetooke & entred their Citie, could by no means be appea≈øed, nor by the wailefull out‚ñ™ cries of all ≈øorts of people (as of men, women, and children) be moved to any pittie, they pro≈øtrating them≈øelues to the common ≈ølaughter, crying for mercie, and humbly ≈øubmitting them≈øelues at his feete, vntill ≈øuch time as in triumphant manner pa≈ø≈øing through their citie, he perceiued three French gentlemen, who alone, with an incredible & vndaunted boldnes gain≈øtood the enraged violence, and made head again≈øt the furie of his victorious army. The con≈øideration and re≈øpect of ≈øo notable a vertue, did fir≈øt abate the dint of his wrath, and from tho≈øe three began to relent, and ≈øhew mercie to all the other inhabitants of the ≈øaid towne. Scanderbeg. Prince of Epirus, following one of his ≈øoldiers, with purpo≈øe to kill him, who by all means of humilitie, & ≈øubmi≈ø≈øe entreatie, had fir≈øt a≈ø≈øaied to pacifie him, in ≈øuch an vnavoidable extremity, re≈øolved at la≈øt, re≈øolutely to encounter him with his ≈øword in his hand. This re≈øolution did immediatly ≈øtay his Captaines fury, who ≈øeeing him vndertake ≈øo honorable an attempt, not only forgave, but received him into grace & favour. This example may happily, of ≈øuch as have not knowne the prodigious force, and matchle≈ø≈øe valor of the ≈øaid Prince, admit an other interpretation. The Emperor Courad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

ther of the≈øe waies might ea≈øily per≈øwade me: for I am much inclined to mercie, and affected to mildne≈ø≈øe. So it is, that in mine opinion, I ≈øhould more naturally ≈øtoop vnto compa≈ø≈øion, than bend to e≈øtimation. Yet is pitie held a vicious pa≈ø≈øion among the Stoickes. They would have vs aide the afflicted, but not to faint, and co≈øuffer with them. The≈øe examples ≈øeeme fitte≈øt for mee, for≈øomuch as the≈øe mindes are ≈øeene to be a≈ø≈øaulted and environed by the≈øe two meanes, in vndauntedly ≈øuffering the one, and ≈øtooping vnder the other. It may peraduentvre be ≈øaid, that to yeelde ones heart vnto commi≈øeration, is an effect of facilitie, tenderne≈ø≈øe, and meekene≈ø≈øe: whence it proceedeth, that the weake≈øt natures, as of women, children, and the vulgar ≈øort are more ≈øubject vnto it. But (having contemned teares and wailings) to yeeld vnto the onely reverence of the ≈øacred Image of vertue, is the effect of a couragious and imployable minde, holding a ma≈øculine and con≈øtant vigor, in honour and affection. Notwith≈øtanding amazement and admiration may in le≈ø≈øe generous mindes worke the like effect. Witne≈ø≈øe the Thebanes, who having accu≈øed and indited their captaines, as of a capitall crime, for≈øomuch as they had continued their charge, beyond the time pre≈øcribed them, ab≈øolved and quit Pelopidas of all puni≈øhment, becau≈øe he ≈øubmi≈ø≈øiuely yeelded vnder the burden of ≈øuch objections, and to ≈øave him≈øelfe, imployed no other meanes, but ≈øuing-reque≈øts, and demi≈ø≈øe entreaties; where on the contrary, Epaminondas, boldely relating the exploits atchieved by him, and with a fierce and arrogant manner, vpbraiding the people with them, had not the heart ≈øo much as to take their lots into his hands, but went his way, and was freely ab≈øolved: the a≈ø≈øembly much commending the ≈øtoutne≈ø≈øe of his courage. Diony≈øius the elder, after long-lingering and extreame difficulties, having taken the Citie of Reggio, and in it the Captaine Phyton (a worthy hone≈øt man) who had ≈øo ob≈øtinately defended the ≈øame, would needes ≈øhew a tragicall example of revenge. Fir≈øt, he tolde him, how the day before, he had cau≈øed his ≈øonne, and all his kinsfolkes to be drowned. To whom Phy ‚Ä¢ on, ≈øtoutly out-≈øtaring him an≈øwered nothing, but that they were more happy than him≈øelfe, by the ≈øpace of one day. Afterward hee cau≈øed him to be ≈øtripped, and by his executioners to be taken and dragged through the Citie, mo≈øt ignominiou≈øly, and cruelly whipping him, charging him be≈øides, with outragious and contumel ‚Ä¢ ous ≈øpeeches. All which notwith≈øtanding, as one no whit di≈ømaied, hee ever ≈øhewed a con≈øtant and re≈øolute heart. And with a cheerefull and bold countenance went on ≈øtill, lowdly recounting the honourable and glorious cau≈øe of his death, which was, that hee would never con≈øent to yeeld his Countrie into the handes of a cruell tyrant, menacing him with an imminent puni≈øhment of the Gods. Shall thy vengeance and cruelties never have an end? Is thy life of that worth, as it may counter vaile the ≈øundry mi≈øchiefes that are like to en≈øue, if it be pre≈øerved? Livia his wife being in bed with him, perceiving his agonie, and hearing his ≈øpeeches, ≈øaid thus vnto him: And may not womens coun≈øels be admitted? Doe as Phy≈øitians are woont, who when their ordinarie receipts will not worke, have recour≈øe to the contrarie. Hitherto thou coulde≈øt never doe any good with ≈øeveritie: Lepidus hath followed Savidienus, Murena Lepidus, Coepio Murena, Egnatius Scoepio, beginne now to proove what good lenitie and clemencie will doe thee. Cinna is convicted, pardon him: To annoy or hurt thee now, he is not able, and thou ≈øhalt thereby encrea≈øe thy glory. Augu≈øtus ≈øeemed very glad to have found an Advocate of his humour, and having thanked his wife, and countermaunded his friends, whom he had ≈øummoned to the Coun≈øell, commaunded Cinna to be brought before him alone. Then ≈øending all men out of his chamber, and a chaire prepared for Cinna to ≈øit in, he thus be≈øpake him: Fir≈øt Cinna, I require to have gentle audience, and that thou wilt not interrupt my ≈øpeech, which ended, I will give thee time and lea≈øure to an≈øwer me: Thou knowe≈øt (oh Cinna) that when I had taken thee pri≈øoner in mine enemies campe, who wast not only become, but borne my foe; I ≈øaved thee, then put thee in quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of thy goods, and at last, have ≈øo enriched thee, and placed thee in ≈øo high a degree, that even the conquerours are become envious over the conquered. The Prie≈øtes office, which thou beggedst at my hands, I freely be≈øtowed on thee, having fir≈øt refu≈øed the ≈øame to others, who≈øe fathers and friendes had in many battels ≈øhead their bloud for me: After all which benefites, and that I had in dutie tied thee ≈øo fast vnto me, thou ha≈øt notwith≈øtanding vndertaken to kill me. To whom Cinna replied, crying alowde, That he had never ≈øo much as conceived ≈øo wicked a thought, much le≈ø≈øe entertained the ≈øame. Oh Cinna, this is not according to thy promi≈øe, an≈øwered then Augu≈øtus, which was, that thou woulde≈øt not interrupt me: What I ≈øay, is true, thou ha≈øt vndertaken to murther me, in ≈øuch a place, on ≈øuch a day, in ≈øuch a company, and in ≈øuch manner: and ≈øeeing him ≈øo amazed in heart, and by his evidence ≈øtrucken dombe, moved thereunto, not by the condition of his promi≈øe, but by the guilt of his ≈øelfe-accu≈øing con≈øcience; why woulde≈øt thou doe it, replied he, is it becau≈øe thou woulde≈øt be Emperour? Truely the common-wealth is but in hard condition, if none but my ≈øelfe hinder thee from the Empire. The ‚Ä¢ can≈øt not ≈øo much as defend thine owne hou≈øe, and did≈øt but lately loo≈øe a proce≈ø≈øe, only by the favor of a≈øeely libertine. What? ha≈øt thou no meane or power in any other matter, but to attempt Cae≈øars life? I quit it, if there be no man but my ≈øelfe to impeach thy hopes. Suppo≈øe≈øt thou that Paulus, that Fabius, that the Co≈ø≈øenians or the Servillianes will ever permit thee? And ≈øo great a troupe of noble men, noble, not onely in name, but ≈øuch as by their vertues honour their nobilitie, will ever ≈øuffer it? After many other ≈øuch like di≈øcour≈øes (for he talked with him more than two houres) he ≈øaid vnto him; Away, oh Cinna, that life which once I gave thee, as to an enemie, I now give thee againe, as to a traitour, and a patricide: let a true friend≈øhip from this day forward begin betwene vs, let vs ≈øtrive together, which of vs two with a better faith ≈øhall out-goe the other, and whether I have given thy life, or thou ha≈øt received the ≈øame with great confidence: and ≈øo left him. Shortly after he gave him the Con≈øul≈øhip, blaming him that he dur≈øt not aske it of him. And ever after held him as his deere friend, and made him alone, heire and executor of his goodes. Now after this accident, which hapned to Augustus in the xl. yeare of his age, there was never any con≈øpiracie or enterpri≈øe attempted again≈øt him; and he received a ju≈øt reward
for his ≈øo great clemency. But the like ≈øucceeded not to our Prince, for his mildne≈ø≈øe and lenitie, could not ≈øo warrant him, but that afterward he fell into the ≈ønares of the like trea≈øon: ≈øo vaine and frivolous a thing is humane wi≈øedome: and contrary to al projects, devi≈øes, coun≈øels, & precautions, fortune doth ever keepe a full ≈øway and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all events. We count tho≈øe Phi≈øitians happy and ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull, that ≈øucce≈ø≈øefully end a de≈øperate cure, or come to a good i≈ø≈øue: as if there were no other arte but theirs, that could not ≈øub≈øi≈øt of it ≈øelfe, and who≈øe foundations were too feeble, to ≈øtand and relie vpon her owne ≈øtrength: and as if there were none but it, that ≈øtandes in neede of fortunes helpe-affoording hand, for the effecting of her operations. My conceit of it, is both the wor≈øt and the be≈øt a man may imagine: for thankes be to God, there is no commerce betweene vs: I am contrary to others; for I ever de≈øpi≈øe it, and when I am ≈øick, in ≈øtead of entring into league or compo≈øition with it, I then beginne to hate and feare it mo≈øt: and an≈øwere ≈øuch as vrge mee to take Phy≈øicke, that at lea≈øt they will tarie till ≈øuch time as I have recovered my health and ≈øtrength againe; that then I may the better be enabled to endure the violence and hazard of their potions. I let nature worke, and pre≈øuppo≈øe vnto my ≈øelfe, that ≈øhe hath provided her ≈øelfe, both of teeth and clawes, to defend her ≈øelf from ≈øuch a≈ø≈øaults as ≈øhal be≈øet her, and to maintaine this contexture or frame, who≈øe di≈ø≈øolution it ≈øo much hateth. In liew of bringing helpe vnto her, when ≈øhee mo≈øt ≈øtriveth, and is combated by ≈øickene≈ø≈øe, I greatly feare le≈øt I bring ≈øuccor vnto her adver≈øarie, and ≈øurcharge her with new enemies. Now I conclude, that not onely in Phi≈øicke, but likewi≈øe in ≈øundry more certaine artes, fortune hath great ≈øhare in them. The Poeticall furies, which ravi≈øh and tran≈øport their Author beyond him≈øelfe, why ≈øhall we not a≈øcribe them to his good fortune, ≈øince him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øeth, that they exceede his ≈øtrength and ≈øufficiencie, and acknowledgeth to proceede from el≈øewhere, than from him≈øelfe, and that they are not in his power, no more than Orators ≈øay to have tho≈øe ≈øtrange motions and extraordinary agitations, that in their arte tran≈øport them beyond their purpo≈øe? The like wee ≈øee to bee in painting, for ≈øometimes the Painters hand ≈øhall draw certaine lines or draughts, ≈øo farre exceeding his conception or skill, that him≈øelfe is forced to enter into admiration and amazement. But fortune yet doth much more evidently ≈øhewe, the ≈øhare ≈øhee hath in all their workes, by the graces and beauties that often are found in them, not only beyond the intent, but be≈øides the very knowledge of the workman. A heedy Reader ≈øhall often di≈øcover in other mens compo≈øitions, perfections farre-differing from the Authors meaning, and ≈øuch as haply he never dreamed of, and illu≈øtrateth them with richer ≈øen≈øes, and more excellent con≈øtructions. As for military enterpri≈øes, no man is ≈øo blinde but ≈øeeth what ≈øhare fortune hath in them: even in our coun≈øels and deliberations, ≈øome chance or good lucke mu≈øt needs be joyned to them, for what≈øoever our wi≈øedome can effect, is no great matter. The ≈øharper and quicker it is, more weakene≈ø≈øe findes it in it≈øelfe, and ≈øo much the more doth it di≈øtru≈øt it≈øelfe. I am of Sillaes opinion: and when I neare≈øt con≈øider the mo≈øt glorious exploites of warre, me thinkes I ≈øee, that tho≈øe who have the conduct of them, employ neyther coun≈øell nor deliberation about them, but for fa≈øhion-≈øake, and leave the be≈øt part of the enterpri≈øe to fortune, and on the confidence they have in her ayde, they ≈øtill go beyond the limits of all di≈øcour≈øe. Ca≈øuall rejoycings, and ≈øtrange furies en≈øue among their deliberations, which for the mo≈øt induce them to take the coun≈øell lea≈øt grounded vpon apparance or rea≈øon, and which quaile their courage beyond rea≈øon; whence it hath ≈øucceeded vnto diver≈øe great Captaines, by giving credite to ≈øuch ra≈øh coun≈øels, and aleaging to their ≈øouldiers, that by ≈øome divine in≈øpiration, and other ≈øignes and progno≈øtications, they were encouraged to ≈øuch and ≈øuch enterpri≈øes. Loe here wherefore in this vncertainty and perplexitie, which the impui≈ø≈øances and inabilitie doth bring vs to ≈øee and chu≈øe what is mo≈øt commodious, for the difficulties which the divers accidents and circum≈øtances of everie thing drawe with them: the ≈øure≈øt way, if other con≈øiderations did not invite vs thereto, is, in my conceit, to follow the partie, wherein is mo≈øt hone≈øtie and ju≈øtice; and ≈øince a man doubteth of the neare≈øt way, ever to keepe the right. As in the≈øe two examples I have lately mentioned, there is no doubt, but that it was more commendable and generous in him, who had received the offence, to remit and pardon the ≈øame, than to have done otherwi≈øe. If the fir≈øt had but ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, his good intent is not to be blamed; and no man knoweth, had he taken the contrary way, whether he ≈øhould have e≈øcaped the end, to which his de≈øtinie called him; and then had he lo≈øt the glorie and commendations, of ≈øo ≈øeld-≈øeene humanitie. Sundrie
men po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with this feare, are read-of in auncient Hi≈øtories; the greate≈øt part of which have followed the way of fore-running the con≈øpiracies, which were complotted again≈øt them, by revenge or tortures, but I ≈øee very few, that by this remedy have received any good; witne≈ø≈øe ≈øo many Romane Emperours. Hee that perceiveth him≈øelfe to be in this danger, ought not much to relie vpon his power, or hope in his vigilancie. For, how hard a matter is it, for a man to warrant and ≈øafegard him≈øelfe from an enemie, that masks vnder the vi≈øage of the mo≈øt officious and heartie-≈øeeming friend we have? And to knowe the inward thoughts and minde-concealed meanings of ≈øuch as daily attend, and are continually with vs? It will little availe him to have forraine nations to his guard, and ever to be encircled about with troupes of Armed men; who≈øoever he be that re≈øolveth to condemne his owne life, may at any time become ma≈øter of other mens lives.

Moreover that continuall ≈øu≈øpition, which makes the Prince to mi≈øtru≈øt every body, ≈øhould be a wonderfull vexation to his minde. And therefore when Dion was adverti≈øed that Callippus watched to kill him, could never finde in his heart to informe him≈øelfe of it: affirming; He had rather die once, than ever live in feare and mi≈øerie, and to garde him≈øelfe not only from his enemies, but from his very friends. Which thing Alexander pre≈øented more lively and vndantedly by effect, who by a letter of Parme ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o having received adverti≈øement, that Phillip his neere≈øt and be≈øt regarded Phi≈øitian, had with money beene ≈øubborned and corrupted by Darius, to poi≈øon him, who at the very in≈øtant that he gave Phillip the letter to reade, ≈øwallowed downe a potion he had given him: was it not to expre≈ø≈øe his re≈øolution, that if his friends would kill him, he would not ≈øhunne them, but con≈øent to their treachery? This Prince is the Soveraigne patterne of hazardous attempts: yet know I not whether in all his life, he ≈øhewed an act of more re≈øolute con≈øtancie, than this, nor an ornament ≈øo many waies famous. Tho≈øe which daily preach and buzze in Princes eares, vnder colour of their ≈øafetie a hee ‚Ä¢ y diffidence and ever-warie di≈øtru≈øtfulne≈ø≈øe, doe nought but tell them of their ruine, and further their ≈øhame and downefall. No noble act is atchived without danger. I know one by his owne complexion of a right martiall courage, and ready for any re≈øolution, who≈øe good and hopefull fortune is dayly corrupted by ≈øuch verball per≈øwa≈øions; as fir≈øt to keepe clo≈øe with his friends; never to li≈øten to any reconciliation with his olde enemies: to ≈øtand vpon his owne guarde; never to commit him≈øelfe to any ≈øtronger then him≈øelfe, what faire prom≈øe ≈øoever they make him, or what≈øoever apparant profit they ≈øeeme to containe. I al≈øo know another, who becau≈øe he did ever follow the contrarie coun≈øell, and would never li≈øten to ≈øuch ≈øchoole-rea≈øons, hath beyond all hope rai≈øed his fortune above the common reach. That boldene≈ø≈øe wherewith they ≈øo greedily gape after glory, is alwaies at hand, when ever neede ≈øhall be, as gloriou≈øly in a dublet as in an armor; in a cabinet as in a campe; the arme held downe, as lifted vp. A wi≈øedome ≈øo tenderly-preci≈øe, and ≈øo preci≈øely-circum≈øpect, is a mortall enemie to haughty executions. Scipio, to ≈øound the depth of Siphax intent, and to di≈øcover his minde; leaving his armie, and abandoning the yet vn≈øetled country of Spaine, which vnder his new conque≈øt of it, was likely to be ≈øu≈øpected, he I ≈øay, could pa≈ø≈øe into Affrike only with two ≈øimple ≈øhips or ≈ømall barkes, to commit him≈øelfe in a ≈øtrange and foe countrie, to engage his per≈øon, vnder the power of a barbarous King, vnder an vnknowne faith, without either ho≈øtage, or letters of credence, yea without any body, but onely vpon the a≈ø≈øurance of the greatne≈ø≈øe of his courage, of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull good fortune, and of the promi≈øe of his high-rai≈øed hopes. Habita fides ip≈øam plerumque fidem obligat. Mo≈øt commonly tru≈øting obligeth tru≈øtine≈ø≈øe. To an ambicious and famea≈øpiring minde, contrariwi≈øe, a man mu≈øt yeeld little, and cary a hard hand again≈øt ≈øu≈øpitions: Feare and di≈øtru≈øt draw on offences and allure them. The mo≈øt mi≈øtru≈øtfull of our Kings e≈øtabli≈øhed his affaires, and ≈øetled his e≈øtate, e≈øpecially becau≈øe he had voluntarily given over, abandoned and committed his life and libertie, to the hands and mercy of his enemies: Seeming to put his whole confidence in them, that ≈øo they might likewi≈øe conceive an vndoubted affiance in him. Cae≈øar did onely confront his mutinous legions, and oppo≈øe his hardly-ruled Armies, with the minde-quelling authoritie of his countenance, and awemooving fiercene≈ø≈øe of his wordes: and did ≈øo much tru≈øt him≈øelfe and his fortune, that he no whit feared to abandon and commit him≈øelfe to a ≈øeditious and rebellious Armie.

div.p:
True it is, that this vndaunted a≈ø≈øurance can not ≈øo fully and lively be repre≈øented, but by tho≈øe in whom the imagination or apprehen≈øion of death, and of the wor≈øt that may happen, can ≈øtrike no amazement at all: for, to repre≈øent it fearefully-trembling, doubtfull and vncertaine, for the ≈øervice of an important reconciliation, is to effect no great matter: It is an excellent motive to gaine the heart and good will of others, for a man to go and ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to them, provided it be done freely, and without con≈øtraint of any nece≈ø≈øitie, and in ≈øuch ≈øort, that a man bring a pure and vn≈øpotted confidence with him, and at lea≈øt his countenance void of all ≈øcruple. Being yet a child, I ≈øaw a gentleman, who had the command of a great Citie, and by a commotion of a ≈øeditiou≈øly-furious people greatly put to his plunges, who to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the ri≈øing-fire of this tumult, re≈øolved to ≈øally out from a ≈øtrongly-a≈ø≈øured place, where he was ≈øafe, and yeeld him≈øelfe to that many-headed mon≈øter mutinous rowt; thrived ≈øo ill by it, that he was mi≈øerably ≈ølaine among≈øt them: yet deeme I not his over≈øight to have beene ≈øo great an i≈ø≈øuing out, his memorie being of mo≈øt men condemned, as becau≈øe he tooke a way of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and remi≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe, and attempted to extingui≈øh that rage and hurly-burly, rather by way of following, than of guiding, and by requiring ≈øute, than by demon≈øtrative re≈øolution: and I deeme a gratiou≈øly-milde ≈øeveritie, with a militarie commandement, full of confidence and ≈øecuritie, be≈øeeming his ranke, and the dignitie of his charge, had better availed him, had beene more ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull, at lea≈øt with more honour, and well ≈øeeming comline≈ø≈øe. There is nothing le≈ø≈øe to bee expected or hoped for at the hands of this mon≈øtrous-faced-multitude, thus agitated by furie, then humanitie and gentlene≈ø≈øe; it will much ≈øooner receive reverence, and admit feare. I might al≈øo blame him, that having vndertaken a re≈øolution (in my judgement, rather brave then ra≈øh) to ca≈øt him≈øelfe incon≈øiderately, weake and vnarmed, amid≈øt a tempe≈øtuous Ocean of ≈øencele≈ø≈øe and mad men, he ≈øhould have gone through-≈øtitch with it, and not leave the per≈øon he repre≈øented in the briers, whereas, after he had perceived the danger at hand, he chanced to bleede at the no≈øe; and then to change that demi≈ø≈øe and flattering countenance he had vndertaken, into a di≈ømaide and drooping looke, filling both voice and eyes with a≈øtoni≈øhment and repentance: and ≈øeeking to ≈øquat him≈øelfe, hee the more enflamed, and called them vpon him. It was determined, there ≈øhould be a generall mu≈øter made of divers troupes of armed men (a place fitte≈øt for ≈øecret revenges, and where they may ≈øafe≈øt be atchieved) there were mo≈øt apparant rea≈øons, that the place was very vn≈øure, or at lea≈øt, to be ≈øu≈øpected, by ≈øuch as were to have the principall and nece≈ø≈øary charge to ≈øurvey them. Divers coun≈øels were propo≈øed, ≈øundry opinions heard, as in a ≈øubject of great difficultie, and on which depended ≈øo many weightie con≈øequences. My advi≈øe was, they ≈øhould carefully avoide to give any te≈øtimonie of ≈øu≈øpition, or ≈øhew of doubt, and that our troupes ≈øhould be as full as might be, and the Fyles orderly ranked, and every Souldier ≈øhew an vndanted carriage, and vndi≈ømaied countenance, and in ≈øtead of keeping ≈øome of our forces backe (which thing mo≈øt opinions aimed at) all Captaines ≈øhould be put in minde to admoni≈øh their Souldiers to make their ≈øallies as orderly and as ≈øtrong as might be, in honour of the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; and ≈øpare no powder, which would ≈øerve as a gratification toward the≈øe ≈øu≈øpectfull troupes, which afterward cau≈øed a mutuall and profitable confidence. I finde the cour≈øe that Iu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s Cae≈øar held to be the be≈øt a man may take: Fir≈øt he a≈ø≈øeved by clemencie to purcha≈øe the love of his very enemies, contenting him≈øelfe in the con≈øpiracies that were di≈øcovered vnto him, ≈øimply to ≈øhew they were not vnknowen to him, but had perfect notice of them. That done, he tooke a mo≈øt noble re≈øolution, which was, without dread or di≈ømay, or any care-taking, to attend what≈øoever might betide him, wholy abandoning and remitting him≈øelfe into the hands of the Gods and of fortune. For certainely, it is the ≈øtate wherein he was, when he was murthered in the Senate. A ≈øtranger having publi≈øhed every where, that he could teach Diony≈øius the tyrant of Siracu≈øa away to vnder≈øtand and di≈øcover the very certaintie of all the practi≈øes, his ≈øubjects or any el≈øe ≈øhould practi≈øe again≈øt him, if he would be≈øtow a good ≈øumme of money vpon him: Diony≈øius being thereof adverti≈øed, ≈øent for him, to di≈øcover the ≈øecret and vnder≈øtand the truth of ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie an arte for his pre≈øervation: the ≈øtranger tolde him, there was no other skill in his arte, but that
he ≈øhould deliver him a talent, and then boa≈øt hee had learned the v≈øe of ≈øo vnvaluable a ≈øecret of him. Diony≈øius allowed of his invention, and forthwith cau≈øed ≈øix hundred crownes to be delivered him. It is not likely that ever he would have given ≈øo great a ≈øumme of mony to an vnknowne man, but in reward of a mo≈øt profitable in≈øtruction; for by way of this reputaion he kept his enemies ≈øtill in awe. And therefore doe Princes wi≈øely publi≈øh ≈øuch adverti≈øements as they receive of the plots con≈øpired, and trea≈øons, practi≈øed again≈øt their lives and ≈øtates, thereby to make men beleeve, that nothing can be attempted again≈øt them, but they ≈øhall have knowledge of it. The Duke of Athens committed many fond over≈øights in the e≈øtabli≈øhing of his late tyrannie vpon the Florentines, but this the chiefe≈øt, that having received the fir≈øt adverti≈øement of the Monopolies and Complots the Florentines contrived again≈øt him, by Mathew, ≈øurnamed Morozo, one of the complices, thinking to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe this warning, and conceale that any in the Citie were offended at him, or grudged at his rule, cau≈øed him immediatly to be put to death. I remember to have heretofore read the ≈øtorie of a Romane (a man of ≈øpeciall dignitie) who flying the tyrannie of the Triumuirate, had many times by the ≈øutteltie of his invention, e≈øcaped tho≈øe who pur≈øued him. Plato in his Lawes, thinkes there is no wor≈øe plague, or more pernicious in his Citie, then to ≈øuffer youth, to have the reines of libertie in her owne hand, to change in their attires, in their ge≈øtures, dances, exerci≈øes, and ≈øongs, from one forme to an other: And to remove their judgement, now to this, now to that place; following new-fangled devi≈øes, and regarding their inventors: By which, old cu≈øtomes are corrupted, and ancient in≈øtitutions de≈øpi≈øed. div.head: The foure and fortieth Chapter.
div.p:
REa≈øon doth appoint-vs ever to walke in one path, but not alwaies to keep one place: And that a wi≈øe-man ≈øhould not permit humane pa≈ø≈øions to ≈øtray from the right carrier; he may (without prejudice vnto his dutie) al≈øo leave-it vnto them either to ha≈øten or to ≈ølow his pace, and not place him≈øelfe as an immoveable and impa≈ø≈øible Colo≈ø≈øus. Were vertue her≈øelfe corporeall and incarnate, I think her pul≈øe would beat and worke ≈øtronger, marching to an a≈ø≈øault, then going to dinner: For, it is nece≈ø≈øarie that ≈øhe heat and move her≈øelfe. I have therefore mark't-it as a rare thing; to ≈øee great per≈øonages ≈øometimes, even in their weightie≈øt enterpri≈øes, and mo≈øt important affaires, hold them≈øelves ≈øo re≈øolutelya≈ø≈øured in their ≈øtate, that they doe not ≈øo much as breake their ≈øleepe for them. Alexander the great, on the day appointed for that furious-bloodie battle again≈øt Darius, ≈ølept ≈øo ≈øoundly and ≈øo long that morning, that Parmenion was faine to enter his chamber, & approching neere vnto his bed, twice or thrice to call him by his name, to awaken him, the houre of the battle being at hand, and vrging him. Otho the Emperour having determined to kill him≈øelfe, the very ≈øame night, after he had given order for his dome≈øticall affaires, ≈øhared his
monie among≈øt his ≈øervans, and whetted the edge of a ≈øword, wherewith he intended to wound him≈øelfe, expecting no other thing, but to know whether all his friends were gone to re≈øt, fell into ≈øo ≈øound a ≈øleepe, that the groomes of his chamber heard him ≈ønort in another roome. This Emperours death hath many parts ≈øemblable vnto that of great Cato, and namely this: For, Cato being prepared to defeat him≈øelfe, while≈øt he expected to heare newes, whether the Senators, whom he cau≈øed to retire, were lanched out from the haven of Vtica, fell ≈øo fa≈øt a≈øleep, that he was heard to ≈ønort into the next chamber: And he whom he had ≈øent toward the port, having awaked him, to tell him, the ≈øtorme was ≈øo rough, that the Senators could not conveniently put out to ≈øea, he ≈øent another, and lying downe a new, fell a≈øleep againe, vntill the la≈øt me≈ø≈øenger a≈ø≈øured him, they were gone. We may al≈øo compare him vnto Alexander, in that great and dangerous ≈øtorme, which threatned him, by the ≈øedition of Metellus the Tribune, who laboured to publi≈øh the decree of Pompeys re-appeal into the Citie, together with his armie, at what time the commotion of Catiline was on foote: again≈øt which decree onely Cato did in≈øi≈øt, and to that purpo≈øe had Metellus and he had many injurious ≈øpeeches, and menaced one another in the Senate-hou≈øe: And it was the next day, they were like to come to the execution in the market-place, where Metellus, be≈øides the favour of the common people, and of Cae≈øar then con≈øpiring and complotting for the aduancement of Pompey, ≈øhould come, accompanied with a multitude of ≈øtrange and fortaine ≈ølaves and fencers, to doe their vtmo≈øt: And Cato ≈øtrengthened with his onely con≈øtancie, and with an vnmated re≈øolve: So that his kin≈ømen, his familiars, and many hone≈øt men tooke great care, and were in heavie anxietie and pen≈øivene≈ø≈øe for him: of which many never left him all night, but ≈øate vp together, without re≈øt, eating, or drinking, by rea≈øon of the danger they ≈øaw prepared for him; yea, his wife and ≈øi≈øters did nought but weep and waile, and for his ≈øake torment them≈øelves in their hou≈øe, whereas contrariwi≈øe he alone comforted every bodie, and blamed them, for their demi≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe: And after he had ≈øupped, (as he was wont) he went quietly to his bed, and ≈ølept verie ≈øoundly vntill the next morning, that one of his copartners in the Tribune-≈øhip, came to call him, to goe to the skirmi≈øh. The knowledge we have of this mans vnmated-haughtie heart, by there≈øt of his life; may make vs judge with all ≈øecuritie, that it onely proceeded from a ≈øpirit, ≈øo far elevated above ≈øuch accidents, that he dained not ≈øo much as to trouble his mind with them, no more then with ordinarie chances. In the ≈øea-fight, which Augu≈øtus gained again≈øt Sextus Pompeius in Sicilie, even at the in≈øtant he ≈øhould go to fight, was ≈øurpri≈øed with ≈øo heavie a ≈øleep, that his friends were compelled to awaken-him, to give the ≈øignall of the battell; which afterward gave occa≈øion vnto Marcus Antonius, to charge him with this imputation, that he had not dared with open eyes to ≈øurvay the mar≈øhalling of his armie, and that his heart would not ≈øuffice him, to pre≈øent him≈øelfe vnto his ≈øouldiers, vntill ≈øuch time that Agrippa brought him newes of the victorie he had obtained of his enemies. But concerning yong Marius, who committed a greater errour (for on the day of his la≈øt battel again≈øt Sylla, after he had mar≈øhalled his armie, and given the word or ≈øignall of the battell) he lay downe in the ≈øhadow vnder a tree, a while to re≈øt him≈øelfe, and fell ≈øo fa≈øt a≈øleep, that he could hardly be awaked with the rout and flight of his men, having ≈øeen no part of the fight, they ≈øay, it was becau≈øe he was ≈øo exceedingly aggravated with travell, and over-tired with wearine≈ø≈øe, and want of ≈øleep, that nature was overcome, and could no longer endure. And touching this point, Phi≈øitians may con≈øider; whether ≈øleep be ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie, that our life mu≈øt needs depend of-it: For we find that Per≈øeus King of Macedon, pri≈øoner at Rome, being kept from ≈øleep, was made to die; but Plinie aleadgeth, that ≈øome have lived a long time without any ≈øleep at all. And Herodotus reporteth, There are Nations, where men ≈øleep and wake by halfe yeares. And tho≈øe that write the life of Epimenides the wi≈øe, affirme, that he ≈ølept the continuall ≈øpace of ≈øeaven and fiftie yeares.

div.head: The five and fortieth Chapter.
div.p: THere hapned divers rare accidents, and remarkable chances in our battell of Dreux: but tho≈øe who do not greatly favour the reputation of the Duke of Gui≈øe, doe boldly aledge, that he cannot be excu≈øed, to have made a ≈øtand, and tempori≈øed with the forces he commaunded, whil≈øt the Lord Con≈øtable of France, Generall of the Armie, was engaged and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed with the enemies Artillerie, and that it had been better for him, to hazard him≈øelfe, to charge the enemie flankwi≈øe, then by expecting any aduantage, to have him come behind him, to ≈øuffer ≈øo reprochfull an overthrow, and ≈øo ≈øhamefull a lo≈ø≈øe. But omitting what the event thereof witne≈ø≈øed, he that ≈øhall without pa≈ø≈øion debate the matter, ≈øhall ea≈øilie (in my conceit) confe≈ø≈øe, that the ayme and drift, not onely of a Captaine, but of every particular Souldier, ought chiefly to re≈øpect a victorie in great: And that no particular occurrences, of what con≈øequence ≈øoever, or what intere≈øt may depend on them, ≈øhould never divert-him from that point. Philopoemen in an encounter with Machanidas, having ≈øent before, a ≈øtrong troupe of Archers, and good marke men, to begin the skirmi≈øh: and the enemie, after he had put them to route and di≈ø-ranked them, ammu≈øing him≈øelfe in mainly pur≈øuing them, and following the victorie along≈øt the maine battell, where Philopoemen was, although his ≈øouldiers were much moved and offended to ≈øee their fellowes put to the wor≈øt, he could not be induced to bouge from his place, nor make head again≈øt his enemie, to ≈øuccour his men; but rather, having ≈øuffered them to be defeated, and cut in pieces before his face, began then to charge his enemies in the battalion of their Infanterie, when he perceived them for≈øaken of their hor≈øemen: And albeit they were Lacedemonians, fora≈ømuch as he charged them, at what time (≈øuppo≈øing to have gained the day) they began to di≈øorder them≈øelves, he ea≈øilie overcame them; which done, he pur≈øued Machanidas. This ca≈øe, is cou≈øin-german vnto that of the Duke of Gui≈øe. In that ≈øharpe-bloodie battell of Age≈øilaus again≈øt the Boeotians, which Xenophon (who was there pre≈øent) ≈øaith, To have beene the whotte≈øt and rude≈øt, that ever he had ≈øeene: Age≈øilaus refu≈øed the advantage, which fortune pre≈øented him, to let the battalion of the Boeotians pa≈ø≈øe, and to charge them behind, what certaine victorie ≈øoever he ≈øaw likely to follow the ≈øame, e≈øteeming that it were rather skill then valour, and to ≈øhew his prowe≈ø≈øe, and matchle≈ø≈øe-haughtie courage, cho≈øe rather to charge them in the front of their forces: But what followed? He was well beaten, and him≈øelfe ≈øore-hurt, and in the end compelled to leave his enterpri≈øe, and embrace the re≈øolution, which in the beginning he had refu≈øed, cau≈øing his men to open them≈øelves, to give pa≈ø≈øage vnto that torrent of the Boeotians; who when they were pa≈øtthrough, perceiving them to march in di≈øaray, as they who per≈øwaded them≈øelves to be out of all danger, he pur≈øued them, and charged them flank-wi≈øe. All which notwith≈øtanding, he could never put to route, or force them run-away, for they, orderly, and faire and ≈øoftly made their retreit, ever ≈øhewing their face, vntill ≈øuch time as they got ≈øafely into their houlds and trenches.

div.head: The ≈øixe and fortieth Chapter.
div.p:
WHat diver≈øitie ≈øoever there-be in hearbs, all are ≈øhuffled-vp together vnder the name of a ≈øallade. Even ≈øo, vpon the con≈øideration of names, I will heer huddlevpa gallymafrie of diver≈øe articles. Every ≈øeverall nation hath ≈øome names, which, I wot not how
are ≈øometimes taken in ill part, as with vs Iacke, Hodge, Tom, Will, Bat, Benet, and ≈øo forth. Item, it ≈øeemeth that in the genealogies of Princes, there are certaine names fatally affected; as Ptolomeus with the Aegyptians, Henries in England, Charles in France, Baldwins in Flanders, and Williams in our ancient Aqustanie, whence ≈øome ≈øay came the name of Gui ‚Ä¢ nne; which is but a cold invention: As if in Plato him≈øelfe there were not ≈øome as har≈øh and ill-founding. Item, it is an idle matter, yet neverthele≈ø≈øe, by rea≈øon of the ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe, worthie the memorie, and recorded by an oculare witne≈ø≈øe, that Henrie Duke of Normandie ≈øonne to Henrie the ≈øecond King of England, making a great fea≈øt in France, the a≈ø≈øemblie of the Nobilitie was ≈øo great, that for pa≈øtimes ≈øake, being, by the re≈øemblance of their names, divided into ≈øeverall companies: in the fir≈øt were found a hundred and ten Kinghts ≈øitting at one table, and all called Williams; be≈øides private Gentlemen and ≈øervants. It is as plea≈øant to di≈øtribute the tables by the names of the a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, as it was vnto Geta the Emperor, who would have all his me≈ø≈øes or di≈øhes ≈øerved-in at his table orderly according to the fir≈øt letters of their names; As for example, tho≈øe that began with P. as pig, pie, pike, puddings, pouts, porke, pancakes, &c. were all ≈øerved in together; and ≈øo of all the re≈øt. Item, it is a common ≈øaying, That it is good to have a good name: As much to ≈øay, good credit, or good reputation. Yet verely it is verie commodious to have a well-≈øounding and ≈ømooth name, and which is ea≈øie to be pronounced, and facile to be remembred: For, Kings, Princes, Lords, and Magi≈øtrates know and remember vs the better by them, and will not ≈øo ≈øoone forget-vs. Marke but of tho≈øe that ≈øerve and follow-vs, whether we doe not more ordinarily commaund, and ≈øooner employ ≈øuch, who≈øe names come readier to our tongue, or memorie. I have ≈øeene our King Henrie the ≈øecond, who could never ‚Ä¢ it on the right name of a Gentleman of Ga≈øcoigne; and did ever call a Ladie waiting on the Queene, by the generall ≈øurname of hir hou≈øe, becau≈øe that of hir father was ≈øo har≈øh, and hard to be remembred. And Socrates ≈øaith, It ought to be a fathers ≈øpeciall care, to give his children good and ea≈øie-≈øounding names. Item, it is reported, that the foundation of our Ladie the great at Poitiers had this beginning; A licentious yoong man having his dwelling hou≈øe where the Church now ≈øtandeth, had one night gotten a wench to lie with him, who ≈øo ≈øoone as ≈øhe came to bed, he demaunded hir name, who an≈øwered, Marie: The yong man hearing that name, was ≈øodainly ≈øo ≈øtrucken with a motive of religion, and an awefull re≈øpect vnto that ≈øacred name, of the virgin Marie, the ble≈ø≈øed mother of our Saviour and Redeemer, that he did not only pre≈øently put hir away from him, but reformed all the remainder of his ≈øucceeding life: And that in con≈øideration of this miracle, there was fir≈øt erected a Chappell in the place where this yong mans hou≈øe ≈øtood, con≈øecrated vnto that holy name, and afterward the faire great church, which yet continueth. This vocale and auricular correction, and ≈øo full of devotion, ≈øtrucke right vnto his ≈øoule. This other following, of the ≈øame kind, in≈øinuated it≈øelfe by the corporall ≈øences. Pythagoras being in companie with two yong men, whom he heard complot and con≈øult (being ≈øomewhat heated with fea≈øting and drinking) to go and ravi≈øh a cha≈øt-hou≈øe, commaunded immediatly the min≈øtrels to change their tune; and ≈øo by a ≈øolemne, grave, ≈øevere, and ≈øpondaicall kind of mu≈øicke, did ≈øweetly inchaunt allay, and in-trance their ra≈øhviolent‚ñ™ and lawle≈ø≈øe lu≈øt. Item, ≈øhall nor ≈øucceeding po≈øteritie ≈øay, that our moderne reformation hath been exact and delicate, to have not onely oppugned and re≈øi≈øted errors and vices, and filled the world with devotion, humilitie, obedience, peace, and every other kind of vertue, but even to have combated their ancient names of bapti≈øme, Charles, Lewis, Francis, to people the world with Methu≈øalem, Ezechiel, Malachie, much better feeling of a lively faith? A Gentleman my neighbour, e≈øteeming the commodities of ancient times in regard of our daies, forgot not to aledge the fiercene≈ø≈øe and magnificence of the names of the Nobilitie of tho≈øe times, as Don Grumedan‚ñ™ Quedragan, and Age≈øilan: And that, but to heare them ≈øounded, a man might ea≈øilie perceive; they had been other manner of men; then Peter, Gui ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ , or Michell. Item; I commend and am much beholding to Iames Amiot; in the cour≈øe of a French oration of his to have ≈øtill kept the full ancient Latin names, without di≈øgui≈øing or changing them, to give them a new-French cadence. At the fir≈øt they ≈øeemed ≈øomewhat har≈øh vnto the Reader; but now, by rea≈øon of the credit, which his Plutarke hath de≈øervedly gotten among≈øt-vs, cu≈øtome hath removed all ≈øtrangene≈ø≈øe from-vs. I have often wi≈øhed that tho≈øe who write hi≈øtories in Latin, would leave-vs our names whole, and ≈øuch as they are: For, altering Va ‚Ä¢ demont, to Vallemontanus, and metamorpho≈øing them, by ≈øuring them to the
Graecian or Latin tongue, we know not what to make of them, and are often at a non-plus. To conclude my di≈øcour≈øe; It is an ill cu≈øtome, and of exceeding bad con≈øequence in our countrie of France, to call every man by the name of his Towne, Mannor, Hamlet, or Lord≈øhip, as the thing that doth mo≈øt confound hou≈øes, and bring ≈øur-names out of knowledge. A cadet or yonger-brother of a good hou≈øe, having had for his appanage a Lord≈øhip, by who≈øe name he hath beene knowne and honored, cannot well for≈øake and leave the ≈øame ten yeares after his death; His Lord-≈øhip commeth vnto a ≈øtranger, who doth the like: Ghe≈ø≈øe then where we are, and how we ≈øhall doe to come to the perfect knowledge of the≈øe men. Wee need not goe far for other examples, but looke into our Royall hou≈øe, where ≈øo many partages, ≈øo many ≈øur-names, and ≈øo many ≈øeverall titles have ≈øo encumbred-vs, that the originall of the ≈øtocke is vtterly lo≈øt. There is ≈øo much libertie in the≈øe mutations, that even in my time, I have ≈øeen no man nor woman advanced by fortune vnto ≈øome extraordinarie preferment, that hath not immediatly had adjoyned vnto him or hir Genealogicall titles, new and vnknowne to their fathers, and that hath not beene engraffed into ≈øome noble ≈øtocke or familie. And as good lucke ≈øerveth, the ba≈øe≈øt vp≈øtart, and mo≈øt ob≈øcure hou≈øes are mo≈øt apt vnto adulteration, and fal≈øification. How many privat Gentlemen have ‚Ä¢ e in France, which according to their accompt, and blazoning of their gentrie, are of the royall blood or race? I beleeve more then others. Was it not pretilie ≈øaid, and with a good grace, by one of my friends? There was a great companie bandied together about a quarell which a Gentleman had with another, who in verie truth had ≈øome prerogative of titles, honours, and alliances aboue the common ≈øort of Nobilitie; vpon which word of his prerogative, every one ≈øeeking to equall him≈øelfe vnto him, alledged, ≈øome one of ≈øpring, ≈øome another, ≈øome the re≈øemblance of his name, ≈øome of his armes, other≈øome an old far-fetcht pedigree, and the meane≈øt of them to be the great grand-child of ≈øome King beyond the Seas. When they came all to dinner, this man whom hitherto they had all followed, in liew of taking his wonted place, making low-lowting reverences, went to the lowe≈øt end of the board, entreating the companie to hold him excu≈øed, that through ra≈øh-vnadvi≈øedne≈ø≈øe he had hitherto lived with them companion-like, but now being lately enformed of their right qualities, he began to know them according to their ancient degrees, and that it did not duly belong vnto him to ≈øit above ≈øo many Princes. And after he had acted his play, he began to raile vpon them with a thou≈øand injuries; ≈øaying thus vnto them. For the love of God content your ≈øelves, with what your forefathers have been contented, and with the ≈øtate whereto God hath called-vs: we have ≈øufficient if we can maintaine it well, let-vs not di≈øparage the fortune and condition of our predece≈ø≈øors; and reject-we the≈øe fond imaginations, which can not faile any man, what≈øoever he be, that is ≈øo impudent as to alledge them. Cre≈øts, Armes, and Coates have no more certaintie then ≈øurnames. I beare Azure ≈øem√® of trefoiles, a Lions Paw in faece, Or, armed Gules. But this con≈øideration draweth me perforce vnto an other field. On what doe we e≈øtabli≈øh this tran≈øitorie renowne, which with ≈øo great mind-po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing toyle, and indu≈øtrie we ≈øeeke and gape-after? And what is that but a word for all mouths? or three or foure da≈øhes of a pen, fir≈øt, ≈øo ea≈øie to be varied, as I would willingly aske tho≈øe, whom the honour of ≈øo many victories concerneth, or whether Gue≈øquin, or Gle≈øquin, or Gueaquin? yet were there more apparance heer, then in Lucian that œπ. did ≈øue T. for,

div.p: I vtterly condemne all maner of violence in the education of a yong ≈øpirit, brought vp to honour and liberty. Let vs rea≈øonably accommodate their life, with ≈øuch things as are in our power. And therfore ≈øhould not we marry ≈øo yoong, that our age doe in a maner confound it ≈øelfe with theirs. In a certaine country of the Spani≈øh Indies, no man was ≈øuffered to take a wife, before he were fortie yeares olde, and women might marry at tenne yeares of age. There is no rea≈øon, neither is it convenient, that a Gentleman of five and thirtie yeares, ≈øhould give place to his ≈øonne, that is but twenty: For then is the father as ≈øeemely, and may a≈øwell appeare, and ≈øet him≈øelfe forward, in all manner of voyages of warres, a≈øwell by land as ≈øea, and doe his Prince as good ≈øervice, in court, or el≈øe where, as his ≈øonne: He hath neede of all his parts, and ought truly to impart them, but ≈øo, that he forget not him≈øelfe for others: And to ≈øuch may ju≈øtly that an≈øwere ≈øerve, which fathers have commonly in their mouthes: I will not put off my clothes before I be readie to goe to bed. But a father over-burthend with yeares, and crazed through ≈øickene≈ø≈øe, and by rea≈øon of weakene≈ø≈øe and want of health, barred from the common ≈øocietie of men, doth both wrong him≈øelfe, injure his, idely and to no v≈øe to hoorde vp, and keepe clo≈øe a great heape of riches, and deale of pelfe. The worthie≈øt action, that ever the Emperour Charles the fifth performed was this, in imitation of ≈øome ancients of his quality, that he had the di≈øcretion to know, that rea≈øon commanded vs, to ≈øtrip or ≈øhift our ≈øelves when our cloathes trouble and are too heavie for vs, and that it is high time to goe to bed, when our legges faile vs. He re≈øigned his meanes, his greatne≈ø≈øe and Kingdome to his Sonne, at what time he found his former vndanted re≈øolution to decay, and force to conduct his a≈ølaires, to droope in him≈øelfe, together with the glory he had thereby acquired.

div.p:
This fault, for a man not to be able to know him≈øelfe betimes, and not to feele the impui≈ø≈øance and extreame alteration, that age doth naturally bring, both to the body and the minde (which in mine opinion is equall, if the minde have but one halfe) hath lo≈øt the reputation of the mo≈øt part of the greate≈øt men in the world. I have in my daies both ≈øeene and fam ‚Ä¢ liarly knowen ≈øome men of great authority, whom a man might ea≈øily de≈øcerne, to be ≈øtrangely fallen from that ancient ≈øufficiency, which I know by the reputation they had thereby attained‚ñ™ vnto in their be≈øt yeares. I could willingly for their honors ≈øake have wi≈ø ‚Ä¢ t them at home about their owne bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, di≈øcharged from all negotiations of the commonwealth and employments of war, that were no longer fit for them. I have ≈øometimes been familiar in a Gentlemans hou≈øe, who was both an old man and a widdower, yet lu≈øty of his age. This man had many daughters ‚Ä¢ ariageable, and a ≈øonne growne to mans ≈øtate, and readie to appeare in the world, a thing that drew‚ñ™ on, and was the cau≈øe of great charges, and many vi≈øitations, wherein he tooke but little plea≈øure, not onely for the continuall care hee had to ≈øave, but more by rea≈øon of his age, hee had betaken him-≈øelfe to a manner of life farre different from ours. I chanced one day to tell him ≈øomewhat boldly (as my cu≈øtome is) that it would better be≈øeeme him to give vs place, and re≈øigne his chiefe hou≈øe to his ≈øon (for he had no other mannor-hou≈øe conveniently well furni≈øhed) and quietly retire him≈øelfe to ≈øome farme of his, where no man might trouble him, or di≈øturbe his re≈øt, ≈øince he could not otherwi≈øe avoide our importunitie, ≈øeeing the condition of his children; who afterward followed my coun≈øell, and found great ea≈øe by it. It is not to be ≈øaid, that they have any thing given them by ≈øuch a way of obligation, which a man may not recall againe: I, that am readie to play ≈øuch a part, would give over vnto them the full po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of my
hou≈øe, and enjoying of my goods, but with ≈øuch libertie and limited condition, as if they ≈øhould give me occa≈øion, I might repent my ≈øelfe of my gift, and revoke my deede. I would leave the v≈øe and fruition of all vnto them, the rather becau≈øe it were no longer fit for me to weald the ≈øame. And touching the di≈øpo≈øing of all matters in gro≈ø≈øe, I would re≈øerve what I plea≈øed vnto my ≈øelfe. Having ever judged, that it mu≈øt be a great contentment to an aged father, him≈øelfe to direct his children in the government of his hou≈øhold-affaires, and to be able whil≈øt him≈øelfe liveth, to checke and controule the demeanors: ≈øtoring them with in≈øtruction and advi≈øed coun≈øel according to the experience he hath had of them, and him≈øelf to addre≈ø≈øe the ancient honour and order of his hou≈øe in the handes of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, and that way warrant him≈øelfe of the hopes hee may conceive of their future conduct and after ≈øucce≈ø≈øe. And to this effect, I would not ≈øhunne their company. I would not be far from them, but as much as the condition of my age would permit, enjoy and be a partner of their ≈øports, mirths, and fea≈øts. If I did not continually live among≈øt them (as I could not wel without offending their meetings and hindering their recreation, by rea≈øon of the peevi≈øh frowardne≈ø≈øe of my age, and the trouble of my infirmities, and al≈øo without forcing their rules, and re≈øi≈øting the forme of life, I ≈øhould then follow) I would at lea≈øt live neere them, in ≈øome corner of my hou≈øe, not the be≈øt and faire≈øt in ≈øhew, but the mo≈øt ea≈øefull and commodious. And not as ≈øome yeeres ≈øince, I ≈øaw a Deane of S. Hillarie of Poictiers, reduced by rea≈øon and the incommoditie of his melancholy to ≈øuch a continuall ≈øolitarine≈ø≈øe, that when I entered into his chamber he had never remooved one ≈øtep out of it in two and twenty yeares before: yet had all his faculties free and ea≈øie, onely a rheume excepted that fell into his ≈øtomake. Scar≈øe once a weeke would he ≈øuffer any body to come and ≈øee him. Hee would ever be ≈øhut vp in his chamber all alone, where no man ≈øhould come, except a boy, who once a day brought him meate, and who might not tarrie there, but as ≈øoone as he was in, mu≈øt goe out againe. All his exerci≈øe was ≈øometimes to walke vp and downe his chamber, and now and then reade on ≈øome booke (for he had ≈øome vnder≈øtanding of letters) but ob≈øtinately re≈øolved to live and die in that cour≈øe, as he did ≈øhortly after. I would endevour by a kinde of civill demeanour and milde conver≈øation, to breede and ≈øettle in my children a trueharty-loving friend≈øhip, and vnfained good will towards me. A thing ea≈øily obtained among≈øt well-borne mindes: For, if they proove, or be ≈øuch ≈øurly-furious bea≈øtes, or given to churli≈øh di≈øobedience, as our age bringeth forth thou≈øands, they mu≈øt as bea≈øtes be hated, as churls neglected, and as degenerate avoided. I hate this cu≈øtome, to forbid children to call their fathers father, and to teach them another ≈øtrange name, as of more reverence: As if nature had not ≈øufficiently provided for our authoritie. We call God-almightie by the name of father, and di≈ødaine our children ≈øhould call vs ≈øo. I have reformed this fault in mine owne hou≈øholde. It is al≈øo follie and inju≈øtice to deprive children, e≈øpecially being of competent age, of their fathers familiaritie, and ever to ≈ønew them a ≈øurly, au≈øtere, grim, and di≈ødainefull countenance, hoping thereby to keepe them in awefull feare and duteous obedience. For, it is a very vnprofitable proceeding, and which maketh fathers yrke≈øome vnto children; and which is wor≈øe, ridiculous. They have youth and ≈øtrength in their hands, and con≈øequently, the breath and favour of the worlde; and doe with mockerie and contempt receive the≈øe churli≈øh fierce, and tyrannicall countenaunces, from a man that hath no lu≈øty bloud left him, neither in his heart, nor in his veines; meere bugge-beares, and ≈øcar-crowes, to ≈øcare birdes with all. If it lay in my power to make my ≈øelfe feared, I had rather make my ≈øelfe beloved. There are ≈øo many ≈øortes of defects in age, and ≈øo much impui≈ø≈øance: It is ≈øo ≈øubject to contempt, that the be≈øt purcha≈øe it can make, is the good will, love and affection of hers. I have knowen one who≈øe youth had bin very imperious and rough, but when he came to mans age, although hee live in as good plight and health as may be, yet he cha≈øeth, he ≈øcoldeth, he brawleth, he fighteth, he ≈øweareth, and biteth, as the mo≈øt boi≈øtrous and tempe≈øtuous ma≈øter of France, he frets and con≈øumes him≈øelfe with ca ‚Ä¢ ke and care and vigilancy (all which is but a juglin & ground for his familier to play vpon, and cozen him the more) as for his goods, his garners, his cellers, his coffers, yea his pur≈øe, while≈øt him≈øelfe keepes the keyes of them, clo≈øe in his bo≈øome and vnder his boul≈øter, as charily as he doth his e ‚Ä¢ es, other enjoy and commaund the better part of them; while≈øt he plea≈øeth and fla ‚Ä¢ tereth him≈øelfe, with the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ggardly ≈øparing of his table, all goeth to wracke, and is lavi≈øhly wa≈øted in diver≈øe corners of his hou≈øe, in play, in riotous
≈øpending, and in ≈øoothingly entertaining the accompts or tales of his vaine chafing, fore≈øight and providing. Every man watcheth and keepeth ≈øentinell again≈øt him, if any ≈øilly or needle≈ø≈øe ≈øervant doe by fortune apply him≈øelfe vnto it, he is pre≈øently made to ≈øu≈øpect him: A quality on which age doth immediately bite of it≈øelfe. How many times hath he vaunted and applauding him≈øelfe told me of the ≈øtrict orders of his hou≈øe, of his good husbandry, of the awe he kept his hou≈øhold in, and of the exact obedience, and regardfull reverence he received of all his family, and how cleare-≈øighted he was in his owne bu≈øine≈ø≈øe:

div.p: I know no man that could produce more parts, both naturall and artificiall, fit to pre≈øerve his mai≈øterie, and to maintaine his ab≈øolutene≈ø≈øe, than he doth; yet is hee cleane falne from them like a childe. Therefore have I made choice of him, among≈øt many ≈øuch conditions that I know, as mo≈øt exemplare. It were a matter be≈øeeming a ≈øchola≈øticall que≈øtion, whether it be better ≈øo, or otherwi≈øe. In his pre≈øence all things give place vnto him. This vaine cour≈øe is ever left vnto his authority, that he is never gaine-≈øaid. He is had in awe, he is feared, he is beleeved, he is re≈øpected his belly-full. Doth he di≈øcharge any boy or ≈øervant? he pre≈øently tru≈ø≈øeth vp his packe, then is he gone; but whether? onely out of his ≈øight, not out of his hou≈øe. The ≈øteps of age are follow, the ≈øen≈øes ≈øo troubled, the minde ≈øo di≈øtracted, that he ≈øhall live and doe his office, a whole yeere in one ≈øame hou≈øe, and never be perceived. And when fit time or occa≈øion ≈øerveth, Letters are produced from farre places, humbly ≈øuing, and pittifully complayning, with promi≈øes to doe better, and to amend, by which he is brought into favour and office againe. Doth the ma≈øter make any bargaine, or di≈øpatch that plea≈øeth not? it is immediately ≈ømothered and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, ≈øoone after forging cau≈øes, and devi≈øing colourable excu≈øes, to excu≈øe the want of execution or an≈øwer. No forraine Letters being fir≈øt pre≈øented vnto him, he ≈øeeth but ≈øuch as are fit for his knowledge. If peradventure they come vnto his hands, as he that tru≈øteth ≈øome one of his men to reade them vnto him, he will pre≈øently devi≈øe what he thinketh good, whereby they often invent, that ≈øuch a one ≈øeemeth to aske him forgivene≈ø≈øe, that wrongeth him by his Letter. To conclude, he never lookes into his owne bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, but by a di≈øpo≈øed, de≈øigned and as much as may be plea≈øing image, ≈øo contrived by ≈øuch as are about him, becau≈øe they will not ≈øtirre vp his choler, moove his impatience, and exa≈øperate his frowardne≈ø≈øe. I have ≈øeene vnder different formes, many long and con≈øtant, and of like effect oeconomies. It is ever proper vnto women, to be read ‚Ä¢ ly bent to contradict and cro≈ø≈øe their husbands. They will with might and maine hand-over head, take hold of any colour to thwart and with≈øtand them: the fir≈øt excu≈øe they meete with, ≈øerves them as a plenary ju≈øtification. I have ≈øeene ≈øome, that would in gro≈ø≈øe ≈øteale from their husbands, to the end (as they tolde their Confe≈ø≈øors) they might give the greater almes. Tru≈øt you to ≈øuch religious di≈øpen≈øations. They thinke no liberty to have, or managing to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe ≈øufficient authority, if it come from their husbands con≈øent: They mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily v≈øurpe it, either by wily craft or maine force, and ever injuriou≈øly, thereby to give it more grace and authority. As in my Di≈øcour≈øe, when it is again≈øt a poore old man, and for children, then take they hold of this Title, and therewith gloriou≈øly ≈øerve their turne and pa≈ø≈øion, and as in a common ≈øervitude, ea≈øily v≈øurpe and monopolize again≈øt his government and domination. If they be men-children, tall, of good ≈øpirit and forward, then they pre≈øently ≈øuborne, either by threats, force or favour, both Steward, Bail ‚Ä¢ ffe, Clarke, Receiver, and all the Fathers Officers, and Servants. We teach Blacke-birds, Starlines, Ravens, Plots, and Pasots to chat; and that facilitie we perceive in them, to lend vs their voyce ≈øo ≈øupple, and th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wind ≈øo tractable, that ≈øo wee may frame and bring-it to a certaine number of letters and ≈øilables, witne≈ø≈øeth, they have a kind of inward rea≈øon, which makes them ≈øo docile, and willing to learne. I thinke every man is cloid and wearied ‚Ä¢ , with ≈øeeing ≈øo many api≈øh and mimmike trickes, that juglers teach their Dogges, as the dances, where they mi≈ø≈øe not one eadence of the ≈øounds or notes they heare: Marke but the divers turnings, and ≈øeverall kinds of motions, which by the commandement of their bare wordes they make them performe: But I wonder not a little at the effect, which is ordinary among≈øt vs; and that is, the dogs which blinde men v≈øe, both in Cittie and Country: I have ob≈øerved how ≈øodainly they will ≈øtoppe when they come before ≈øome dores, where they are wont to receive almes; how carefully they will avoyde the ≈øhocke of Cartes and Coaches, even when they have roume enough to pa≈ø≈øe by them ≈øelves. This Dogge ≈øerved a jugler, who was to play a fiction of many faces, and ≈øundry countenances, there he al≈øo was to act a part. Among≈øt other things, he was for a long while to counterfet and faine him≈øelfe dead, becau≈øe he had eaten of a certaine drugge: having ≈øwallowed a peece of bread, which was ≈øuppo≈øed to be the drug, he began ≈øodainly to ≈øtagger and ≈øhake, as if he had beene giddie, then ≈øtretching and laying him≈øelfe along, as ≈øtiffe as if hee were ≈øtarke-dead, ≈øuffered him≈øelfe to be dragged and haled from one place to another, according to the ≈øubject and plot of the play, and when he knew his time, fir≈øt he began faire and ≈øoftly to ≈øtirre, as if he were rouzed out of a dead ≈ølumber, then lifting vp his head, hee looked and ≈øtared ≈øo ga≈øtly, that all the by-≈øtanders were amazed. The Oxen, which in the Kings gardens of Su≈øa were taught to water them, and to draw water out of deepe Welles, turned certaine great wheeles, to which were fa≈øtned great buckets (as in many places of Languedoke is commonly ≈øeene) and being every one appoynted to draw ju≈øt a hundred turnes a day, they
were ≈øo accu≈øtomed to that number, as it was impo≈ø≈øible by any compul≈øion to make them draw one more, which taske ended they would ≈øuddenly ≈øtop. And omitting what Democritus judged and prooved, which is, that bea≈øtes have in≈øtructed vs in mo≈øt of our Artes: As the Spider to weave and ≈øew, the Swollow to build, the Swan, and the Nightingale mu≈øicke, and divers bea≈øtes, by imitating them, the Arte of Phy≈øicke: Aristotle is of opinion, that Nightingales teach their yoong-ons to ≈øing, wherein they employ both long time and much care: whence it followeth, that tho≈øe which we keepe tame in Cages and have not had lea≈øure to goe to their Parents ≈øchoole, lo≈øe much grace in their ≈øinging. And ≈øo jealous are they in their prenti≈øe-≈øhip, that to excell one another, they will ≈øo ≈øtoutly contend for the ma≈øtery, that many times, ≈øuch as are vanqui≈øhed die; their wind and ≈øtrength ≈øooner failing then their voice. Arrius prote≈øteth to have ≈øeene an Elephant, who on every thigh having a Cimball hanging, and one fa≈øtned to his truncke, at the found of which, all other Elephants danced in a round, now ri≈øing aloft, then lowting full low at certaine cadences, even as the in≈øtrument directed them, and was much delighted with the harmony. But the tale of the Piot is very ≈øtrange, which Plutarke confidently witne≈ø≈øeth to have ≈øeene: This Iay was in a Barbers ≈øhop of Rome, and was admirable in counterfaiting with hir voice what≈øoever ≈øhe heard: It fortuned one day, that certaine Trumpeters ≈øtaied before this ≈øhop, and there ≈øounded a good while; and being gone, all that day, and the next after, the Piot began to be very ≈øad, ≈øilent, and melancholy, whereat all men marvelled, and ≈øurmized that the noi≈øe or clang of the Trumpets had thus affrighted and dizzied hir, and that with hir hearing ≈øhe had al≈øo lo≈øt hir voice. I will not omit to alleadge another example of a Dogge, which Plutarke al≈øo ≈øaith to have ≈øeene (as for any order or methode, I know very well I doe but confound it, which I ob≈øerve no more in ranging the≈øe examples, than I doe in all the re≈øt of my bu≈øine≈ø≈øe) who being in a ≈øhip, noted that this Dogge was in great perplexity how to get ≈øome Oyle out of a deepe Pitcher, which by rea≈øon of it's narrow mouth, he could not reach with his tongue, got him pre≈øently ≈øome Pibble-≈øtones, and put ≈øo many into the Iarre, that he made the Oyle come vp ≈øo neare the brimme, as he could ea≈øily reach and licke ≈øome. And what is that but the effect of a very ≈øubtill ≈øpirit? It is reported, that the Ravens of Barbary will doe the like, when the water they would drinke is too low. This action doth ≈øomewhat re≈øemble that, which Iuba a King of that Nation relateth of their Elephants; that when through the wiles of tho≈øe who cha≈øe them, any one chanceth to fall into certaine deepe pittes, which they prepare for them, and to deceive them, they cover over with reedes, ≈øhrubs, and boughes, his fellowes will ≈øpeedily with all diligence bring great ≈øtore of ≈øtones and peeces of timber, that ≈øo they may helpe to recover him out againe. The ≈øoules of Emperours and Coblers are all ca≈øt in one ≈øame mould. Con≈øidering the importance of Princes actions, and their weight, wee per≈øwade our ≈øelves, they are brought forth by ≈øome as weighty and important cau≈øes; wee are deceived: They are mooved, ≈øtirred and remooved in their motions, by the ≈øame ≈øprings and wardes, that wee are in ours. The ≈øame rea≈øon that makes vs chide and braule, and fall out with anie of our neighboures, cau≈øeth a warre to follow betweene Princes; The ≈øame rea≈øon that makes vs whip or beate a lackey, maketh a Prince (if hee apprehend it) to ≈øpoyle and wa≈øte a whole Province. Thouching tru≈øt and faithfulne≈ø≈øe there is no creature in the worlde ≈øo treacherous as man. Our hi≈øtories report the earne≈øt pur≈øuite and ≈øharpe cha≈øe, that ≈øome Dogges have made for the death of their ma≈øters. King Pirrhus finding a Dog, that watched a dead man, and vnder≈øtanding he had done ≈øo three daies and nights together, commanded the corps to be enterred, and tooke the Dog along with him. It fortuned one day (as Pirrhus was ≈øurvaying the Generall Mu≈øters of his Army) the Dog perceiving in that multitude, the man who had murthered his mai≈øter, loud-barking, and with great rage ran furiou≈øly vpon him; by which ≈øignes he furthered and procured his mai≈øters revenge, which by way of ju≈øtice, was ≈øhortly executed. Another Dogge being appointed to watch a Temple in Athens, having perceived a ≈øacrelegious theefe, to carrie away the faire≈øt jewels therein, barked at him ≈øo long as he was able, and ≈øeeing he could not awaken the Sextons or Temple-keepers, followed the theefe, whither-≈øoever he went; daie-light being come, he kept him≈øelfe a loof-off, but never lo≈øt the ≈øight of him: if he offered him meat, he vtterly refu≈øed it; but if any pa≈ø≈øenger chanced to come by, on them he fawned, with waging his taile, and tooke whatever they offered him; If the theefe ≈øtaied to re≈øt him≈øelfe, he al≈øo ≈øtayed in the ≈øame place: The newes of this Dogge being come to the Temple-keepers, they as they went along, enquiring of the Dogs haire and colour, pur≈øued his tracke ≈øo long, that at la≈øt they found both the Dog and the theefe in the Citie of Cromyon, whom they brought backe to Athens, where for his offence he was ≈øeverely puni≈øhed. And the judges in acknowledgement of the Dogges good office, at the Cities charge appointed him for his ≈øu≈øtenance a certaine daily mea≈øure of Corne, and enjoyned the Prie≈øts of the Temple, carefully to looke vnto him. Touching gratitude and thankfulne≈ø≈øe, (for me thinks we have need to further this word greatly) this onely example ≈øhall ≈øuffice, of which Appion reporteth to have been a≈øpectator him≈øelfe. One day (≈øaith he) that the Senate of Rome, (to plea≈øe and recreate the common people) cau≈øed a great number of wilde bea≈øts to be baited, namely huge great Lions, it ≈øo fortuned, that there was one among≈øt the re≈øt, who by rea≈øon of his furious and ≈øtately carriage, of his vnmatched ≈øtrength, of his great limmes, and of his loude, and terror-cau≈øing roaring, drew all by-≈øtanders eyes to gaze vpon him. Among≈øt other ≈ølaves, that in ≈øight of all the people were pre≈øented to encounter with the≈øe bea≈øts, there chanced to be one Androdus of Dacia, who belonged vnto a Roman Lord, who had been Con≈øull. This huge Lion, having eyed him a far off, fir≈øt made a ≈øuddaine ≈øtop, as ≈øtrucken into a kind of admiration, then with a milde and gentle countenance, as if he would willingly have taken acquaintance of him, faire and ≈øoftly approached vnto him: Which done, and re≈øting, a≈ø≈øured he was the man he tooke him for, begun fawningly to wagge his taile, as dogges doe that fawne vpon their new-≈øound ma≈øters, and licke the poore and mi≈øerable ≈ølaves hands and thighes, who through feare was almo≈øt out of his wits and halfe dead. Androdus at la≈øt taking hart of grace; and by rea≈øon of the Lions mildene≈ø≈øe having rouzed vp his ≈øpirits, and wi≈øhly fixing his eies vpon him, to ≈øee whether he could call him to remembrance; it was to all beholders a ≈øingular plea≈øure to ob≈øerve the love, the joy, and blandi≈øhments, ech endevored to enter-≈øhew one another. Whereat the people rai≈øing a loud crie, and by their ≈øhouting and clapping of hands ≈øeeming to be much plea≈øed; the Emperour willed the ≈ølave to be brought before him, as de≈øirous to vnder≈øtand of him the cau≈øe of ≈øo ≈øtrange and ≈øeld-≈øeene an accident: Who related this new, and wonderfull ≈øtorie vnto him.

My ma≈øter (≈øaid he) being Procon≈øull in Affrica, for≈øomuch as he cau≈øed me every day to be mo≈øt cruelly beaten, and held me in ≈øo rigorous bondage, I was con≈øtrained, as being wearie of my life, to run away: And ≈øafely to ≈øcape from ≈øo eminent a per≈øon, and who had ≈øo great authoritie in the Countrie, I thought it be≈øt to get me into the de≈øert, and mo≈øt vnfrequented wilderne≈ø≈øes of that region, with a full re≈øolution, if I could not compa≈ø≈øe the meanes to ≈øu≈øtaine my ≈øelfe, to finde one way or other, with violence to make my ≈øelfe away. One day, the Sunne about noone-tide being extreamly hote, and the ≈øcorching heat thereof intollerable, I fortuned to come vnto a wilde vnhanted cave, hidden among≈øt crags, and almo≈øt inacce≈ø≈øible, and where I imagined no footing had ever been; therein I hid my ≈øelfe: I had not long been there, but in comes this Lion, with one of his pawes ≈øore hurt, and bloody-goared, wailing for the ≈ømart, and groaning for the paine he felt; at who≈øe arrivall, I was much di≈ømaide, but he ≈øeeing me lie clo≈øe-cowring in a corner of his den, gently made his approaches vnto me, holding forth his goared paw toward me, and ≈øeemed with ≈øhewing the ≈øame humbly to ≈øue, and ≈øuppliantly to beg for help at my hands. I, moved with ruth, taking it into my hand, pulled out a great ≈øplint, which was gotten into-it, and ≈øhakingoff all feare, fir≈øt I wrung and cru≈øht his ≈øore, and cau≈øed the filth and matter, which therein was gathered, to come forth; then, as gently as for my hart I could, I clean≈øed, wiped, and dried the ≈øame. He feeling ≈øome ea≈øe in his griefe, and his paine to cea≈øe, ≈øtill holding his foote betweene my hands, began to ≈øleep and take ≈øome re≈øt. Thence forward he and I lived

But at la≈øt wearied with this kinde of bruti≈øh life, the Lion being one day gone to purcha≈øe his wonted pray, I left the place, hoping to mend my fortunes, and having wandred vp and downe three dayes, I was at la≈øt taken by certaine Souldiers, which from Africa brought me into this Citie to my Ma≈øter againe, who immediately condemned me to death, and to be devoured by wilde bea≈øts. And as I now perceive, the ≈øame Lion was al≈øo ≈øhortly after taken, who as you ≈øee hath now required me of the good turne I did him, and the health which by my meanes he recoved. Behold heer the hi≈øtorie, Androdus reported vnto the Emperour, which after he cau≈øed to be declared vnto all the people, at who≈øe generall reque≈øt, he was forthwith ≈øet at libertie, and quit of his puni≈øhment, and by the common con≈øent of all, had the Lion be≈øtowed vpon him. Appion ≈øaith further, that Androdus was daily ≈øeen to leade the Lion vp and downe the ≈øtreets of Rome, tied onely with a little twine, and walking from taverne to taverne, received ≈øuch money as was given him, who would gently ≈øuffer him≈øelfe to be handled, touched, decked, and ≈øtrowed with flowers, all over and over, many ≈øaying when they met him: yonder is the Lion that is the mans ho≈øte, and yonder is the man that is the Lions Phi≈øitian.
