div.p:
As ≈øome of our nations have wives in common, and ≈øome in ≈øeverall, each man keeping him≈øelfe to his owne; ≈øo have ≈øome bea≈øts; yet ≈øome there are, that ob≈øerve their marriages, with as great re≈øpect as we doe ours. Touching the mutuall ≈øocietie, and reciprocall confederation, which they devi≈øe among≈øt them≈øelves, that ≈øo they may be fa≈øt combined together, and in times of need help one another, it is apparant, that if Oxen, Hogs, and other bea≈øts being hurt by vs, chance to crie, all the heard runnes to aide him, and in his defen≈øe will joine all together. The fi≈øh, called of the Latines Scarus, having ≈øwallowed the fi≈øhers hooke, his fellowes will pre≈øently flocke about him, and nibble the line in ≈øunder; and if any of them happen to be taken in a bow-net, ≈øome of his fellowes turning his head away, will put his taile in at the necke of the net, who with his teeth fa≈øt-holding the ≈øame, never leave him, vntill they have pulled him out. The Barble fi≈øhes, if one of them chance to be engaged, will ≈øet the line again≈øt their backes, and with a fin they have, toothed like a ≈øharp ≈øaw, pre≈øently ≈øaw and fret the ≈øame a≈øunder. Concerning particular offices, which we for the benefit of our life, draw one from an other, many like examples are found among≈øt them. It is a≈ø≈øuredly beleeved, that the Whale never ≈øwimmeth, vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øhe have a little fi≈øh going before her, as her vantgard, it is in ≈øhape like a Gudgeon, and both the Latines and we, call it the Whales-guide; for, ≈øhe doth ever follow him, ≈øuffering her ≈øelfe, as ea≈øily to be led and turned by him, as a ≈øhip is directed and turned by a ≈øterne: for requitall of which good turne, whereas all things el≈øe, be it, bea≈øt, fi≈øh, or ve≈ø≈øell, that comes within the horrible Chaes of this mon≈øtrous mouth, is pre≈øently lo≈øt and devoured, this little fi≈øh, doth ≈øafely retire him≈øelfe therein, and there ≈øleepes verie quietly, and as long as he ≈øleepes, the Whale never ≈øtirs; but a≈ø≈øoone as he awaketh and goeth his way, whereever he takes his cour≈øe ≈øhe alwaies followeth him, and if ≈øhe fortune to loo≈øe him, ≈øhe wanders here and there, and often ≈øtriketh vpon the rocks, as a ≈øhip that hath nor ma≈øt nor rudder. This, Plutarke witne≈ø≈øeth to have ≈øeen in the Iland of Anticyra. There is ≈øuch a like ≈øocietie betweene the little bird called a Wren, and the Crocodill: For, the Wren ≈øerveth as a ≈øentinell to ≈øo great a mon≈øter: And if the Ichneumon, which is his mortall enemie approach to fight with him, the little bird let, le≈øt he might ≈øurpri≈øe him whil≈øt he ≈øleepeth, with his ≈øinging, and pecking him with his bill, awakens him, and gives him warning of the danger he is in. The bird liveth by the ≈øcraps, and feedeth vpon the leavings of that mon≈øter, who gently receiveth him into his mouth, and ≈øuffers him to pecke his jawes and teeth for ≈øuch mammockes of fle≈øh as ≈øticke betweene them: and if he purpo≈øe to clo≈øe his mouth, he doth fir≈øt warne him to be gone, faire and ea≈øie clo≈øing it by little and little, without any whit cru≈øhing or hurting him. The
≈øhell-fi≈øh called a Nacre, liveth even ≈øo with the Pinnotere, which is a little creature like vnto a Crabfi≈øh, and as his porter or v≈øher waites vpon him, attending the opening of the Nacre, which he continually keepes gaping, vntill he ≈øee ≈øome little fi≈øh enter in, fit for their turne, then he creepes into the Nacre, and leaves not pinching his quicke fle≈øh, vntill he makes him clo≈øe his ≈øhell, and ≈øo they both together fa≈øt in their hold, devour their prey. In the maner of the Tunnies life, may be di≈øcovered a ≈øingular knowledge of the three parts of the Mathematikes. Fir≈øt for A≈øtrologie, it may well be ≈øaid that man doth learne it of them: For, where≈øoever the winter Sol≈øtitium doth take them, there do they ≈øtay them≈øelves, and never ≈øtir till the next Aequinoctium, and that is the rea≈øon why Aristotle doth ≈øo willingly a≈øcribe that arte vnto them: Then for Geometrie and Arithmetike, they alwaies frame their ≈øhole of a Cubike figure, every way ≈øquare: and ≈øo forme a ≈øolide, clo≈øe and wel-ranged battailon, encompa≈ø≈øed round about of ≈øixe equall ≈øides. Thus orderly mar≈øhaled, they take their cour≈øe and ≈øwim whither their journey tends, as broad and wide behind as before: So that he that ≈øeeth and telleth but one ranke, may ea≈øily number all the troope, for≈øomuch as the number of the depth is equall vnto the bredth, and the bredth vnto the length. Touching magnanimitie and haughtie courage, it is hard to ≈øet it forth more lively, and to produce a rarer patterne, then that of the Dog, which from India was ≈øent vnto Alexander: to whom was fir≈øt pre≈øented a Stag, then a wilde Boare, and then a Beare, with each of which he ≈øhould have foughten, but he ≈øeemed to make no accompt of them, and would not ≈øo much as remoove out of his place for them, but when he ≈øaw a Lion, he pre≈øently rouzed him≈øelfe, ≈øhewing evidently he meant onely ≈øo noble a bea≈øt worthie to enter combate with him. Concerning repentance and acknowledging of faults committed, it is reported, that an Elephant having through rage of choller ≈ølaine his governour, conceived ≈øuch an extreame inward griefe, that he would never afterward touch any food, and ≈øuffered him≈øelf to pine to death. Touching clemencie, it is reported of a Tiger, (the fierce≈øt and mo≈øt inhumane bea≈øt of all) who having a Kid given her to feed vpon, endured the force of gnawing hunger, two daies together, rather then ≈øhe would hurt him; the third day with maine ≈øtrength ≈øhe brake the cage, wherein ≈øhe was kept-pent, and went el≈øewhere to ≈øhift for feeding; as one vnwilling to ≈øeize vpon the ≈øeelie Kid her familiar and gue≈øt. And concerning priviledges of familiaritie and ≈øympathie cau≈øed by conver≈øation, is it not oft ≈øeen, how ≈øome make Cats, Dogs, and Hares ≈øo tame, ≈øo gentle, and ≈øo milde, that without harming one another they ≈øhall live and continue together? But that which experience teacheth ≈øea-faring men, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that come into the ≈øeas of S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ilie, of the qualitie and condition of the Halcyon bird, or as ≈øome call it Alcedo or kings-fi≈øher, exceeds all mens conceit. In what kinde of creature did ever nature ≈øo much prefer both their hatching, ≈øitting, brooding, and birth? Poets faine, that the Iland of Delos, being before wandring and fleeting vp and downe, was for the delivery of Latona made firme and ≈øetled. But Gods decree hath been, that all the watrie wilderne≈ø≈øe ≈øhould be quiet and made calme, without raine, wind, or tempe≈øt, during the time the Halcyon ≈øitteth and bringeth forth her yoong-ones, which is much about the Winter Solstitium, and ≈øhorte≈øt day in the yeare: By who≈øe priviledge even in the hart & deade≈øt time of Winter we have ≈øeven calme daies, and as many nights to ≈øaile without any danger. Their Hens know no other Cocke but their owne: They never for≈øake him all the daies of their life; and if the Cocke chance to be weake and crazed, the Hen will take him vpon her neck, and carrie him with her, where≈øoever ≈øhe goeth, and ≈øerve him even vntill death. Mans wit could neuer yet attaine to the full knowledge of that admirable kind of building or ≈øtructure, which the Halcion v≈øeth in contriving of her nea≈øt, no, nor devi≈øe what it is-of.

Plutarke, who hath ≈øeen and handled many of them, thinkes it to be made of certaine fi≈øh-bones, which ≈øhe ≈øo compacts, and conjoyneth together, enterla≈øing ≈øome long, and ≈øome cro≈ø≈øe-waies, adding ≈øome foldings and roundings to it, that in the end ≈øhe frameth a round kind of ve≈ø≈øell, readie to floate and ≈øwim vpon the water: which done, ≈øhe carrieth the ≈øame where the Sea-waves beate mo≈øt; there the Sea gently beating vpon it, ≈ønewes her how to daube and patch vp the parts not well clo≈øed, and how to ≈øtrengthen tho≈øe places, and fa≈øhion tho≈øe ribs, that are not fa≈øt, but ≈øtir with the Sea-waves: And on the other ≈øide, that which is clo≈øely wrought, the Sea beating on it, doth ≈øo fa≈øten and conjoyne together, that nothing, no, not ≈øtone or yron, can any way loo≈øen, divide, or break the ≈øame, except with great violence; and what is mo≈øt to be wondred at, is the proportion and figure of the concavitie
within; for, it is ≈øo compo≈øed and proportioned, that it can receive or admit no manner of thing, but the Bird that built-it; for, to all things el≈øe, it is ≈øo impenetrable, clo≈øe and hard, that nothing can po≈ø≈øiblie enter in: no, not ≈øo much as the Sea-water. Loe-heer a mo≈øt plaine de≈øcription of this building, or con≈øtruction taken from a verie good Author: yet me thinks, it doth not fully and ≈øufficiently re≈øolve vs of the difficultie in this kinde of Architecture. Now from what vanitie can it proceed, we ≈øhould ≈øo willfully contemne, and di≈ødaeinfully interpret tho≈øe effects, which we can neither imitate nor conceive? div.p:
THe familiarity I have with the≈øe two men, and the ayde they affoord me in my olde age, and my Booke meerely framed of their ≈øpoiles, bindeth me to wed and maintaine their honour. As for Seneca, amonge≈øt a thou≈øand petty-Pamphlets, tho≈øe of the pretended reformed religion have publi≈øhed for the defence of their cau≈øe, which now and then proceede from a good hand, and which, pitty it is, it ≈øhould not be employed in more ≈øerious and better ≈øubjects: I have heeretofore ≈øeene one, who to prolong and fill vp the ≈øimilitude, he would finde betweene the governement of our vnfortunate late king Charles the ninth and that of Nero, compareth the whilom lord Cardinall of Loren ‚Ä¢
vnto Seneca; their fortunes to have beene both chiefe men in the governement of their Princes, and therewithall their manners, their conditions and their demeanours: wherein (in mine opinion) hee doth the ≈øaide lorde Cardinall great honour: for, although I bee one of tho≈øe that highly re≈øpect his ≈øpirite, his woorth, his eloquence, his zeale toward his religion and the ≈øervice of his King; and his good fortune to have beene borne in an age, wherein hee was ≈øo new, ≈øo rare, and there withall ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie for the common-wealth, to have a Cleargie-man of ≈øuch dignitie and nobilitie, ≈øufficient and capable of ≈øo weightie a charge: yet to confe≈ø≈øe the truth, I e≈øteeme not his capacitie ≈øuch, nor his vertue ≈øo exqui≈øitely vn≈øpotted, nor ≈øo entire or con≈øtant, as that of Seneca. Now this Booke whereof I ≈øpeake, to come to his intention, maketh a mo≈øt injurious de≈øcription of Seneca, having borrowed his reproaches from Dion the Hi≈øtorian, to who≈øe te≈øtimony I give no credite at all: For be≈øides, he is incon≈øtant, as one who after hee hath called Seneca exceeding wi≈øe, and ≈øhortly after termed him a mortall enemy to Neroes vices, in other places makes him covetous, given to v≈øurie, ambitious ba≈øe-minded, voluptuous and vnder fal≈øe pretences, and fained ≈øhewes, a counterfet Philo≈øopher; his vertue appeareth ≈øo lively, and wi≈øedome ≈øo vigorous in his writings; and the defence of the≈øe imputations is ≈øo manife≈øt, as well of his riches, as of his exce≈ø≈øive expences, that I beleeve no witne≈ø≈øe to the contrarie. Moreover, there is great rea≈øon wee ≈øhould rather give credite to Romane Hi≈øtorians in ≈øuch things, then to Graecians and ≈øtrangers, whereas Tacitus and others ≈øpeake very honourably of his life and death, and in all other circum≈øtance declare him to have beene a mo≈øt excellent and rarely-vertuous man. Iove, though of Marble, feeles the letches force,
From his old Church to day made to remoove,
Though God and Stone, hee's carried like a coar≈øe.

Androg ‚Ä¢ ras in helth bath'd over night with vs,
And merry ≈øupt, but in the morne ≈øtarke dead was found.
Of his ≈øo ≈øudden death, the cau≈øe ≈øhall I di≈øcu≈ø≈øe.
Hermocrates the Leech he ≈øaw in ≈øleepe vn≈øound.

div.p:
Vpon which I will tell you two pretty ≈øtories. The Baron of Caupene in Chalo≈ø≈øe and I, have both in common the right of the patronage of a benifice, which is of a very large precinct, ≈øituated at the feet of our Mountaines, named Lohontan. It is with the inhabitants of
that corner, as it is ≈øaid to be with tho≈øe of the valley of Angrougne. They lead a kind of peculiar life; their attire, and their cu≈øtomes apart and ≈øeverall. They were directed and governed by certaine particular policies and cu≈øtomes, received by tradition from Father to Child: Whereto, without other Lawes or Compul≈øion, except the reverence and awe of their cu≈øtome and v≈øe, they awefully tied and bound them≈øelves. This petty ≈øtate had from all antiquity continued in ≈øo happy a condition, that no neighbouring ≈øevere judge had ever beene troubled to enquire of their life and affaires, nor was ever Atturny or Pety fogging Lawyer called for, to give them advi≈øe or coun≈øell; no ‚Ä¢ ≈øtranger ≈øought vnto to determine their quarrels or decide their contentions; neither were ever beggers ≈øeene among≈øt them. They alwaies avoided commerce and ≈øhunned alliances with the other World, lea≈øt they ≈øhould alter the purity of their orders and policy; vntill ≈øuch time (as they ≈øay) that one amonge≈øt them, in their fathers daies, having a minde pufft vp with a noble ambition, to bring his name and credit in reputation, devi≈øed to make one of his Children Sir Iohn Lackelatine, or Ma≈øter Peter-an-Oake: And having made him learne to write in ≈øome neighbour Towne not farre off, at la≈øt procured him to be a Country Notary, or Petty-fogging Clarke. This fellow having gotten ≈øome pelfe and become great, began to di≈ødaine their ancient cu≈øtomes, and put the pompe and ≈øtateline≈ø≈øe of our higher regions into their heads. It fortuned that a chiefe Go≈ø≈øip of his had a Goate di≈øhorned, whom he importunately ≈øolicited to ≈øue the Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øer, and demand law and right at the Iudge or Iu≈øticers hands, that dwelt there-abouts; And ≈øo never cea≈øing to ≈øow ≈øedition and breed ≈øutes amonge≈øt his neighbours, he never left till he had confounded and marred all. After this corruption or intru≈øion of law (they ≈øay) there en≈øued pre≈øently another mi≈øchiefe of wor≈øe con≈øequence, by meanes of a Quacke-≈øalver, or Empirike Phy≈øition that dwelt amonge≈øt them, who would needes be married to one of their daughters, and ≈øo endenizon and ≈øettle him≈øelfe among≈øt them.

This gallant began fir≈øt to teach and in≈øtruct them in the names of agewes, rheumes and impo≈øtumes; then the ≈øcituation of the heart, of the liver and other entrailes: A Science vntill then never knowen or heard of among them. And in ≈øtead of garlike, wherewith they had learned to expell, and were wont to cure all di≈øea≈øes, of what qualitie and how dangerous ≈øoever they were, he induced and inured them, were it but for a cough or cold, to take ≈øtrange compo≈øitions and potions: And thus beganne to trafficke not onely their health, but al≈øo their deaths. They ≈øweare, that even from that time, they haue apparantly perceived, that the evening Sereine or night-calme bred the head-ach and bla≈øted them; that to drinke being hot or in a ≈øweat empaired their helthes; that Autumne windes were more vnwhole≈øome and dangerous, then tho≈øe of the Springe-time: And that ≈øince his ≈ølibber≈øawces, potions and phy≈øicke came fir≈øt in v≈øe; they finde them≈øelues mole≈øted and di≈øtempered with Legions of vnaccu≈øtomed malladies and vnknowen di≈øea≈øes; and plainely feele and ≈øen≈øibly perceive a generall weakene≈ø≈øe and declination in their antient vigor; and that their lives are nothing ≈øo long, as before they were. Loe heere the fir≈øt of my tales. The other is, that before I was troubled with the ≈øtone-chollicke and gravell in the bladder, hearing diuers make e≈øpeciall account of a hee-goats blood, as of an heavenly Manna ≈øent in the≈øe latter-ages for the good and pre≈øervation of mans life: and hearing men of good vnder ≈øtanding ≈øpeake of it, as of an admirable and much-good-working drugge, and of an infallible operation: I, who have ever thought my ≈øelfe ≈øubject to all accidents, that may in any ≈øort fall on man, being yet in perfect health, beganne to take plea≈øure to provide my ≈øelfe of this myracle, and foorthwith gave order (according to the receipt) to have a Bucke-goate gotten, and carefully fed in mine owne hou≈øe. For the blood mu≈øt be drawne from him in the hotte≈øt moneth of Summer, and he mu≈øt onely be fed with ≈øoluble hearbes, and drincke nothing but White-wine. It was my fortune to come to mine owne hou≈øe the very ≈øame day the Goate ≈øhould be killed; where ≈øome of my people came in ha≈øte to tell mee, that my Cooke found two or three great bowles in his paunch, which in his maw among≈øt his meat ≈øhocked one again≈øt another. I was ≈øo curious as I would needes have all his garbage brought before me; the thicke and large skinne whereof I cau≈øed to be opened, out of which came three great lumpes or bodies, as light as any ≈øpunge, ≈øo framed as they ≈øeemed to be hollow, yet outwardly hard and very firme, bemotled with divers dead and wanni≈ø ‚Ä¢ colours: The one perfectly as round as any bowle, the other two ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øer, and not
≈øo round, yet ≈øeemed to grow towards it. I have found (after I had made diligent inquiry among ≈øuch as were wont to open ≈øuch bea≈øts) that it was a ≈øeld-≈øeene and vnheard of accident. It is very likely they were ≈øuch ≈øtones as ours be, and cozen-germanes to them; which if it be, it is but vaine for ≈øuch as be troubled with the ≈øtone or gravell to hope to be cured, by meanes of a bea≈øts-blood, that was drawing neere vnto death, and ≈øuffered the ≈øame di≈øea≈øe. For, to aleadge the blood cannot participate of that contagion', and doth no whit thereby alter his accu≈øtomed vertue, it may rather be inferred, that nothing ingendreth in a body, but by con≈øent and communication of all the parts. The whole ma≈ø≈øe doth worke, and the whole frame agitate altogether, although one part, according to the diver≈øitie of operations, doth contribute more or le≈ø≈øe than another; whereby it manife≈øtly appeareth, that in all parts of this bucke-goate, there was ≈øome grettie or petrificant qualitie. It was not ≈øo much for feare of any future chaunce, or in regard of my ≈øelfe, that I was ≈øo curious of this experiment; as in re≈øpect, that as well in mine owne hou≈øe, as el≈øe-where in ≈øundry other places, it commeth to pa≈ø≈øe, that many women doe often gather and lay vp in ≈øtore, divers ≈øuch kindes of ≈ølight drugges to help their neighbours, and other people with them, in time of nece≈ø≈øitie; applying one ≈øame remedy to an hundred ≈øeverall di≈øea≈øes: yea many times ≈øuch as they would be very loath to take them≈øelves; with which they often have good lucke, and well thrives it with them. As for mee I honour Phy≈øitions, not according to the common-received rule, for nece≈ø≈øitie ≈øake (for to this pa≈ø≈øage another of the Prophet may be alleaged, who reprooved King A≈øa, becau≈øe hee had recour≈øe vnto Phy≈øitions) but rather for love I beare vnto them≈øelves; having ≈øeene ≈øome, and knowne diver≈øe hone≈øt men among≈øt them, and worthy all love and e≈øteeme. It is not them I blame, but their Arte; yet doe I not greatly condemne them for ≈øeeking to profit by our fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe (for mo≈øt men doe ≈øo) and it is a thing common to all worldlings. Diver≈øe profe≈ø≈øious and many vacations, both more and le≈ø≈øe worthie than theirs, ≈øub≈øist and are grounded onely vpon publike abu≈øes and popular errours. I ≈øend for them when I am ≈øicke, if they may conveniently be found; and love to be entertained by them, rewarding them as other men doe. I give them authoritie to enjoyne me to keepe my ≈øelfe warme, if I love it better ≈øo than otherwi≈øe. They may chu≈øe, be it either leekes or lettuce, what my broth ≈øhall be made withall, and appoynt mee either white or clarer to drinke; and ≈øo of other things el≈øe, indifferent to my ta≈øte, humor or cu≈øtome. I know well it is nothing to them, for≈øomuch as Sharpene≈ø≈øe and Strangene≈ø≈øe are accidents of Phy≈øickes proper e≈ø≈øence. Lycurgus allowed and appoynted the ≈øicke men of Sparta to drinke wine. Why did he ≈øo? Becau≈øe being in health, they hated the v≈øe of it. Even as a Gentleman who dwelleth not farre from mee, v≈øeth wine as a ≈øoveraigne remedie againg agews, becau≈øe being in perfect health, he hateth the ta≈øte thereof as death. How many of them ≈øee wee to be of my humour? That is, to di≈ødaine all Phy≈øicke for their owne behoofe, and live a kinde of formall free life, and altogether contrarie to that, which they pre≈øcribe to others? And what is that, but a manife≈øt abu≈øing of our ≈øimplicitie? For, they holde their life as deare, and e≈øteeme their health as pretious as wee doe ours, and would apply their effects to their skill, if them≈øelves knew not the vncertaintie and fal≈øehood of it. It is the feare of paine and death; the impatience of the di≈øea≈øe and griefe; and indi≈øcreete de≈øire and headlong thir≈øt of health, that ≈øo blindeth them, and vs. It is meere faintnes that makes our conceit; and pu≈øillanimitie forceth our credulitie, to bee ≈øo yeelding and pliable. The greater parte of whome doe notwith≈øtanding not beleeve ≈øo much, as they endure and ≈øuffer of others: For I heare them complaine, and ≈øpeake of it no otherwi≈øe than wee doe. Yet in the ende are they re≈øolved. What ≈øhould I doe then? As if impatience were in it≈øelfe a better remedie than patience Is there any of them, that hath yeelded to this mi≈øerable ≈øubjection, that doth not likewi≈øe yeelde to all manner of impo≈øtures? or dooth not ≈øubject him≈øelfe to the mercie of whom≈øoever hath the impudencie to promi≈øe him recoverie, and warrant him health?

The Babilonians were wont to carry their ≈øicke people into the open ≈øtreetes; the common ≈øort were their phy≈øitions: where all ≈øuch as pa≈ø≈øed by were by humanitie and civilitie to enquire of their ≈øtate and maladie, and according to their skill or experience, give them ≈øome ‚Ä¢ ound adui≈øe and good coun≈øell. We differ not greatly from them: There is no poore Woman ≈øo ≈øimple, who≈øe mumbling and muttering, who≈øe ≈ølibber-≈ølabbers and drenches wee doe not employ. And as for mee, were I to buy any medicine, I would rather ≈øpend my money in this kinde of phy≈øicke, than in any other; becau≈øe therein is no danger or hurt
to be feared. What Homer and Plato ≈øaid of the Aegyptians, that they were all Phy≈øitions, may well be ≈øaid of all people. There is neither Man nor Woman, that vanteth not him≈øelfe to have ≈øome receipt or other, and doth not hazard the ≈øame vpon his neighbour, if he will but give credite vnto him.

I was not long ≈øince in a company, where I wot not who of my fraternity, brought newes of a kinde of pilles, by true accompt, compo≈øed of a hundered and odde ≈øeverall ingredients; Whereat we laughed very heartily, and made our ≈øelves good ≈øport: For, what rocke ≈øo hard were able to re≈øi≈øt the ≈øhocke, or with≈øtand the force of ≈øo thicke and numerous a battery? I vnder≈øtand neverthele≈ø≈øe, of ≈øuch as tooke of them, that the lea≈øt graine gravell dained not to ≈øtirre at all. I cannot ≈øo ≈øoone give over writing of this ≈øubject, but I mu≈øt needes ≈øay a word or two, concerning the experience they have made of their pre≈øcriptions, which they would have vs take as a warrantize or a≈ø≈øurance of the certainty of their drugges and potions. The greate≈øt number, and as I deeme, more than the two thirds of medicinable vertues, con≈øi≈øt in the quinte≈ø≈øence or ≈øecret propriety of ≈øimples, whereof we can have no other in≈øtruction but v≈øe and cu≈øtome. For, Quinte≈ø≈øence is no other thing than a quality, whereof we cannot with our rea≈øon finde out the cau≈øe. In ≈øuch trials or experiments, tho≈øe which they affirme to have acquired by the in≈øpiration of ≈øome Daemon, I am contented to receive and allow of them (for, touching myracles, I meddle not with them) or be it the experiments drawne from things, which for other re≈øpects fall often in v≈øe with vs: As if in Wooll, wherewith we wont to cloth our ≈øelves, ≈øome ≈øecret ex≈øiccating or drying quality, have by accident beene found, that cureth kibes or chilblaines in the heeles; and if in reddi≈øhes, we eat for nouri≈øhment, ≈øome opening or aperitive operation have beene di≈øcovered. Galen reporteth, that a Leprous man chanced to be cured, by meanes of a Cuppe of Wine he had drunke, for≈øomuch as a Viper was by fortune fallen into the Wine caske. In which example we finde the meane, and a very likely directory to this experience. As al≈øo in tho≈øe, to which Phy≈øitions affirme, to have beene addre≈ø≈øed by the examples of ≈øome bea≈øts. But in mo≈øt of other experiences, to which they ≈øay they came by fortune, and had no other guide but hazard, I finde the progre≈ø≈øe of this information incredible. I imagine man, heedfully viewing about him the infinite number of things, creatures, plants and mettals. I wot not where to make him beginne his E≈ø≈øay; And ≈øuppo≈øe he ca≈øt his fir≈øt fanta≈øie vpon an Elkes-Horne, to which an ea≈øie and gentle credulity mu≈øt be given; he will be as farre to ≈øeeke, and as much troubled in his ≈øecond operation: So, many di≈øea≈øes and ≈øeverall circum≈øtances are propo≈øed vnto him, that before he come to the certainty of this point, vnto which the perfection of his experience ≈øhould arrive, mans wit ≈øhall be to ≈øeeke, and not know where to turne him≈øelfe; And before (amidde≈øt this infinity of things) hee finde out what this Horne is: Among≈øt the numberle≈ø≈øe di≈øea≈øes that are, what an Epilep≈øie is; the ≈øundrie and manifolde complexions in a melancholy man; So many ≈øea≈øons in Winter: So diver≈øe Nations among≈øt French-men; So many ages in age; So diver≈øe coele≈øtiall changes and alterations, in the conjunction of Venus and Saturne; So ≈øeverall and many partes in a mans body, nay in one of his fingers. To all which being neyther guided by argument, nor by conjecture, nor by example, or divine in≈øpiration, but by the one ly motion of fortune; it were mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, it ≈øhould be by a perfectly artificiall, well-ordred, and methodicall fortune. Moreover, ≈øuppo≈øe the di≈øea≈øe thorowly cured, how ≈øhall he re≈øt a≈ø≈øured, but that eyther the evill was come to his vtmo≈øt period, or that an effect of the hazard, cau≈øed the ≈øame health? Or the operation of ≈øome other thing, which that day he had eyther eaten, drunke or touched? or whether it were by the merite of his Grand-mothers prayers? Be≈øides, ≈øuppo≈øe this experiment to have beene perfect, how many times was it applied and begun a new; And how often was this long and tedious web of fortunes and encounters woven over againe, before a certaine rule might be concluded? And being concluded, by whom is it I pray you? Among≈øt ≈øo many millions of men, you ≈øhall ≈øcar≈øe meete with three or foure, that well duely ob≈øerve, and carefully keepe a Regi≈øter of their experiments; ≈øhall it be your, or his happe, to light truely, or hit ju≈øt with one of them three or foure? What if another man? Nay what if a hundred other men have had and made contrary experiments, and cleane oppo≈øite conclu≈øions, and yet have ≈øorted well? We ≈øhould peradventure di≈øcerne ≈øome ≈øhew of light, if all the judgements and con≈øultations of men were knowne vnto vs. But That three Witne≈ø≈øes and three Doctors ≈øhall ≈øway all mankind, there
is no rea≈øon. It were requi≈øite, humane nature had appointed and made ≈øpeciall choi≈øe of them and that by expre≈ø≈øe procuration and letter of atturny they were by her declared our Iudges and deputed our Atturnies.

div.head: To my Lady of Duras.
div.p: MAdame, the la≈øt time it plea≈øed you to come and vi≈øite me, you found me vpon this point. And becau≈øe it may be, the≈øe toyes of mine may happily come to your hands: I would have them witne≈ø≈øe, their Authour reputeth him≈øelfe highly honoured, for the favours it ≈øhall plea≈øe you to ≈øhew them. Wherein you ≈øhall di≈øcerne the very ≈øame demeanor and ≈øelfe-countenance, you have ≈øeene in his conver≈øa≈øion. And could I have a≈ø≈øumed vnto my ≈øelfe any other fa≈øhion, than mine owne accu≈øtomed, or more honourable and better forme, I would not have done it: For, all I ≈øeeke to reape by my writings, is, they will naturally repre≈øent and to the life, pourtray me to your remembrance. The very ≈øame conditions and faculties, it plea≈øed your Lady-≈øhip to frequent and receive, with much more honor and curte≈øie, than they any way de≈øerve, I will place and reduce (but without alteration and change) into a ≈øolide body, which may happily continue ≈øome daies and yeares after mee: Where, when ≈øoever it ≈øhall plea≈øe you to refre≈øh your memory with them, you may ea≈øily finde them, without calling them to remembrance; which they ≈øcar≈øely de≈øerve. I would entreate you to continue the favour of your Friend-≈øhip towards mee, by the ≈øame qualities, through who≈øe meanes it was produced. I labour not to be beloved more and e≈øteemed better being dead, than alive. The humour of Tyberius is ridiculous and common, who endevoured more to extingui≈øh his glory in future ages, than yeeld him≈øelfe regardfull and plea≈øing to men of his times. If I were one of tho≈øe, to whom the World my be indebted for prai≈øe, I would quit it for the one moytie, on condition it would pay me before-hand: And that the ≈øame would ha≈øten, and in great heapes environ me about, more thicke than long, and more full than la≈øting. And let it hardly vani≈øh with my knowledge, and when this ≈øweet alluring ≈øound ≈øhall no more tickle mine eares. It were a fond conceite, now I am ready to leave the commerce of men, by new commendations, to goe about, anew to beget my ≈øelfe vnto them.

I make no account of goods, which I could not employ to the v≈øe of my life. Such as I am ≈øo would I be el≈øewhere then in Paper. Mine arte and indu≈øtry have beene emploied to make my ≈øelfe of ≈øome worth. My ≈øtudy and endevour to doe, and not to write. I have applied all my skill and devoire to frame my life. Lo-heere mine occupation and my worke. I am a le≈ø≈øe maker of books, then of any thing el≈øe. I have de≈øired and aimed at ≈øufficiencie, rather for the benefite of my pre≈øent and e≈ø≈øentiall commodities, then to make a Store-hou≈øe, and hoard it vp for mine heires. Who≈øoever hath any worth in him, let him ≈øhew it in his behaviour, maners and ordinary di≈øcour≈øes; be it to treat of love or of quarrels, of ≈øport and play or bed-matters, at board or el≈øe-where; or be it in the conduct of his owne affaires, or private hou≈øhold matters. Tho≈øe whom I ≈øee make good bookes, having tattered ho≈øen and ragged clothes on, had they believed mee they ≈øhould fir≈øt have gotten them≈øelves good clothes. Demand a Spartan, whether he would rather be a cunning Rhethorician, then an excellent Souldier: nay were I asked, I would ≈øay, a good Cooke, had I not ≈øome to ≈øerve me. Good Lord (Madame) how I would hate ≈øuch a commendation, to be a ≈øufficient man in writing, and a fooli≈øh-≈øhallow-headed braine or coxcombe in all things el≈øe: yet had I rather be a foole; both here and there, then to have made ≈øo bad a choi≈øe, wherein to imploy my worth. So farre am I al≈øo from expecting, by ≈øuch trifles to gaine new honour to my ≈øelfe: as I ≈øhal think I make a good bargaine, if I loo≈øe not a part of that little, I had already gained. For, be≈øides that this dombe and dead picture, ≈øhall derogate and ≈øteale from my naturall being, it fadgeth not and hath no reference vnto my better ≈øtate, but is much falne from my fir≈øt vigor and naturall jollity, enclining to a kinde of drooping or mouldine≈ø≈øe. I am now come to the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øell, which beginneth to ta≈øte of his dregs and lees. Otherwi≈øe (good Madame) I ≈øhould not have dared ≈øo boldly to have ripped vp the my≈øteries of Phi≈øicke,
≈øicke, con≈øidering the e≈øteeme and credite your ≈øelfe, and ≈øo many others, a≈øcribe vnto it, and hold it in; had I not been directed therunto by the authors of the ≈øame. I thinke they have but two ancient ones in Latine, to wit Pliny and Cel≈øus. If you fortune at any time to looke into them, you ≈øhall finde them to ≈øpeake much more rudely of their Art, then I doe. I but pinch it gently, they cut the throate of it. Pliny among≈øt other things, doth much ≈øcoffe at them, for≈øomuch as when they are at their wits end, and can goe no further, they have found out this goodly ≈øhift, to ≈øend their long-turmoiled, and to no end much tormented patient, with their drugs and diets, ≈øome to the help of their vowes and myracles, and ≈øome others to hot Baths and waters. (Be not offended noble Lady, he meaneth not tho≈øe on this ≈øide, vnder the protection of your hou≈øe, and all Gramontoi≈øes.) They have a third kinde of ≈øhift or eva≈øion to ≈øhake vs off and di≈øcharge them≈øelves of the imputations or reproaches, we may ju≈øtly charge them with, for the ≈ømall amendment of our infirmities; whereof they have ≈øo long had the ≈øurvay and governement, as they have no more inventions or devi≈øes left them, to ammu≈øe vs with; that is, to ≈øend vs, to ≈øeeke and take the good aire of ≈øome other Country. Madam, we have harped long enough vpon one ≈øtring; I hope you will give me leave to come to my former di≈øcour≈øes againe, from which for your better entertainement, I had ≈øomewhat digre≈ø≈øed.

It was (as farre as I remember) Pericles, who being demanded, how he did; you may (≈øaid he) judge it by this, ≈øhewing certain ≈øcroules or briefes he had tied about his necke and armes. He would infer, that he was very ≈øicke, ≈øince he was forced to have recour≈øe to ≈øuch vanities, and had ≈øuffered him≈øelfe to be ≈øo dre≈øt. I affirme not, but I may one day be drawne to ≈øuch fond opinions, and yeeld my life and health to the mercy, di≈øcretion and regiment of Phi≈øitions. I may happily fall into this fond madne≈ø≈øe; I dare not warrant my future con≈øtancy. It cannot herein be, as in trades; where the Crafts-man and his worke doe often differ. Being a man of ≈øo ≈øound and hone≈øt conuer≈øation, write he ≈øo fooli≈øhly? Are ≈øuch learned writings come from a man of ≈øo weake a conver≈øation? who hath but an ordinary conceite, and writeth excellently, one may ≈øay his capacity is borrowed, not of him≈øelfe. A skilfull man, is not skilfull in all things: But a ≈øufficient man, is ≈øufficient euery where, even vnto ignorance. Heere my booke and my ≈øelfe march together, and keepe one pace. El≈øe-where one may commend or condemne the worke, without the worke-man; heere not: who toucheth one, toucheth the other. He who ≈øhall iudge of it without knowing him, ≈øhall wrong him≈øelfe more then me: he that knowes it,
hath wholly ≈øatisfied mee. Happie beyond my merite, If I get this onely portion of publike approbation, as I may cau≈øe men of vnder≈øtanding to thinke, I had beene able to make v≈øe and benefit of learning, had I beene endowed with any: and de≈øerued better helpe of memorie. excu≈øe wee heere what I often ≈øay, that I ≈øeldome repent my ≈øelfe, and that my con≈øcience is contented with it ≈øelfe; not of an Angels or a hor≈øes con≈øcience, but as of a mans con≈øcience. Adding euer this clau≈øe, not of ceremonie, but of true and e≈ø≈øentiall ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion; that I ≈øpeake inquiring and doubting, meerely and ≈øimply referring my ≈øelfe, from re≈øolution, vnto common and lawfull opinions. I teach not; I report: Noe vice is ab≈øolutely vice, which offendeth not, and a ≈øound iudgement accu≈øeth not: For, the deformitie and incommoditie thereof is ≈øo palpable, as peraduenture they haue rea≈øon, who ≈øay, it is chiefly produced by ≈øotti≈øhne≈ø≈øe and brought forth by ignorance; ≈øo hard is it, to imagine one ≈øhould know it without hating it. Malice ≈øucks vp the greate≈øt part of her owne venome, and therewith impoy≈øoneth her≈øelfe. ∆≤ice, leaueth, as an vlcer in the fle≈øh, a repentance in the ≈øoule, which ≈øtill ≈øcratcheth, and bloodieth it ≈øelfe. For rea≈øon effaceth other griefes and ≈øorrowes, but engendereth tho≈øe of repentance: the more yrke≈øome, becau≈øe inwarde: As the colde and heate of agues is more offen≈øiue then that which comes outward. I account vice (but each according to their mea≈øure) not onely tho≈øe which rea≈øon di≈øalowes, and nature condemnes, but ≈øuch as mans opinion bath forged as fal≈øe and erronious, if lawes and cu≈øtome authorize the ≈øame. In like manner there is not goodne≈ø≈øe but gladdeth an hone≈øt di≈øpo≈øition. There is truely I wot not what kinde or congratulation, of well doing, which reioyceth in our ≈øelues, and a generous jollitie, that accompanieth a good con≈øcience. A minde couragiou≈ølie vicious, may happily furni≈øh it ≈øelfe with ≈øecurity, but ≈øhee cannot bee fraught, with this ≈øelfe-ioyning delight and ≈øatisfaction. It is noe ≈ømall plea≈øure, for one to feele him≈øelfe pre≈øerued from the contagion of an age ≈øo infected as ours, and to ≈øay to him≈øelfe; could a man enter and ≈øee euen into my ≈øoule, yet ≈øhould he not finde me guilty, either of the affliction or ruine of any body, nor culpable of enuie or reuenge, nor of publike offence again≈øt the lawes, nor tainted with innouation, trouble or ≈øedition; nor ≈øpotted with fal≈øifying of my worde; and although the libertie of times alowed and taught it every man, yet could I neuer bee induced to touch the goods or diue into the pur≈øe of any French man; and haue alwayes liued vpon mine own, as well in time of war, as of peace: nor did I euer make v≈øe of any pooremans labour, without reward. The≈øe te≈øtimonies of an vn≈øpotted con≈øcience are very plea≈øing, which naturall ioy is a great benefit vnto vs; and the onely payment neuer faileth vs. To ground the recompence of vertuous actions, vpon the approbation of others, is to vndertake a mo≈øt vncertaine or troubled foundation, namely in an age ≈øo corrupt and times ≈øo ignorant, as this is: the vulgar peoples good opinion is iniurious. Whom tru≈øt you in ≈øeeing what is commendable; God keepe mee from beeing an hone≈øt man, according to the de≈øcription I dayly ≈øee made of honour, each one by him≈øelfe. Quae fuerant vitia, mores ≈øunt. What ear≈øt were vices, are now growne fa≈øhious. Some of my friendes, have ≈øometimes attempted to ≈øchoole me roundly, and ≈øift mee plainely, either of their owne motion, or envited by me, as to an office, which to a well compo≈øed minde, both in profit and lovingne≈ø≈øe, exceedeth all the duties of ≈øincere amity. Such have I euer entertained with open armes of curte≈øie, and kinde acknowledgement. But now to ≈øpeake from my con≈øcience, I often found ≈øo much fal≈øe mea≈øure in their reproches and prai≈øes, that I had not greatly erred if I had rather erred, then done well after their fa≈øhion. Such as wee e≈øpecially, who live a private life not expo≈øed to any gaze but our owne, ought in our hartes e≈øtabli≈øh a touch≈øtone, and thereto touch our deedes and try our actions; and accordingly, now cheri≈øh, and now cha≈øti≈øe our ≈øelues. I haue my owne lawes and tribunall, to iudge of mee, whether I adre≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe more then any where els. I re≈øtraine my actions according to other, but extend them according to my ≈øelfe. None but your ≈øelf knowes rightly whether you be demi≈ø≈øe and cruel, or loyall and deuout. Others ≈øee you not, but ghe≈ø≈øe you by vncertaine coniectures: They ≈øee not ≈øo much your nature, as your arte. Adhere not then to their opinion, but hold vnto your owne. Tuo tibi iudicio e≈øt vtendum. Virtutis & viciorum graue ip≈øius con≈øcientiae pondus Cic. Nat. Deor. L. 3. e≈øt: qua ≈øublata iacent omnia; You mu≈øt v≈øe your owne iudgement: The weight of the very con≈øcience of vice and vertues is heauy: take that away, and all is downe. But where as it is ≈øaid, that repentance nearely followeth ≈øinne, ≈øeemeth not to emplye ≈øinne placed in his rich aray, which lodgeth in vs as in his proper man≈øion. One may di≈øavowe and di≈øclaime vices, that ≈øurpri≈øe vs, and whereto our pa≈ø≈øions tran≈øport vs: but tho≈øe, which by long habite are rooted in a
≈øtrong, and ankred in a powerfull will, are not ≈øubiect to contradiction. Repentance is but a denying of our will, and an oppo≈øition of our fanta≈øies which diuerts vs here and there. It makes ≈øome di≈øauow his former vertue and continencie.

div.p: That is an exqui≈øite life, which euen in his owne priuate keepeth it ≈øelfe in awe and order. Euery one may play the jugler, and repre≈øent an hone≈øt man vpon the ≈øtage; but within, and in bo≈øome, where all thinges are lawfull, where all is concealed; to keepe a due rule or formall decorum, that's the point. The next degree, is to bee ≈øo in ones owne home, and in his ordinary actions, whereof we are to giue accoumpt to no body: wherin is no ≈øtudy, nor arte, And therefore Bias de≈øcribing the perfect ≈øtate of a family, whereof (≈øaith hee) the mai≈øter, be ≈øuch inwardly by him≈øelfe, as hee is outwardly, for feare of the lawes, and re≈øpect of mens ≈øpeaches. And it was a worthy ≈øaying of Iulius Dru≈øus, to tho≈øe worke-men, which for three thou≈øande crownes, offered ≈øo to reforme his hou≈øe, that his neighbours ≈øhould no more ouer looke into it: I will giue you ≈øixe thou≈øand (≈øaid hee) and contriue it ≈øo, that on all ≈øides euery man may looke into it. The cu≈øtome of Age≈øilaus is remembred with honour, who in his trauaile was wont to take vp his lodging in churches, that the people, and Gods them≈øelues might pry into his priuate actions. Some haue beene admirable to the world, in whom nor his wife, nor his ≈øeruant euer noted any thing remarkeable. Few men haue beene admired of their familiars. No man hath beene a Prophet, not onely in his hou≈øe, but in his owne country, ≈øaith the experience of hi≈øtories. Euen ≈øo in things of nought. And in this ba≈øe example, is the image of greatne≈ø≈øe di≈øcerned. In my climate of Ga≈øcoigne they deeme it a ie≈øt to ≈øee mee in print. The further the knowledge which is taken of mee is from my home, of ≈øo much more woorth am I. In Guienne I pay Printers; in other places they pay mee. Vpon this accident they ground, who liuing and pre≈øent keepe clo≈øe-lurking, to purcha≈øe credit when they ≈øhall be dead and ab≈øent. I had rather haue le≈ø≈øe. And I ca≈øt not my ≈øelfe into the world, but for the portion I draw from it. That done, I quit it. The people attend on ≈øuch a man with wonderment, from a publike act, vnto his owne doores: together with his roabes hee leaues-of his part; falling ≈øo much the lower, by how much higher hee was mounted. View him within, thereall is turbulent, di≈øordered and vile. And were order and formality found in him, a liuely, impartiall and well ≈øorted iudgement is required, to perceiue and fully to di≈øcerne him in the≈øe ba≈øe and priuate actions. Con≈øidering that order is but a dumpi≈øh and drow≈øie vertue: To gaine a Battaile, perfourme an Amba≈ø≈øage, and gouerne a people, are noble and woorthy actions; to chide, laugh, ≈øell, pay, loue, hate, and mildely and iu≈øtly to conuer≈øe both with his owne and with him≈øelfe; not to relent, and not gaine-≈øay him≈øelfe, are thinges more rare, more difficult and le≈ø≈øe remarkeable.

Retired liues ≈øu≈øtaine that way, what euer ≈øom ≈øay, offices as much more crabbed, and extended, then other liues doe. And priuate men (≈øaith Ari≈øtotle) ≈øerue vertue more hardly, and more highly attend her, then tho≈øe which are magi≈øtrates or placed in authority. Wee prepare our ≈øelues vnto eminent occa≈øions, more for glory then for con≈øcience. The neare≈øt way to come vnto glory, were to doe that for con≈øcience, which wee doe for glory. And me ≈øeemeth the vertue of Alexander repre≈øenteth much le≈ø≈øe vigor in her large Theater, then that of Socrates, in his ba≈øe and ob≈øcure excercitation. I ea≈øily conceiue Socrates, in the roome of Alexander; Alexander in that of Socrates I cannot. If any aske the one, what hee can doe, hee will an≈øwere, Conquer the world; let the ≈øame que≈øtion bee demaunded of the other, he will ≈øay, leade my life conformably to it's naturall condition; A ≈øcience much more generous, more important, and more lawfull.

The woorth of the minde con≈øisteth not in going high, but in marching orderly. Her greatne≈ø≈øe is not excerci≈øed in greatne≈ø≈øe; in mediocritye it is. As tho≈øe, which iudge and touch vs inwardely, make no great accoumpt of the brightne≈ø≈øe of our publique actions; and ≈øee they are but ≈øtreakes and poyntes of cleare Water,
≈øurging from a bottome, otherwi≈øe ≈ølimie and full of mud: So tho≈øe who iudge vs by this gay outward apparance, conclude the ≈øame of our inward con≈øtitution, and cannot couple popular faculties as theirs are, vnto the≈øe other faculties, which amaze them ≈øo farre from their leuell. So doe we attribute ≈øauage ≈øhapes and ougly formes vnto diuels. As who doeth not a≈øcribe high-rai≈øed eye-browes, open no≈øtrils, a ≈øterne frightfull vi≈øage, and a huge body vnto Tamburlane, as is the forme or ≈øhape of the imagination we haue fore-conceiued by the bruite of his name? Had any heretofore ≈øhewed me Era≈ømus, I could hardly had bin induced to think, but what≈øoeuer he had ≈øaid to his boy or ho≈øtes, had beene Adages and Apothegmes. We imagine much more fitly an Artificer vpon his clo≈øe ≈øtoole or on his wife, then a great judge, reverend for his carriage and regardfull for his ≈øufficiencie; we thinke, that from tho≈øe high thrones they ≈øhould not aba≈øe them≈øelues ≈øo low, as to liue. As vicious mindes are often incited to do well by ≈øome ≈øtrange impul≈øion, ≈øo are vertuous ≈øpirits mooued to d ‚Ä¢ e ill. They mu≈øt then bee judged by their ≈øettled e≈øtate, when they are neare them≈øelues, and as we ≈øay, at home, if at any time they be ≈øo; or when they are neare≈øt vnto re≈øt, and in their naturall ≈øeate. Naturall inclinations are by in≈øtitution helped and ≈øtrengthned, but they neither change nor exceed. A thou≈øand natures in my time, haue a thwart, a contrary di≈øcipline, e≈øcaped toward vertue or toward vice.

div.p:
The≈øe originall qualities are not grubd out, they are but covered, and hidden: The Latine tongue is to mee in a manner naturall; I vnder≈øtand it better then French; but it is now fortie yeares, I have not made v≈øe of it to ≈øpeake, nor much to write: yet in ≈øome extreame emotions and ≈øuddaine pa≈ø≈øions, wherein I haue twice or thrice falen, ≈øince my yeares of di≈øcretion; and namely once, when my father being in perfect health, fell all along vpon me in a ≈øwoune, I haue euer, euen from my very hart vttered my fir≈øt wordes in latine: Nature ru≈øhing and by force expre≈ø≈øing it ≈øelfe, again≈øt ≈øo long a cu≈øtome; the like example is aleaged of diuers others. Tho≈øe which in my time, haue attempted to correct the fa≈øtions of the world by new opinions, reforme the vices of apparance; tho≈øe of e≈ø≈øence they leaue vntouched if they encrea≈øe them not: And their encrea≈øe is much to be feared. We willinglie protract all other well-doing vpon the≈øe externall reformations, of le≈ø≈øe co≈øt, and of greatter merit; whereby wee ≈øatisfie good-cheape, other naturall con≈øub≈øtantiall and inte≈øtine vices. Looke a little into the cour≈øe of our experience. There is no man (if he li≈øten to him≈øelfe) that doth not di≈øcouer in him≈øelfe a peculiar forme of his, a ≈øwaieng forme, which wre≈øtleth again≈øt the in≈øtitution, and again≈øt the tempe≈øts of pa≈ø≈øions, which are contrarie vnto him. As for me, I feele not my ≈øelfe much agitated by a ≈øhocke; I commonly finde my ≈øelfe in mine owne place, as are ≈øluggi≈øh and lumpi≈øh bodies. If I am not clo≈øe and neare vnto my ≈øelfe, I am never farre-off: My debauches or exce≈ø≈øes tran≈øport me not much. There is nothing extreame and ≈øtrange: yet haue I ≈øound fits and vigorous lu≈øts.‚ñ™ The true condemnation, and which toucheth the common fa≈øhion of our men, is, that their very retreate is full of corruption and filth: The Idea of their amendment blurred and deformed; their repentance crazed and faultie, very neere as much as their ≈øinne. Some, either becau≈øe they are ≈øo fa≈øt and naturally ioyned vnto vice, or through long cu≈øtome, haue lo≈øt all ≈øence of it's vgline≈ø≈øe. To others (of who≈øe rancke I am) vice is burthenous, but they counter-ballance it with plea≈øure, or other occa≈øions: and ≈øuffer it, and at a certaine rate lend them≈øelues vnto it; though ba≈øely and viciou≈øly. Yet might happily ≈øo remote a di≈øproportion of mea≈øure bee imagined, where with ju≈øtice, the plea≈øure might excu≈øe the offence, as we ≈øay of profit,
Not onely being accidentall, and out of ≈øinne, as in thefts, but even in the very excerci≈øe of it, as in the acquaintance, or copulation with women; where the prouocation is ≈øo violent, and as they ≈øay, ≈øometime vnre≈øi≈øtable, In a towne of a kin≈øman of mine; the other day, beeing in Armignac, I ≈øawe a country man, commonly ≈øirnemed the Theefe: who him≈øelfe reported his life to haue beene thus. Beeing borne a begger, and perceiuing, that to get his bread by the ≈øweate of his brow and labour of his handes, would neuer ≈øufficiently arme him again≈øt penury, he re≈øolued to become a Theefe; and that trade had employed all his youth ≈øafely, by meanes of his bodily ≈øtrength: for he euer made vp Harue≈øt and Vintage in other mens groundes; but ≈øo farre off, and in ≈øo great heapes, that it was beyond imagination, one man ≈øhould in one night carry away ≈øo much vpon his ≈øhoulders: and was ≈øo carefull to equall the pray, and di≈øperce the mi≈øchiefe he did, that the ≈øpoile was of le≈ø≈øe import to euery particular man.

Hee is now in olde yeares indifferently rich; for a man of his condition (Godamercy his trade) which hee is not a≈øhamed to confe≈ø≈øe openly, And to reconcile him≈øelfe with God, hee affirmeth, to bee dayly ready, with his gettings, and other good turnes, to ≈øatisfie the po≈øterity of tho≈øe hee hath heeretofore wronged or robbed; which if him≈øelfe bee not of abilitie to performe (for hee cannot doe all at once) hee will charge his heires withall, according to the knowledge hee hath, of the wrongs by him done to euery man. By this de≈øcription, bee it true or fal≈øe, hee re≈øpecteth theaft, as a di≈øhone≈øt and vnlawfull action, and hateth the ≈øame: yet le≈ø≈øe then pinching want: Hee repents but ≈øimplie; for in regarde it was ≈øo counterballanced and recompenced, hee repenteth not. That is not that habit which incorporates vs vnto vice, and confirmeth our vnder≈øtanding in it; nor is it that boy≈øterous winde, which by violent bla≈øtes dazeleth and troubleth our mindes, and at that time confoundes, and ouerwhelmes both vs, our iudgement, and all into the power of vice. What I doe, is ordinarily full and compleate, and I march (as wee ≈øay) all in one piece: I haue not many motions, that hide them≈øelves and ≈ølinke away from my rea≈øon, or which very neare are not guided by the con≈øent of all my partes, without diui≈øion, or inte≈øtine ≈øedition: my iudgement hath the whole blame, or commendation; and the blame it hath once, it hath euer: for, almo≈øt from it's birth, it hath beene one, of the ≈øame inclination, cour≈øe and force. And in matters of generall opinions, euen from my infancie, I ranged my ≈øelfe to the point I was to hold. Some ≈øinnes there are outragious, violent and ≈øuddaine; leaue we them.

But tho≈øe other ≈øinnes, ≈øo often rea≈ø≈øumed, determined and adui≈øed vpon, whether they bee of complexion, or of profe≈ø≈øion and calling, I cannot conceiue how they ≈øhould ≈øo long bee ≈øettled in one ≈øame courage, vnle≈ø≈øe the rea≈øon and con≈øcience of the ≈øinner were thervnto inwardly priuie and con≈øtantly willing. And how to imagine or fa≈øhion the repentance thereof, which hee vanteth, doeth ≈øome times vi≈øite him, ≈øeemeth ≈øomewhat hard vnto mee. I am not of Phythagoras Sect, that men take a new ≈øoule, when to receive Oracles, they approach the images of Gods; vnle≈ø≈øe he would ≈øay with all, that it mu≈øt bee a ≈øtrange one, new, and lent him for the time: our owne, giuing ≈øo little ≈øigne of purification, and cleane≈ø≈øe worthy of that office, They doe altogether again≈øt the Stoycall precepts, which appoint vs to correct the imperfections and vices we finde in our ≈øelues, but withall forbidde vs to di≈øturbe the quiet of our minde. They make vs beleeue, they feele great remor≈øe, and are inwardly much di≈øplea≈øed with ≈øinne; but of amendment, correction or intermi≈ø≈øion, they ≈øhew vs none. Surely there can bee noc perfect health; Where the di≈øea≈øe is not perfectlye remooued. Were repentance put in the ≈øcale of the ballance, it woulde weigh downe ≈øinne. I finde no humour ≈øo ea≈øie to bee counterfeited as Deuotion: If one conforme not his life and conditions to it, her e≈ø≈øence is ab≈øtru≈øe and concealed, her apparance gentle and ≈øtately.

For my part, I may in generall wi≈øh to bee other then I am; I may condemne and mi≈ølike my vniuer≈øall forme; I may be≈øeech God to grant mee an vndefiled reformation, and excu≈øe my naturall weakene≈ø≈øe; but mee ≈øeemeth I ought not to tearme this repentance noe more then the di≈øplea≈øure of being neither Angell nor Cat ‚Ä¢ . My actions are ≈øquared to what I am and conformed to my condition. I cannot doe better: And repentance dooth not properly concerne what is not in our power; ≈øorrow dooth. I may imagine infinite di≈øpo≈øitions of a higher pitch, and better gouerned then myne, yet doe I nothing better my faculties;
noe more then mine arme becommeth ≈øtronger, or my wit more excellent, by conceiuing ≈øome others to be ≈øo. If to ≈øuppo≈øe & wi≈øh a more nobler working then ours, might produce the repentance of our owne, wee ≈øhould then repent vs of our mo≈øt innocent actions: for≈øomuch as wee iudge that in a more excellent nature, they had heene directed with greater perfection and dignity; and our ≈øelves would doe the like. When I con≈øult with my age of my youthes proceedings, I finde that commonly, (according to my opinion) I managed them in order. This is all my re≈øi≈øtance is able to performe. I flatter not my ≈øelfe: in like circum≈øtances, I ≈øhould euer bee the ≈øame. It is not a ≈øpot, but a whole dye, that ≈øtaynes mee. I acknowledge noe repentance, that is ≈øuperficiall, meane and ceremoious. It mu≈øt touch mee on all ≈øides, before I can terme it repentance. It mu≈øt pinch my entrailes, and afflict them as deepely and throughly, as God him≈øelfe beholdes mee. When in negotiating, many good fortunes haue ≈ølipt mee for want of good di≈øcretion, yet did my proiects make good choyce, according to the occurrences pre≈øented vnto them. Their manner is euer to take the ea≈øier and ≈øurer ≈øide. I finde that in my former deliberations, I proceeded, after my rules, di≈øcreetely, for the ≈øubiects ≈øtate propounded to mee; and in like occa≈øions, would proceede a like; a hundred yeares, hence. I re≈øpect not what now it is, but what it was, when I con≈øulted of it. The con≈øequence of all de≈ø≈øignes con≈øi≈øtes in the ≈øea≈øons; occa≈øions pa≈ø≈øe, and matters change vnce≈ø≈øantlie. I have in my time runne into ≈øome gro≈ø≈øe, ab≈øurde and important errors; not for want of good adui≈øe, but of good happe. There are ≈øecret and indiuinable partes in the obiects men doe handle; e≈øpeciallie in the nature of men and mute conditions, without ≈øhew, and ≈øometimes vnknowne of the very po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øours, produced and ≈øtirred vp by ≈øuddaine occa≈øions. If my wit coulde neyther finde nor pre≈øage them, I am not offended with it; the function thereof is contained within it's owne limits. If the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe beate mee, and favour the ≈øide I refu≈øed; there is noe remedy; I fall not out with my ≈øelfe; I accu≈øe my fortune, not my endeuour: that's not called repentance. Phocion had giuen the Athenians ≈øome coun≈øell, which was not followed; the matter, again≈øt his opinion, ≈øucceeding happily; How now Phocion, (quoth one) art thou plea≈øed the matter hath thriued ≈øo well? yea (≈øaide hee) and I am glad of it, yet repent not the adui≈øe I gaue.

When any of my friends come to mee for coun≈øell, I be≈øtowe it francklie and clearelie, not as (well nigh all the worlde doth) wavering at the hazard of the matter, whereby the contrary of my meaning may happen, that ≈øo they may ju≈øtly finde fault with my adui≈øe: for which I care not greatly. For they ≈øhall doe mee wrong, and it became nor mee to refu≈øe them that dutie. I haue no body to blame for my faultes or misfortunes, but my ≈øelfe. For in effect I ≈øeldome v≈øe the adui≈øe of other vnle≈ø≈øe it be for complements ≈øake, and where I haue need of in≈øtruction or knowledge of the fact. Marry in things wherin nought but judgment is to bee employed; ≈øtrange rea≈øons may ≈øerve to ≈øu≈øtaine, but not to divert me. I lende a favourable and curteous eare vnto them all. But (to my remembrance) I never beleeued any but mine owne. With mee they are but Flyes and Moathes, which di≈øtract my will. I little regarde mine owne opinions, other mens I e≈øteeme as little: Fortune payes mee accordingly. If I take no coun≈øell I give as little. I am not much ≈øought after for it and le≈ø≈øe credited when I give it: Neither knowe I any enterpri≈øe, either private or publike, that my adui≈øe hath directed and brought to conclu≈øion. Euen tho≈øe whome fortune had ≈øome-way tyde therevnto, have more willingly admitted the direction of others conceites, then mine. As one that am a jealous of the rights of my quiet, as of tho≈øe of my authoritie; I would rather haue it thus.

Where leaving me, they iumpe with my profe≈ø≈øion, which is, wholly to ≈øettle and containe mee in my ≈øelfe. It is a plea≈øure vnto mee, to bee di≈øintere≈ø≈øed of other mens affayres, and di≈øingaged from their contentions. When ≈øutes or bu≈øine≈ø≈øes bee ouer-pa≈øt, how-≈øo-ever it bee, I greeve little at them. For, the imagination that they mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily happen-≈øo, puts mee out of paine; behould them in the cour≈øe of the Vniuer≈øe, and enchained in Stoy call cau≈øes. Your fantazie cannot by wi≈øhe or imagination, remooue one point of them, but the whole order of things mu≈øt rever≈øe both what is pa≈øt, and what is to come. More-over, I hate that accidentall repentance which olde age bringes with it.

Hee that in ancient times ≈øaid, hee was beholden to yeares, becau≈øe they had ridde him of voluptuou≈øne≈ø≈øe, was not of mine opinion. I ≈øhall neuer giue impui≈ø≈øance thankes, for any good it can doe mee. Nec tam aver≈øa vnquam videbitur ab opere ≈øuo providentia, vt debilitas inter optima inuenta ≈øit. Nor ≈øhall fore-≈øight euer bee ≈øeene ≈øo auer≈øe from hir owne worke, that weakene≈ø≈øe bee found to bee one of the best things. Our appetites are rare in olde-age: the blowe over-pa≈ø≈øed, a deepe ≈øacietie ≈øeazeth vpon vs: Therein I ≈øee no con≈øcience. Fretting care and weakene≈ø≈øe, imprint in vs an effeminate and drowzie vertue.

Wee mu≈øt not ≈øuffer our ≈øelues ≈øo fully to be carried into naturall alterations, as to corrupt or adulterate our iudgement by them. Youth and plea≈øure haue not heretofore prevailed ≈øo much ouer me, but I could ever (even in the mid≈øt of ≈øen≈øualities) di≈øcerne the vgly face of ≈øinne: nor can the di≈øta≈øte which yeares bring on me, at this in≈øtant, keepe mee from di≈øcerning that of voluptuou≈øne≈ø≈øe in vice. Now I am no longer in it, I judge of it as if I were ≈øtill there. I who lively and attentively examine my rea≈øon, finde it to be the ≈øame that po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed me in my mo≈øt di≈ø≈øolute and licentious age; vnle≈ø≈øe perhaps, they being enfeebled and empayred by yeares, doe make ≈øome difference: And finde, that what delight it refu≈øeth to affoorde mee in regarde of my bodilie health, it would no more denie mee, then in times pa≈øt, for the health of my ≈øoule. To ≈øee it out of combate, I holde it not the more couragious. My temptations are ≈øo mortified and crazed, as they are not worthy of it's oppo≈øitions; holding but my hand before me, I be-calme them. Should one pre≈øent that former concupi≈øcence vnto it, I feare it would be of le≈ø≈øe power to ≈øu≈øtance it than heretofore it hath beene. I ≈øee in it, by it ≈øelfe no encrea≈øe of iudgement, nor acce≈ø≈øe of brightne≈ø≈øe, what it now iudgeth, it did then. Wherefore if there be any amendment, t'is but di≈øea≈øed. Oh mi≈øerable kinde of remedie, to be beholden vnto ≈øickne≈ø≈øe for our health. It is not for our mi≈øhap, but for the good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of our iudgement to performe this office. Cro≈ø≈øes and afflictions, make me doe nothing but cur≈ø≈øe them. They are for people, that cannot be awaked but by the whip. The cour≈øe of my rea≈øon is the nimbler in pro≈øperitie; It is much more di≈øtracted and bu≈øied in the dige≈øting of mi≈øchiefes, than of delights. I ≈øee much cleare ‚Ä¢ in faire weather. Health forewarneth me, as with more plea≈øure, ≈øo to better purpo≈øe than ≈øickne≈ø≈øe. I approached the neare≈øt I could vnto amendment and regularity, when I ≈øhould have enioyed the ≈øame; I ≈øhould be a≈øhamed and vexed, that the mi≈øery and mi≈øhap of my old age could exceede the helth, attention and vigor of my youth: and that I ≈øhould be e≈øteemed, not for what I have beene, but for what I am leaft to be. The happy life (in my opinion) not (as ≈øaid Anti≈øthenes) the happy death, is it that makes mans happine≈ø≈øe in this world.

I have not prepo≈øterou≈øly bu≈øied my ≈øelfe to tie the taile of a Philo≈øopher, vnto the head and bodie of a varlet: nor that this paultrie end, ≈øhould di≈øavow and belie the faire≈øt, ≈øounde≈øt, and longe≈øt part of my life. I will pre≈øent my ≈øelfe, and make a generall mu≈øter of my whole, every where vniformally. Were I to live againe, it ≈øhould bee as I have already lived. I neither deplore what is pa≈øt, nor dread what is to come: and if I be not deceived, the inward parts have neerely re≈øembled the outward. It is one of the chiefe≈øt points wherein I am beholden to fortune, that in the cour≈øe of my bodies e≈øtate, each thing hath beene carried in ≈øea≈øon. I have ≈øeene the leaves, the blo≈ø≈øomes, and the fruit; and now ≈øee the drooping and withering of it. Happily, becau≈øe naturally. I beare my pre≈øent mi≈øeries the more gently, becau≈øe they are in ≈øea≈øon, and with greater favour make mee remember the long happine≈ø≈øe of my former life. In like manner, my di≈øcretion may well bee of like proportion in the one and the other time: but ≈øure it was of much more performance, and had a better grace, being fre≈øh, iolly and full of ≈øpirit, then now that it is worne, decrepite and toyle≈øome.

I therefore renounce the≈øe ca≈øuall and dolourous reformations. God must touch our heartes; our con≈øcience must amende of it ≈øelfe, and not by re-inforcement of our rea≈øon, nor by the enfeebling of our appetites. Voluptuou≈øne≈ø≈øe in it ≈øelfe is neither pale nor di≈øcouloured, to be di≈øcerned by bleare and troubled eyes. Wee ≈øhould affect temperance and cha≈øtity for it ≈øelfe, and for Gods cau≈øe, who hath ordained them vnto vs:
that which Catars be≈øtow vpon vs, and which I am beholden to my chollicke for, is neither temperance nor cha≈øtitie. A man cannot boa≈øt of contemning or combating ≈øen≈øualitie, if hee ≈øee her not, or know not her grace, her force and mo≈øt attractive beauties. I know them both, and therefore may ≈øpeake it. But mee thinkes our ≈øoules in age are ≈øubject vnto more importunate di≈øea≈øes and imperfections, then they are in youth. I ≈øaid ≈øo being young, when my beardle≈ø≈øe chinne was vpbraided mee; and I ≈øay it againe, now that my gray beard gives me authoritie. We entitle wi≈ødome, the frowardne≈ø≈øe of our humours, and the di≈øta≈øte of pre≈øent things; but in truth wee abandon not vices, ≈øo much as wee change them; and in mine opinion for the wor≈øe. Be≈øides a ≈øillie and ruinous pride, comber≈øome tattle, wayward and vn≈øociable humours, ≈øuper≈øtition and a ridiculous carking for wealth, when the v≈øe of it is well nigh lo≈øt, I finde the more enuie, inju≈øtice and leaudne≈ø≈øe in it. It ≈øets more wrinckles in our mindes, then on our foreheads: nor are there any ≈øpirits, or very rare ones, which in growing old ta≈øte not ≈øowrely and mu≈øtily. Man marcheth entirely towards his encrea≈øe and decrea≈øe. View but the wi≈øedome of Socrates, and divers circum≈øtances of his condemnation, I dare ≈øay he ≈øomething lent him≈øelfe vnto it by prevarication of purpo≈øe: being ≈øo neere, and at the age of ≈øeventie, to endure the benumming of his ≈øpirits riche≈øt pace, and the dimming of his accu≈øtomed brightne≈ø≈øe. What Metamorpho≈øes have I ≈øeene it daily make in diuers of mine acquaintances? It is a powerfull maladie, which naturally and imperceptible glideth into vs: There is required great proui≈øion of ≈øtu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , heed and precaution, to auoid the imperfections wherewith it chargeth vs; or at lea≈øt to weaken their further progre≈ø≈øe. I finde that notwith≈øtanding all my entrenchings, by little and little it getteth ground vpon mee: I hold out as long as I can, but know not whither at length it will bring mee. Happe what happe will, I am plea≈øed the world know from what height I tumbled.

div.head: The third Chapter.
div.p:
WE mu≈øt not cleave ≈øo fa≈øt vnto our humours and di≈øpo≈øitions. Our chiefe≈øt ≈øufficiencie is, to applie our ≈øelves to divers fa≈øhions. It is a being, but not a life, to bee tied and bound by nece≈ø≈øitie to one onely cour≈øe. The goodlie≈øt mindes are tho≈øe that have mo≈øt varietie and pliablene≈ø≈øe in them. Behold an honourable te≈øtimonie of old Cato: Huic ver≈øatile ingenium ≈øic pariter ad omnia fuit, vt natum ad id vnum diceres, quodcunque ageret. Iiu. bel. Mac. l. 9. Hee had a wit ≈øo turneable for all things alike, as one would ≈øay hee had beene onely borne for that hee went about to doe. Were I to dre≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe after mine owne manner, there is no fa≈øhion ≈øo good, whereto I would bee ≈øo affected or tied, as not to know how to leave and loo≈øe it. Life is a motion vnequall, irregular and multiforme. It is not to bee the friend (le≈ø≈øe the ma≈øter) but the ≈ølave of ones ≈øelfe to follow vnce≈ø≈øantly, and bee ≈øo addicted to his inclinations, as hee cannot ≈øtray from them, nor wre≈øt them. This I ≈øay now, as being extremely pe≈øtred with the importunitie of my minde, for≈øomuch as ≈øhee cannot ammu≈øe her ≈øelfe, but whereon it is bu≈øied; not employ it ≈øelfe, but bent and whole. How light ≈øoever the ≈øubject is one giues it, it willingly amplifieth, and wire-drawes the ≈øame, even vnto the highe≈øt pitch of toile. It's idlene≈ø≈øe is therefore a painefull trade vnto mee, and offen≈øive to my health. Mo≈øt wits have neede of extravagant ≈øtuffe, to vn-benumme and exerci≈øe them≈øelves: mine hath neede of it, rather to ≈øettle and continue it ≈øelfe: ∆≤itia otij negotio di≈øcutienda ≈øunt, The vices of idlene≈ø≈øe ≈øhould bee ≈øhaken off with bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: For, theS ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . ep. 56. mo≈øt laborious care and principall ≈øtudie of it, is, to ≈øtudie it ≈øelfe. Bookes are one of tho≈øe bu≈øine≈ø≈øes that ≈øeduce it from ≈øtudie. At the fir≈øt thoughts that pre≈øent them≈øelves, it rouzeth vp and makes proofe of all the vigour it hath. It exerci≈øeth it's function ≈øometimes toward force, ≈øometimes toward order and comeline≈ø≈øe, it rangeth, moderates
and fortifieth. It hath of it ≈øelfe to awaken the faculties of it: Nature having given it, as vnto all other, matter of it's owne for advantage, and ≈øubiects fit enough whereon to devi≈øe and determine. Meditation is a large and powerfull ≈øtudie to ≈øuch as vigorou≈øly can ta≈øte and employ them≈øelues therein. I had rather forge then furni≈øh my minde.

There is no office or occupation either weaker or ≈øtronger, then that of entertaining of ones thoughts according to the minde, what≈øoever it be. The greate≈øt make it their vacation, Quibus viuere e≈øt cogitare, to whom it is all one to liue and to meditate. Nature hath al≈øo favoured it with this priuilege, that there is nothing we can doe ≈øo long; nor action, whereto wee give our ≈øelves more ordinarily and ea≈øily. It is the worke of Gods (≈øaith Aristotle) whence both their happine≈ø≈øe and ours proceedeth. Reading ≈øerves mee e≈øpecially, to awake my conceit by divers objects; to bu≈øie my judgement, not my memorie. Few entertainments then, ≈øtay mee without vigour and force. T'is true that courte≈øie and beautie po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe mee, as much or more, then waight and depth. And becau≈øe I ≈ølumber in all other communications, and lend but the ≈øuperficiall parts of my attention vnto them, it often befalleth mee, in ≈øuch kinde of weake and ab≈øurd di≈øcour≈øes, (di≈øcour≈øes of countenance) to blurt out and an≈øwer ridiculous toies, and fond ab≈øurdities, vnworthie a childe; or wilfully to hold my peace; therewithall more fooli≈øhly and incivilly. I have a kinde of raving fancie-full behaviour, that retireth mee into my ≈øelfe; and on the other ≈øide, a gro≈ø≈øe and childi≈øh ignorance of many ordinarie things; by meanes of which two qualities, I have in my daies committed five or ≈øix as ≈øotti≈øh trickes, as any one who≈øoever; which to my derogation may bee reported. But to follow my purpo≈øe, this har≈øh complexion of mine makes me nice in conuer≈øing with men (whom I mu≈øt picke and cull out for the nonce) and vnfit for common actions. Wee liue and negotiate with the people: If their behaviour importune vs, if wee di≈ødaine to lend our ≈øelves to ba≈øe and vulgar ≈øpirits, which often are as regular as tho≈øe of a finer mould; and all wi≈øedome is va≈øavourie, that is not conformed to common in≈øipience. Wee are no longer to intermeddle either with our, or other mens affaires: and both publike and private for≈øake ≈øuch kinde of people.

The lea≈øt wre≈øted, and mo≈øt naturall proceedings of our minde, are the faire≈øt; the be≈øt occupations, tho≈øe which are lea≈øt forced. Good God, how good an office doth wi≈øedome vnto tho≈øe, who≈øe de≈øires ≈øhee ≈øquareth according to their power! There is no ≈øcience more profitable. As one may, was the burden and favoured ≈øaying of Socrates: A ≈øentence of great ≈øub≈øtance. Wee mu≈øt addre≈ø≈øe and ≈øtay our de≈øires, to things mo≈øt ea≈øie and neere≈øt. Is it not a fond-peevi≈øh humour in mee, to di≈øagree from a thou≈øand; to whom my fortune joineth mee, without whom I cannot live, to adhere vnto one or two, that are out of my commerce and conuer≈øation; or rather to a fanta≈øticall conceit, or fancie-full de≈øire, for a thing I cannot obtaine? My ≈øoft behaviours and milde manners, enemies to all ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe and foes to all bitterne≈ø≈øe, may ea≈øily have di≈øcharged mee from envie and contention. To bee beloved, I ≈øay not, but not to bee hated, never did man give more occa≈øion. But the coldne≈ø≈øe of my conuer≈øation, hath with rea≈øon robd mee of the good will of many; which may bee excu≈øed, if they interpret the ≈øame to other, or wor≈øe ≈øen≈øe. I am mo≈øt capable of getting rare amities, and continuing exqui≈øite acquaintances. For ≈øo much as with ≈øo greedie hunger I ≈ønatch at ≈øuch acquaintances as an≈øwer my ta≈øte and ≈øquare with my humour. I ≈øo greedily produce and headlong ca≈øt my ≈øelfe vpon them, that I doe not ea≈øily mi≈ø≈øe to cleaue vnto them, and where I light-on, to make a ≈øteadie impre≈ø≈øion; I have often made happie and ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull triall of it.

In vulgar worldly friend≈øhips, I am ≈øomewhat cold and barren; for my proceeding is not naturall, if not vnre≈øi≈øted and with hoi≈øed-full ≈øailes. Moreover, my fortune having enured and allured mee, even from my infancie, to one ≈øole-≈øingular and perfect amitie, hath verily, in ≈øome ≈øort, di≈øta≈øted mee from others: and over-deeply imprinted in my fanta≈øie, that it is a bea≈øt ≈øociable and for companie, and not of troupe, as ≈øaid an ancient writer. So that it is naturally a paine vnto mee, to communicate my ≈øelfe by halves, and with modification; and that ≈øervile or ≈øu≈øpicious wi≈øedome, which in the conver≈øation of the≈øe numerous and imperfect amities, is ordained and propo≈øed
vnto vs: Pre≈øcribed in the≈øe daies e≈øpecially, Wherein one cannot ≈øpeake of the world but dangerou≈ølie or fal≈øelie. Yet I ≈øee, that who (as I doe) makes for his ende, the commodities of his lyfe (I meane e≈ø≈øentiall commodities) mu≈øt auoyde as a plague, the≈øe difficulties and quaintne≈ø≈øe of humour.

I ≈øhould commend a high-ray≈øed minde, that could both bende and di≈øcharge it ≈øelfe: that where-ever hir fortune might tran≈øporte hir, ≈øhee might continue con≈øtant: that could di≈øcour≈øe with hir neyghbour of all matters, as of hir building, of hir hunting and of any quarrell; and entertaine with delight a Carpenter or a Gardiner. I enuye tho≈øe which can be familiar with the meane≈øt of their followers, and vouchafe to contract friend≈øhip, and frame di≈øcour≈øe with their owne ≈øeruantes. Nor do I like the adui≈øe of Plato, ever to ≈øpeake imperiou≈ølye vnto our attendants, without blithne≈ø≈øe and ≈øance any familiaritie: be it to men or women ≈øeruants. For, be≈øides my rea≈øon, it is inhumanitie, and inju≈øtice, to attribute ≈øo much vnto that prerogatiue of fortune: and the govenrment, where le≈ø≈øe inequalitie is permited betweene the ≈øeruant and may≈øter, is, in my conceite the more indifferent. Some other ≈øtudie to rouze and rai≈øe their minde; but I to aba≈øe and pro≈øtrate mine: it is not faultie but in exten≈øion.

div.p: Even as the Lacedemonian valoure had neede of moderation, and of ≈øweete and plea≈øing ≈øoundes of Flutes, to flatter and allaye it in time of warre, lea≈øt it ≈øhould runne head-long into ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe and furye: whereas all other nations v≈øe commonly pearcing ≈øoundes and ≈øtrong ≈øhouts, which violently excite, and enflame their ≈øouldyers courage: ≈øo thinke I (again≈øt ordinarye cu≈øtome) that in the imployment of our ≈øpirite, wee have for the mo≈øt part more need of leade then winges; of coldene≈ø≈øe and quiet, then of heate and agitation. Above all, in my mind, The onely way to playe the foole well, is to ≈øeeme wi≈øe among fooles: to ≈øpeake as though ones tongue were ever bent to Fauelar' in punta diforchetta, To Ital. div.p:
And alleadge Plato, and Saint Thomas for things, which the fir≈øt man they meete would decide as well, and ≈øtand for as good a witne≈ø≈øe. Such learning as could not enter

If the well borne will give any credit vnto me, they ≈øhall be plea≈øed to make their owne and naturall riches to prevaile and be of worth: They hide and ≈øhroud their formes vnder fortaine and borrowed beawties: It is great ≈øimplicity, for any body to ≈ømoother and conceale his owne brightne≈ø≈øe, to ≈øhine with a borrowed light: They are buried and entombed vnder the Arte of CAPS∆≤LA TOTAE, It is becau≈øe they doe not ≈øufficiently know them≈øelves: the World containes nothing of more beauty: It is for them to honour Artes, and to beawtifie embelli≈øhment. What neede they more then to live beloved and honoured? They have, and know but too much in that matter. There needes but a little rouzing and enflaming of the faculties that are in them.

When I ≈øee them medling with Rhetoricke, with Law, and with Logicke, and ≈øuch like tra≈øh, ≈øo vaine and vnprofitable for their v≈øe; I enter into feare, that tho≈øe who advi≈øe them to ≈øuch things, doe it, that they may have more law to governe them vnder that pretence.
