It is ≈øufficient, that without vs, they may frame, or roule the grace of their eyes, vnto cheerefulne≈ø≈øe, vnto ≈øeverity, and vnto mildene≈ø≈øe: and ≈øea≈øon a No with frowardne≈ø≈øe, with doubt and with favour; and require not an interpretor in di≈øcour≈øes made for their ≈øervice. With this learning they command without controule, and over-rule both Regents and Schooles. Yet if it offend them to yeeld vs any preheminence, and would for curio≈øity ≈øake have part in bookes al≈øo: Poe≈øie is a ≈øtudy fit for their purpo≈øe: being a wanton, ammu≈øing, ≈øubtill, di≈øgui≈øed, and pratling Arte; all in delight, all in ≈øhew, like to them≈øelves. They may al≈øo ≈øelect diver≈øe commodities out of Hi≈øtory. In Morall Philo≈øophy, they may take the di≈øcour≈øes which enable them to judge of our humours, to cen≈øure our conditions, and to avoide our guiles and treacheries; to temper the ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe of their owne de≈øires. to hu≈øband their liberty: lengthen the delights of life; gently to beare the incon≈øtancy of a ≈øeruant, the peevi≈øhne≈ø≈øe or rudene≈ø≈øe of a husband, the importunity of yeares, the vnwellcomne≈ø≈øe of wrinckles, and ≈øuch like minde-troubling accidents. Loe heare the mo≈øt and greate≈øt ≈øhare of learning I would a≈ø≈øigne them. There are ≈øome particular, retired and clo≈øe di≈øpo≈øitions.

My e≈ø≈øentiall forme is fit for communication, and proper for production: I am all outward and in apparance; borne for ≈øociety and vnto friend≈øhip. The ≈øolitude I love and commend, is e≈øpecially but to retire my affections and redeeme my thoughts vnto my ≈øelfe; to re≈øtraine and clo≈øevp, not my ≈øteppes, but my de≈øires and my eares, re≈øigning all forraigne ≈øolicitude and trouble, and mortally ≈øhunning all manner of ≈øeruitude and obligation; and not ≈øo much the throng of men as the importunity of affaires. Locall ≈øolitarine≈ø≈øe (to ≈øay trueth) doth rather extend and enlarge mee outwardly; I give my ≈øelfe to State-bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and to the world, more willingly when I am all alone. At the Court, and in pre≈ø≈øe of people, I clo≈øe and ≈ølinke into mine owne skinne. A≈ø≈øemblies thru≈øt mee againe into my ≈øelfe. And I never entertaine my ≈øelfe ≈øo fondly, ≈øo licenciou≈øly, and ≈øo particularly, as in places of re≈øpect, and ceremonious di≈øcretion. Our follies make mee not laugh, but our wi≈ødomes doe. Of mine owne complexion, I am no enemy to the agitations and ≈øtirrings of our Courts: I have there pa≈øt great part of my life: and am enured to bee merry in great a≈ø≈øemblies; ≈øo it beeby entermi≈ø≈øion, and ≈øutable to my humour.

But this tenderne≈ø≈øe and coine≈ø≈øe of judgement (whereof I ≈øpeake) doth perforce tie mee vnto ≈øolitarine≈ø≈øe. Yea even in mine owne hou≈øe, in the midde≈øt of a numerous familie and mo≈øt frequented hou≈øes, I ≈øee people more then a good many, but ≈øeldome ≈øuch as I love to conver≈øe or communicate withall. And there I re≈øerve, both for my ≈øelfe, and others, an vnaccu≈øtomed libertie; making truce with ceremonies, a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and invitings, and ≈øuch other trouble≈øome ordinances of our courte≈øie (O ≈øervile cu≈øtome and importunate manner) there every man demeaneth him≈øelfe as hee plea≈øeth, and entertaineth what his thoughts affect; whereas I keepe my ≈øelfe ≈øilent, meditating and clo≈øe, without offence to my gue≈øts or friends.

The men who≈øe familiaritie and ≈øocietie I hunt after, are tho≈øe which are called hone≈øt, vertuous and ≈øufficient: the image of whom doth di≈øta≈øte and divert mee from others. It
is (being rightly taken) the rare≈øt of our formes; and a forme or fa≈øhion chiefly due vnto nature.

The end or ≈øcope of this commerce, is principally and ≈øimply familiarity, conference and frequentation: the exerci≈øe of mindes, without other fruite. In our di≈øcour≈øes, all ≈øubiects are alike to mee: I care not though they want either waight or depth; grace and pertmency are never wanting; all therein is tainted with a ripe and con≈øtant iudgement, and commixt with goodne≈ø≈øe, liberty, cheerefulne≈ø≈øe, and kindne≈ø≈øe. It is not onely in the ≈øubiect of Lawes and affaires of Princes, that our ≈øpirit ≈øheweth it's beautie, grace and vigor: It ≈øheweth them as much in priuate conferences. I know my people by their very ≈øilence and ≈ømyling, and peraduenture di≈øcover them better at a Table, then ≈øitting in ≈øerious coun≈øell.

Hippomacus ≈øaid, hee di≈øcerned good Wre≈øtlers but by ≈øeeing them march through a Street. If learning vouch≈øafe to ≈øtep into our talke, ≈øhee ≈øhall not be refu≈øed; yet mu≈øt not ≈øhee be ≈øterne, ma≈øtring, imperious and importunate, as commonly ≈øhee is; but a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, and docile of hir≈øelfe. Therein wee ≈øeeke for nothing but recreation and pa≈øtime: when we ≈øhall looke to be in≈øtructed, taught and re≈øolved, we will goe ≈øeeke and ≈øue to hir in hir Throne. Let hir if ≈øhee plea≈øe keepe from vs at that time; for, as commodious and plea≈øing as ≈øhee is: I pre≈øume that for a neede wee could ≈øpare hir pre≈øence, and doe our bu≈øine≈ø≈øe well-enough without hir. Wits well borne, ≈øoundly bred and exerci≈øed in the practi≈øe and commerce of men, become gracious and plau≈øible of them≈øelves. Arte is but the Checke-roule, and Regi≈øter of the Productions vttered, and conceites produced by them.

The company of faire, and ≈øociety of hone≈øt women is likewi≈øe a ≈øweet commerce for me: Nam ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s quoque oculos cruditos habemus, for wee al≈øo have learned eyes. If the minde haveCi ‚Ä¢ . parad. not ≈øo much to ≈øolace hir-≈øelfe, as in the former; the corporall ≈øences, who≈øe part is more in the ≈øecond, bring it to a proportion neere vnto the other; although in mine opinion not equall. But it is a ≈øociety wherein it behooveth a man ≈øomewhat to ≈øtand vpon his guard; and e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are of a ≈øtrong con≈øtitution, and who≈øe body can doe much, as in mee. In my youth I heated my ≈øelfe therein and was very violent; and endured all the rages and furious a≈ø≈øaults, which Poets ≈øay happen to tho≈øe who without order or di≈øcretion abandon them≈øelves over-loo≈øly and riotou≈øly vnto it. div.p: It is folly to fa≈øten all ones thoughts vpon it, and with a furious and indi≈øcreet affection to engage him≈øelfe vnto it: But on the other≈øide, to meddle with it without loue or bond of affection, as Comediants doe, to play a common part of age and manners, without ought of their owne but bare-conned words, is verily a proui≈øion for ones ≈øafety: and yet but a cowardly one; as is that of him, who would forgoe his honour, his profit or his plea≈øure for feare of danger; for it is certaine that the practi≈øers of ≈øuch cour≈øes, cannot hope for any fruite able to moove or ≈øatisfie a worthy minde.

One mu≈øt very earne≈øtly have de≈øired that, whereof he would enioy an ab≈øolute delight: I meane, though fortune ≈øhould vniu≈øtly fauour their intention: which often hapneth becau≈øe there is no woman, how deformed and vnhand≈øome ≈øoever, but thinkes hir-≈øelfe louely, amiable and prai≈øe-worthy, either for hir age, hir haire or gate (for there are generally no more faire then foule ones) And the Brachmanian maides wanting other commendations; by Proclamation for that purpo≈øe, made ≈øhew
of their matrimoniall parts vnto the people a≈ø≈øembled, to ≈øee if thereby at lea≈øt they might get them husbands. By con≈øequence there is not one of them, but vpon the fir≈øt oath one maketh to ≈øerve her, will very ea≈øily bee per≈øwaded to thinke well of her ≈øelfe. Now this common trea≈øon and ordinary prote≈øtations of men in the≈øe daies, mu≈øt needes produce the effects, experience already di≈øcovereth: which is, that either they joine together, and ca≈øt away them≈øelves on them≈øelves, to avoid vs, or on their ≈øide follow al≈øo the example wee give them; acting their part of the play, without pa≈ø≈øion; without care, and without love, lending them≈øelves to this entercour≈øe: Neque affectui ≈øuo aut alieno obnoxiae: Neither liable to their owne nor other folkes affection. Thinking, according to Ly≈øias per≈øwa≈øions in Plato, they may ≈øo much the more profitably and commodiou≈øly yeeld vnto vs; by how much le≈ø≈øe we love them: Wherein it will happen as in Comedies, the ≈øpectators ≈øhall have as much or more plea≈øure, as the Comedians. For my part, I no more acknowledge ∆≤enus without Cupid, then a motherhood without an off-≈øpring: They are things which enter-lend and enter-owe one another their e≈ø≈øence. Thus doth this cozening rebound on him that v≈øeth it; and as it co≈øts him little, ≈øo gets he not much by it. Tho≈øe which made Venus a Godde≈ø≈øe, have re≈øpected that her principall beautie was incorporeall and ≈øpirituall. But ≈øhee whom the≈øe kinde of people hunt after, is not ≈øo much as humane, nor al≈øo brutall; but ≈øuch as wilde bea≈øts, would not have her ≈øo filthy and terre≈øtriall. We ≈øee that imagination enflames them, and de≈øire or lu≈øt vrgeth them, before the body: Wee ≈øee in one and other ≈øex, even in whole heards, choi≈øe and di≈øtinctions in their affections, and among≈øt them≈øelves acquaintances of long continued good-will and liking. And even tho≈øe to whom age denieth bodily ≈øtrength, doe yet bray, neigh, roare, skip and wince for love. Before the deed wee ≈øee them full of hope and heat; and when the body hath plaid his part, even tickle and tingle them≈øelves with the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of that remembrance: ≈øome of them ≈øwell with pride at parting from it, others all weary and glutted, ring out ≈øongs of glee and triumph. Who makes no more of it but to di≈øcharge his body of ≈øome naturall nece≈ø≈øitie, hath no cau≈øe to trouble others with ≈øo curious preparation. It is no food for a greedie and clowni≈øh hunger. As one that would not be accounted better then I am, thus much I will di≈øplay of my youths wanton-errours: Not onely for the danger of ones health that followes that game (yet could I not avoid two, though light and cur≈øorie a≈ø≈øaults) but al≈øo for contempt, I have not much beene given to mercenarie and common acquaintances. I have coveted to ≈øet an edge on that ≈øen≈øuall plea≈øure by difficultie, by de≈øire, and for ≈øome glory. And liked Tiberius his fa≈øhions, who in his amours was ≈øwa ‚Ä¢ ed as much by mode≈øty and noblene≈ø≈øe, as by any other qualitie. And Floras humour, who would pro≈øtitute her ≈øelfe to none wor≈øe then Dictators, Con≈øuls, or Cen≈øors, and tooke delight in the dignitie and greatne≈ø≈øe of her lovers, doth ≈øome-what ≈øute with mine. Surely glittering pearles and ≈øilken cloathes adde ≈øome thing vnto it, and ≈øo doe titles, nobilitie and a worthie traine. Be≈øides which, I made high e≈øteeme of the minde, yet ≈øo as the body might not iu≈øtly be found fault withall: For, to ≈øpeake my con≈øcience, if either of the two beauties were nece≈ø≈øarily to bee wanting, I would rather have cho≈øen to want the mentall, who≈øe v≈øe is to be emploied in better things. But in the ≈øubject of love; a ≈øubject that chiefly hath reference vnto the two ≈øen≈øes of ≈øeeing and touching, ≈øome thing may be done without the graces of the minde, but little or nothing without the corporall. Beautie is the true auailefull advantage of women: It is ≈øo peculiarly theirs, that ours though it require ≈øome features and different allurements, is not in her right kue, or true bias, vnle≈ø≈øe confu≈øed with theirs; childi≈øh and beardle≈ø≈øe. It is reported, that ≈øuch as ≈øerve the great Turke vnder the title of beautie (whereof the number is infinite) are di≈ømi≈ø≈øed at furthe≈øt when they once come to the age of two and twenty yeeres. Di≈øcour≈øe, di≈øcretion, together with the offices of true amitie, are better found amongst men: and therefore governe they the worlds affaires. The≈øe two commerces or ≈øocieties are accidentall and depending of others; the one is trouble≈øome and tedious for it's raritie; the other withers with old age: nor could they have ≈øufficiently provided for my liues nece≈ø≈øities. That of bookes, which is the third, is much more ≈øolid-≈øure and much more ours; ≈øome other advantages it yeeldeth to the two former; but hath for her ≈øhare con≈øtancie and the facilitie of her ≈øervice. This acco≈øteth and ≈øecondeth all my cour≈øe, and every where a≈ø≈øi≈øteth me: It comforts mee in age, and ≈øolaceth me in ≈øolitarine≈ø≈øe: It ea≈øeth mee of the burden of a weary-≈øome ≈øloth; and at all times rids mee of tedious companies; it abateth
the edge of fretting ≈øorrow, on condition it bee not extreme and over-in≈øolent. To divert me from any importunate imagination or in≈øinuating conceit, there is no better way then to have recour≈øe vnto bookes: with ea≈øe they allure mee to them, and with facilitie they remoove them all. And though they perceive I neither frequent nor ≈øeeke them, but wanting other more e≈ø≈øentiall, lively, and more naturall commodities, they never mutinie or murmure at mee; but ≈øtill entertaine mee with one and ≈øelfe-≈øame vi≈øage. The ≈øicke man is not to be moaned, that hath his health in his ≈øleeve. In the experience and v≈øe of this ≈øentence, which is mo≈øt true, con≈øi≈øteth all the commoditie I reape of bookes. In effect I make no other v≈øe of them, then tho≈øe who know them not. I enioy them, as a mi≈øer doth his gold; to know, that I may enioy them when I li≈øt; my minde is ≈øetled and ≈øatisfied with the right of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. For it is wonderfull, what repo≈øe I take, and how I continue in this con≈øideration, that they are at my elbow to delight me when time ≈øhall ≈øerve: and in acknowledging what a≈ø≈øi≈øtance they give vnto my life. This is the be≈øt munition I have found in this humane peregrination; and I extremely bewaile tho≈øe men of vnder≈øtanding that want the ≈øame. I accept with better will all otehr kindes of ammu≈øements, how ≈ølight ≈øoever, for≈øomuch as this cannot faile me. The lowermo≈øt is my Chapell; the ≈øecond a chamber with other lodgings, where I often lie, becau≈øe I would bee alone. Above it is a great ward-robe. Magna Sen. con≈ø. ad Pol. c. 26. p. ≈øeruitus est magna fortuna: A great fortune is a great bondage. They cannot bee private ≈øo
much as at their priuie, I have deemed nothing ≈øo rude in the au≈øteritie of the life, which our Church-men affect, as that in ≈øome of their companies they in≈øtitute a perpetuall ≈øocietie of place, and a mumerous a≈ø≈øi≈øtance among≈øt them in any thing they doe. And deeme it ≈øomewhat more tolerable to bee ever alone, then never able to be ≈øo. If any ≈øay to mee, It is a kinde of vilifying the Mu≈øes, to v≈øe them onely for ≈øporte and recreation, he wots not as I doe, what worth, plea≈øure, ≈øporte and pa≈ø≈øe-time is of: I had well nigh termed all other ends ridiculous. I live from hand to mouth, and with reverence bee it ≈øpoken, I live but to my ≈øelfe: there end all my de≈øignes. Being young I ≈øtudied for o≈øtentation; then a little to enable my ≈øelfe and become wi≈øer; now for delight and recreation; never for gaine. Touching hardine≈ø≈øe and vndaunted courage, and as for matchle≈ø≈øe con≈øtancie, vnmooved a≈ø≈øuredne≈ø≈øe, and vndi≈ømaied re≈øolution again≈øt paine, ≈ømarting, famine and death it ≈øelfe; I will not feare to oppo≈øe the examples which I may ea≈øily finde among≈øt them, to the mo≈øt famous ancient examples, wee may with all our indu≈øtrie di≈øcover in all the Annalles and memories of our knowen old World. For, as for tho≈øe which have ≈øubdued them, let them lay a≈øide the wiles, the policies and ≈øtratagems, which they have emploied to cozen, to cunny-catch, and to circumvent them; and the iu≈øt a≈øtoni≈øhment which tho≈øe nations might iu≈øtly conceive, by ≈øeeing ≈øo vnexpected an arrivall of bearded men; divers in language, in habite, in religion, in behaviour, in forme, in countenance; and from a part of the world ≈øo di≈øtant, and where they never heard any habitation was: mounted vpon great and vnknowen mon≈øters; again≈øt tho≈øe, who had never ≈øo much as ≈øeene any hor≈øe, and le≈ø≈øe any bea≈øt what≈øoever apt to beare, or taught to carry either man or burden; covered with a ≈øhining and hard skinne, and armed with ≈ølicing-keene weapons and glittering armour: again≈øt them, who for the wonder of the gli≈øtring of a looking-gla≈ø≈øe or of a plaine knife, would have changed or given ine≈øtimable riches in Gold, Precious Stones and Pearles; and who had neither the skill nor the matter
wherewith at any lea≈øure, they could haue pierced our ≈øteele: to which you may adde the fla≈øhing-fire and thundring roare of≈øhotte and Harguebu≈øes; able to quell and daunt even Cae≈øar him≈øelfe, had hee beene ≈øo ≈øodainely ≈øurpri≈øed and as little experienced as they were: and thus to come vnto, and a≈ø≈øault ≈øilly-naked people, ≈øauing where the inuention of weauing of Cotton cloath was knowne and v≈øed: for the mo≈øt altogether vnarmed, except ≈øome bowes, ≈øtones, ≈øtaues and wodden bucklers: vn≈øu≈øpecting poore people, ≈øurpri≈øed vnder colour of amity and well-meaning faith, over-taken by the curio≈øity to ≈øee ≈øtrange and vnknowne things: I ≈øay, take this di≈øparity from the conquerors, and you depriue them of all the occa≈øions and cau≈øe of ≈øo many vnexpected victories. When I con≈øider that ≈øterne-vntamed ob≈øtinacy, and vndanted vehemence, wherewith ≈øo many thou≈øandes of men, of women and children, doe ≈øo infinite times pre≈øent them≈øelves vnto inevitable dangers, for the defence of their Gods and liberty: This generous ob≈øtinacie to endure all extremities, all difficulties and death, more ea≈øily and willingly, then ba≈øely to yeelde vnto their domination, of whome they haue ≈øo abhominably beene abv≈øed: ≈øome of them choo≈øing rather to ≈øtarue with hunger and fa≈øting, being taken, then to accept foode at their enemies hands, ≈øo ba≈øely victorious: I perceaue, that who≈øoeuer had vndertaken them man to man, without ods of armes, of experience or of number, ≈øhould haue had as dangerous a warre, or perhaps more, as any we ≈øee among≈øt vs.

Why did not ≈øo glorious a conque≈øt happen vnder Alexander, or during the time of the ancient Greekes and Romanes? or why befell not ≈øo great a change and alteration of Empires and people, vnder ≈øuch handes as would gently haue poli≈øhed, reformed and incivilized, what in them they deemed to be barbarous and rude: or would haue nouri≈øhed and fo≈øtered tho≈øe good ≈øeedes, which nature had there brought foorth: adding not onely to the manuring of their grounds and ornaments of their citties ≈øuch artes as wee had; and that no further then had beene nece≈ø≈øary for them, but therewithall ioy ning vnto the originall vertues of the country, tho≈øe of the ancient Grecians and Romanes? What reputation and what reformation would all that farre-≈øpredding worlde haue found, if the examples, demeanors and pollicies, wherewith wee fir≈øt pre≈øented them, had called and allured tho≈øe vncorrupted nations, to the admiration and imitation of vertue, and had e≈øtabli≈øhed betweene them and vs a brotherly ≈øociety and mutuall corre≈øpondencie? How ea≈øie a matter had it beene, profitably to reforme, and chri≈øtianly to in≈øtruct, mindes yet ≈øo pure and new, ≈øo willing to bee taught, beeing for the mo≈øt part endowed with ≈øo docile, ≈øo apt and ≈øo yeelding naturall beginnings? whereas contrarywi≈øe, wee have made v≈øe of their ignorance and inexperience, drawe them more ea≈øily vnto trea≈øon, fraude, luxurie, auarice and all manner of inhumanitie and cruelty, by the example of our life, and patterne of our cu≈øtomes. Who ever rai≈øed the ≈øeruice of marchandize and benefit of trafficke to ≈øo high a rate? So many goodly citties ran≈øacked and razed; ≈øo many nations de≈øtroyed and made de≈øolate; ≈øo infinite millions of harmele≈ø≈øe people of all ≈øexes, ≈øtates and ages, ma≈ø≈øacred, ravaged and put to the ≈øworde; and the riche≈øt, the fayre≈øt and the be≈øt part of the world top≈øituruied, ruined and defaced for the trafficke of Pearles and Pepper: Oh mecanicall victoryes, oh ba≈øe conque≈øt. Never did blinde ambition, never did greedy revenge, publike wrongs or generall enmities, ≈øo moodily enrage, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øionately incen≈øe men again≈øt men, vnto ≈øo horrible ho≈øtilities, bloody di≈ø≈øipation, and mi≈øerable calamities.

Certaine Spaniardes coa≈øting along≈øt the Sea in ≈øearch of mines, fortued to land in a very fertile, plea≈øant and well peopled country: vnto the inhabitants whereof they declared their intent, and ≈øhewed their accu≈øtomed per≈øwa≈øions; ≈øaying: That they were quiet and well meaning-men, comming from farre-countries, being ≈øent from the King of Ca≈øtile, the greate≈øt king of the habitable earth, vnto whom the Pope, repre≈øenting God on earth, had given the principalitie of all the Indies. That if they would become tributaries to him, they ≈øhould bee mo≈øt kindly v≈øed aud courteou≈øly entreated: They required of them victualles for their nouri≈øhment; and ≈øome golde for the behoofe of certaine Phy≈øicall experiments. Moreover, they declared vnto them, the beleeuing in one
onely God, and the trueth of our religion, which they per≈øwaded them to embrace, adding thereto ≈øome minatorie threates. Who≈øe an≈øwer was this: That happily they might be quiet and well-meaning, but their countenance ≈øhewed them to be otherwi≈øe: As concerning their King, ≈øince he ≈øeemed to begge, he ≈øhewed to be poore and needie: And for the Pope, who had made that di≈øtribution, he expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe a man louing di≈ø≈øention, in going about to give vnto a third man, a thing which was not his owne: ≈øo to make it que≈øtionable and litigious amongst the auncient po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of it. As for victualles, they ≈øhould haue part of their ≈øtore: And for golde, they had but little, and that it was a thing they made very ≈ømall accoumpt of, as meerely vnprofitable for the ≈øeruice of their life, whereas all their care was but how to pa≈ø≈øe it happily and plea≈øantly: and therefore, what quantity ≈øoever they ≈øhould finde, that onely excepted which was employed about the ≈øeruice of their Gods, they might bouldly take it. As touching one onely God, the di≈øcour≈øe of him had very well plea≈øed them: but they would by no meanes change their religion, vnder which they had for ≈øo long time liued ≈øo happily: and that they were not accu≈øtomed to take any coun≈øell, but of their friendes and acquaintance. As concerning their menaces, it was a ≈øigne of want of iudgement, to threaten tho≈øe, who≈øe nature, condition, power and meanes was to them vnknowne. And therefore they ≈øhould with all ≈øpeed ha≈øten to auoyd their dominions, for≈øomuch as they were wont to admit or take in good part the kindene≈ø≈øes and remon≈øtrances of armed people, namely of ≈øtrangers, otherwi≈øe they would deale with them, as they had done with ≈øuch others, ≈øhewing them the heads of certaine men ≈øticking vpon ≈øtakes about their Cittie, which had lately beene executed. Loe here an example of the ≈øtammering of this infancy.

But ≈øo it is, neither in this, nor in infinite other places, where the Spaniards found not the marchandi≈øe they ≈øought for, neither made ≈øtay or attempted any violence, what≈øoeuer other commodity the place yeelded: witne≈ø≈øe my Canibales. Of two the mo≈øt mighty and glorious Monarkes of that world, and peraduenture of all our We≈øterne partes, Kings ouer ≈øo many Kings: the la≈øt they depo≈øed and ouercame: He of Peru, hauing by them beene taken in a battell, and ≈øet at ≈øo exce≈ø≈øiue a ran≈øome, that it exceedeth all beliefe, and that truely paide: and by his conuer≈øation hauing giuen them apparant ≈øignes of a free, liberall, vndanted and con≈øtant courage, and declared to be of a pure, noble, and well compo≈øed vnder≈øtanding; a humour po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the conquerors, after they had mo≈øt in≈øolently exacted from him a Million, three hundred fiue and twenty thou≈øand, and fiue hundred waights of golde; be≈øides the ≈øiluer and other precious things, which amounted to no le≈ø≈øe a ≈øumme (≈øo that their hor≈øes were all ≈øhood of ma≈ø≈øive golde) to di≈øcouer what di≈øloyalty or treachery ≈øoever it might co≈øt them) what the remainder of this kings trea≈øure might be, and without controlment enioy what euer he might haue hidden or concealed from them. Which to compa≈ø≈øe, they forged a fal≈øe accu≈øation and proofe again≈øt him; That he practi≈øed to rai≈øe his prouinces, and intended to induce his ≈øubiects to ≈øome in≈øurrection, ≈øo to procure his liberty. Whereupon, by the very iudgement of tho≈øe who had complotted this forgery and trea≈øon again≈øt him, hee was condemned to be publikely hanged and ≈øtrangled: hauing fir≈øt made him to redeeme the torment of being burned aliue, by the bapti≈øme which at the in≈øtant of his execution in charity they be≈øtowed vpon him. A horrible and the like neuer heard of accident: which neverthele≈ø≈øe he vndi≈ømayedly endured with an vnmooued manner, and truly-royall grauity, without euer contradicting him≈øelfe eyther in countenance or ≈øpeech. And then, ≈øomewhat to mittigate and circumvent tho≈øe ≈øilly vn≈øu≈øpecting people amazed and a≈øtoni≈øhed at ≈øo ≈øtrange a ≈øpectacle, they counterfetted a great mourning and lamentation for his death and appointed his funeralls to be ≈øolemnly and ≈øumptuou≈øly celebrated.

The other King of Mexico, having a long time manfully defended his be≈øieged Citie, and in that tedious ≈øiege, ≈øhewed what ever pinching-≈øufferance and re≈øolute-per≈øeverance can effect, if ever any courageous Prince or warre-like people ≈øhewed the ≈øame; and his di≈øa≈øtrous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe having delivered him alive into his enemies hands, vpon conditions to bee v≈øed as be≈øeemed a King: who during the time of his impri≈øoment, did neuer make the lea≈øt ≈øhew of any thing vnworthy that glorious title. After which victory, the Spaniards not finding that quantitie of gold, they had promi≈øed them≈øelves, when they had ran≈øacked and ranged all corners, they by meanes of the crue ‚Ä¢ le≈øt tortures and horrible≈øt torments they could po≈ø≈øibly deui≈øe, beganne to wre≈øt and draw ≈øome more from ≈øuch pri≈øoners as they had in keeping. But vnable to profit any thing that waye, finding ≈øtronger hearts then their torments, they in the end fell to ≈øuch moody
outrages, that contrary to all law of nations, and again≈øt their ≈øolemne vowes and promi≈øes, they condemned the King him≈øelfe and one of the chiefe≈øt Princes of his Court, to the Racke, one in pre≈øence of another: The Prince, environed round with hot burning coales, being ouercome with the exceeding torment, at la≈øt in mo≈øt pittious ≈øort turning his dreary eyes toward his Ma≈øter, as if hee asked mercy of him for that hee could endure no longer‚ñ™ The king fixing rigorou≈øly and fiercely his lookes vpon him, ≈øeeming to vpbraide him with his remi≈øne≈ø≈øe and pu≈øilanimity, with a ≈øterne and ≈øetled voyce vttered the≈øe few wordes vnto him; What? ≈øuppo≈øe≈øt thou I am in a colde bath? am I at more ea≈øe then thou art? Where at the ≈øilly wretch immediately fainted vnder the torture, and yeelded vp the gho≈øt. The king halfe ro≈øted, was carryed away: Not ≈øo much for pitty (for what ruth could euer enter ≈øo barbarous mindes, who vpon the ≈øurmi≈øed information of ≈øome odde peece or ve≈ø≈øell of golde, they intended to get, would broyle a man before their eyes, and not a man onely, but a king, ≈øo great in fortune and ≈øo renouned in de≈øert?) but for≈øomuch as his vnmatched con≈øtancie did more and more make their inhumane cruelty a≈øhamed: They afterward hanged him, becau≈øe he had couragiou≈øly attempted by armes to deliuer him≈øelfe out of ≈øo long captiuity and mi≈øerable ≈øubiection; where he end ed his wretched life, worthy an high minded and neuer danted Prince. At another time, in one ≈øame fire, they cau≈øed to be burned all aliue foure hundred common men, and three ≈øcore principall Lordes of a prouince, whom by the fortune of warre they had taken pri≈øoners. The≈øe narrations we have out of their owne bookes: for they doe not onely auouche, but vauntingly publi≈øh them. May it be, they doe it for a te≈øtimony of their iu≈øtice or zeale toward their religion? verily they are wayes ouerdifferent and enemies to ≈øo ≈øacred an ende. Had they propo≈øed vnto them≈øelues to enlarge and propagate our religion, they would haue con≈øidered, that it is not amplified by po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of landes, but of men: and would have beene ≈øatisfied with ≈øuch ≈ølaughters, as the nece≈ø≈øity of warre bringeth, without indifferently adding therevnto ≈øo bloody a butchery, as vpon ≈øavage bea≈øtes; and ≈øo vniver≈øall as fire or ≈øword could ever attaine vnto; having purpo≈øely pre≈øerued no more then ≈øo many mi≈øerable bond ≈ølaues, as they deemed might ≈øuffice for the digging, working and ≈øeruice of their mines: So that diuers of their chieftaines have beene executed to death, even in the places they had conquered, by the appointment of the Kings of Castile, iu≈øtly offended at the ≈øeld-≈øeene horror of their barbarous demeanours, and well nigh all di≈øe≈øteemed, contemned and hated. God hath meritoriou≈øly permitted, that many of their great pillages, and ill gotten goods, have eyther beene ≈øwallowed vp by the revenging Seas in tran≈øporting them, or con≈øumed by the inte≈øtine warres and ciuill broyles, wherewith them≈øelues have devoured one another; and the greate≈øt part of them have beene ouer-whelmed and buryed in the bowels of the earth, in the very places they found them, without any fruite of their victory. Touching the obiection which ≈øome make, that the receipte, namely in the handes of ≈øo thrifty, wary and wi≈øe a Prince, doth ≈øo little an≈øwer the fore-conceaved hope, which was given vnto his predece≈ø≈øors and the ≈øaid former aboundance of riches, they mette withall at the fir≈øt di≈øcovery of this new-found world, (for although they bring home great quantitye of gold and ≈øiluer, we perceiue the ≈øame to be nothing, in re≈øpect of what might bee expected thence) it may bee an≈øwered, that the v≈øe of mony was there altogether vnknowne; and con≈øequently, that all their golde was gathered together, ≈øeruing to no other purpo≈øe, then for ≈øhew, ≈øtate and ornament, as a mooveable re≈øerued from father to ≈øonne by many pui≈ø≈øant Kings, who exhau≈øted all their mines; to collect ≈øo huge a heape of ve≈ø≈øels and ≈øtatues for the ornament of their Temples, and embelli≈øhing of their Pallaces: whereas all our golde employed in commerce and trafficke betweene man and man. Wee mince and alter it into a thou≈øand formes: wee ≈øpend, wee ≈øcatter and di≈øperce the ≈øame to ≈øeverall v≈øes. Suppo≈øe our Kings ≈øhould thus gather and heape vp all the golde they might for many ages hoarde vp together, and keepe it clo≈øe and vntouch't. Tho≈øe of the kingdome of Mexico were ≈øomewhat more encivilized, and better arti≈øtes, then other nations of that worlde. And as wee doe, ≈øo judged they, that this Vniuers was neare his end: and tooke the de≈øolation wee brought among≈øt them as an infallible ≈øigne of it. They beleeued the ≈øtate of the worlde, to bee divided into fiue ages, and in the life of fiue ≈øucceeding Sunnes, whereof foure had already ended their cour≈øe or time; and the ≈øame which now ≈øhined vpon them, was the fifth and la≈øt. The fir≈øt peri≈øhed together with all other creatures, by an vniver≈øall inundation of waters. The
≈øecond by the fall of the heavens vpon vs which ≈øtifled and ouerwhelmed euery living thing: in which age they affirme the Giants to haue beene, and ≈øhewed the Spaniards certaine bones of them, according to who≈øe proportion the ≈øtature of men came to bee of the height of twenty handfuls. The third, was con≈øumed by a violent fire, which burned and de≈øtroyed all. The fourth by a whirling emotion of the ayre and windes, which with the violent fury of it ≈øelfe, remooued and ouerthrew diuers high mountaines: ≈øaying, that men dyed not of it, but were tran≈øformed into Munkeis. (Oh what impre≈ø≈øions doth not the weakene≈ø≈øe of mans beliefe admit?) After the con≈øummation of this fourth Sunne, the world continued fiue and twenty yeares in perpetuall darkene≈ø≈øe: in the fifteenth of which one man and one woman were created, who renewed the race of man-kinde. Ten yeares after, vpon a certaine day, the Sunne appeared as newly created: from which day beginneth euer ≈øince the calculation of their yeares. On the third day of who≈øe creation, died their ancient Gods, their new ones haue day by day beene borne ≈øince. In what manner this la≈øt Sunne ≈øhall peri≈øh, my aucthor could not learne of them. But their number of this fourth change, doth iumpe and meete with that great coniunction of the Starres, which eight hundred and odde yeares ≈øince, according to the A≈øtrologians ≈øuppo≈øition, produced diuers great alterations and ≈øtrange novelties in the world. Concerning the proud pompe and glorious magnificence, by occa≈øion of which I am fallen into this di≈øcour≈øe, nor Greece, nor Rome, nor Aegipt, can (bee it in profit, or difficultie or nobility) equall or compare ≈øundrie and diuers of their workes. The cawcy or high-way which is yet to bee ≈øeene in Peru, errected by the Kings of that countrie, ≈øtretching from the citty of Quito, vnto that of Cu≈øco (containing three hundred leagues in length) ≈øtraight, euen, and fine, and twentie paces in breadth, curiou≈øly paved, ray≈øed on both ≈øides with goodly, high ma≈øonrie-walles, all along which, on the inner ≈øide there are two continuall running ≈øtreames, plea≈øantly be≈øet with beautious trees, which they call Moly. In framing of which, where they mette any mountaines or rockes, they haue cut, rai≈øed and leuelled them, and filled all hollow places with lime and ≈øtone. At the ende of euery dayes journey, as ≈øtations, there are built ≈øtately great pallaces, plentiou≈øly ≈øtored with all manner of good victuals, apparrell and armes, as well for daylie way-fairing men, as for ≈øuch armies that might happen to pa≈ø≈øe that way. In the e≈øtimation of which worke I haue e≈øpecially con≈øidered the difficulty, which in that place is particvlarly to bee remembred. For they built with no ≈øtones that were le≈ø≈øe then ten foote ≈øquare: They had no other meanes to cary or tran≈øport them, then by meere ≈øtrength of armes to draw and dragge the carriage they needed: they had not ≈øo much as the arte to make ≈øcaffolds; nor knew other deui≈øe, then to rai≈øe ≈øo much earth or rubi≈øh, again≈øt their building, according as the worke ri≈øeth, and afterwarde to take it a way againe. But returne we to our coaches. In ≈øteade of them, and of all other carrying bea≈øtes they cau≈øed them≈øelues to be carryed by men, and vpon their ≈øhoulders. This la≈øt King of Peru, the ≈øame day hee was taken, was thus carried vpon rafters or beames of ma≈ø≈øiue Golde, ≈øitting in a faire chaire of ≈øtate, likewi≈øe all of golde, in the middle of his battaile. Looke how may of his porters as were ≈ølaine, to make him fall (for all their endeuour was to take him aliue) ≈øo many others, and as it were auye, tooke and vnder-went pre≈øently the place of the dead: ≈øo that he could never be brought down or made to fall, what ≈ølaughter ≈øo ever was made of tho≈øe kinde of people, vntill ≈øuch time as a hor≈øeman furiou≈øly ranne to take him by ≈øome parte of his body, and ≈øo pulled him to the ground.

SInce we cannot attaine vnto it, let vs revenge our ≈øelues with railing again≈øt it: yet is is not ab≈øolute railing, to finde faulte with any thing: There are defects found in all
things, how faire ≈øoever in ≈øhow, and de≈øirable they be. It hath generally this evident aduantage, that when ever it plea≈øeth it will decline, and hath well-nigh the choi≈øe of one and other condition. For a man doth not fall from all heights; divers there are, whence a man may de≈øcend without falling. Verily, mee ≈øeemeth, that we value it at too high a rate: and prize over-deare the re≈øolution of tho≈øe, whom we have either ≈øeene or heard, to have contemned, or of their owne motion rejected the ≈øame. Hir e≈ø≈øence is not ≈øo evidently commodious, but a man may refu≈øe it without wonder. Indeed I finde the labour very hard in ≈øuffering of evils; but in the contentment of a meane mea≈øure of fortune, and ≈øhunning of greatne≈ø≈øe, therein I ≈øee no great difficulty. In my conceit, it is a vertue, wherevnto my ≈øelfe, who am but a ≈øimple n ‚Ä¢ nny, might ea≈øily attaine, and without great contention. What ≈øhall they doe, who would al≈øo bring into con≈øideration, the glory, which accompanieth this refu≈øall, wherein may fall more ambition, then even in the de≈øire and ab≈øolute enioying of greatne≈ø≈øe? For ≈øomuch as ambition is never better directed according to it ≈øelfe, then by a ≈øtraying and vnfrequented path. I ≈øharpen my courage toward patience, and weaken the ≈øame again≈øt de≈øire. I have as much to wi≈øh for as another, and leave my wi≈øhes as much liberty and indi≈øcretion: but yet, it never came into my minde, to wi≈øh for Empire, for royalty or eminency of high and commanding fortunes. I aime not that way: I love my ≈øelfe too well. When I thinke to grow, it is but meanely; with a forced and coward aduancement; fit for me: yea in re≈øolution, in wi≈øedome, in health, in beauty and al≈øo in riches. But this credite, this a≈øpiring reputation, this over≈øwaying authority, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øeth my imagination. And cleane oppo≈øite to ≈øome other, I ≈øhould peradventure loue my ≈øelfe better, to be the ≈øecond or third man in Perigot, then the fir≈øt in Paris: At lea≈øt, without faining, I had rather be the third man in Paris, then the fir≈øt in charge. I will neither contend with an V≈øher of a doore, as a ≈øilly vnknowen man; nor with gaping and adoration make a Lane through the throng as I pa≈ø≈øe. I am enured to a meane calling; mediocrity be≈øt fitteth me, as well by my fortune, as by mine owne humor. And have ≈øhewed by the conduct of my life and cour≈øe of my enterpri≈øes, that I have rather ≈øought to avoid, then otherwi≈øe to embrace beyond the degree of fortune that at my birth it plea≈øed God to call me vnto. Each naturall con≈øtitution, is equally iu≈øt and ea≈øie. My minde is ≈øo dull and ≈ølowe, that I mea≈øure not good fortune according to her height, but rather according to her facility. And if my hart be not great enough, it is ratably free and open, and who biddeth me, bouldly to publi≈øh my weakne≈ø≈øe. Should any will me, on the one part, to conferre and con≈øider the life of L. Thorius Balbus, a worthy gallant man, wi≈øe, faire, goodly, healthie, of good vnder≈øtanding, richly-plentious in all maner of commodities and plea≈øures, leading a quiet ea≈øefull life, altogether his owne, with a minde armed, and well prepared again≈øt death, ≈øuper≈øtition, griefes, cares and other encombrances of humane nece≈ø≈øity; dying in his olde age, in an honourable battell, with his weapons in his hand, for the defence of his country; and on the other ≈øide the life of M. Rugulus, ≈øo high and great, as all men know, together with his admirable and glorious ende: the one vnmentioned and without dignity, the other exemplare and wonderfull renouned: truely I would ≈øay what Cicero ≈øaith of it, had I the gift of well-≈øpeaking as hee had. But if I were to ≈øute them vnto mine, I would al≈øo ≈øay, that the former is a≈ømuch agreeing to my quality, and to the de≈øire I endeuour to conforme my quality vnto, as the ≈øecond is farre beyond it. That to this I cannot attaine but by veneration; and to the other I would willingly attaine by cu≈øtome. But returne we to our temporall greatne≈ø≈øe, whence we have digre≈ø≈øed. I am di≈øta≈øted of all ma≈øtry, both actiue and pa≈ø≈øiue. Otanes one of the ≈øeaven that by right might chalenge the crowne, or pretend the kingdome of Per≈øia, re≈øolved vpon ≈øuch a re≈øolution as I ≈øhould ea≈øily have done the like: which was, that he vtterly renounced all maner of claime he might in any ≈øort pretend vnto that crowne, to his fellow competitores, were it either by election or chance: alwaies provided that both him≈øelfe and all his, might liue in that Empire, free from all ≈øubjections, and exempted from all maner of commandement, except that of the ancient lawes: and might both chalenge all liberty, and enioy all immunities, that ≈øhould not preiudice them: being as impacient to command, as to becommanded. The ≈øharpe≈øt and most aificile profe≈ø≈øion of the world, is (in mine opinion) worthily to act and play the King. I excu≈øe more of their faults, then commonly other men doe: and that in con≈øideration of the downe-bearing waight of their immen≈øe charge, which much a≈øtoni≈øheth me: It is a very hard task to keep a aue mea≈øure, in ≈øo vnmea≈øurable a power. Yet is it, that euen with tho≈øe, that are of a le≈ø≈øe excellent
nature, it is a ≈øingular incitation to vertue, to be ≈øeated in ≈øuch a place, where you ≈øhall doe no manner of good, that is not regi≈øtred and recorded: And where the lea≈øt well-dooing, extendeth to ≈øo many per≈øons: And where your ≈øufficiencie (as that of Preachers) is principally directed to the people; a weake and parciall iudge, ea≈øilie to be beguiled, and ea≈øie to bee plea≈øed There are but few things, of which we may giue a ≈øincere iudgement: for there bee very few, wherein in ≈øome ≈øort or other, we are not particularly intere≈ø≈øed. Superioritie and inferioritie, mai≈øtrie and ≈øubiection, are joyntly tied vnto a naturall kinde of enuie and conte≈øtation; they mu≈øt perpetually enter-≈øpoile one another. I beleeue neither the one nor the other, concerning hir companions rights: let vs ≈øuffer rea≈øon to ≈øpeake of it, which is inflexible and impa≈ø≈øible, when or how wee ≈øhall make an end. I was not long ≈øince reading of two Scotti≈øh bookes ≈øtriuing vpon this ≈øubiect. The popular makes the King to bee of wor≈øe condition then a Carter: and hee that extolleth Monarchie, placeth him both in power and ≈øoueraignty, many ≈øteps aboue the Gods. Now the incommoditie of greatne≈ø≈øe, which heere I have vndertaken to note and ≈øpeake of, (vpon ≈øome occa≈øion lately befalne mee) is this. There is peraduenture nothing more plea≈øing to the commerce of men, then the E≈ø≈øayes, which wee through iealou≈øie of honour or valour, make one again≈øt another, bee it in the exerci≈øe of the body or of the minde: wherein ≈øoueraigne greatne≈ø≈øe, hath no true or e≈ø≈øentiall part. Verily, it hath often ≈øeemed vnto mee, that through over much re≈øpect, Princes are therein v≈øed di≈ødainefully and treated iniuriou≈øhe: For, the thing whereat (in my youth) I was infinitely offended, was, that tho≈øe which were trained and ≈øchooled with mee, ≈øhould for beare to doe it in good earne≈øt, becau≈øe they found mee vnworthy to bee with≈øtood or to re≈øi≈øt their endeuours. It is that wee dayly ≈øee to happen vnto them; euery man finding him≈øelfe vnworthy to force him≈øelfe again≈øt them. If one perceive them never ≈øo little affected to have the victorie, there is none but will ≈øtriue to yeelde it them, and that will not rather wrong his glory, then offend theirs: No man imployeth more diligence then needes hee mu≈øt to ≈øerue their honour. What ≈øhare haue Princes in the throng, where all are for them? Mee thinkes I ≈øee tho≈øe Paladines of former ages, pre≈øenting them≈øelues in iou≈øtes, tiltings and combates, with bodies and armes enchanted. Bri≈ø≈øon running again≈øt Alexander, counterfetted his cour≈øe: Alexander chid him for it: but hee ≈øhould haue cau≈øed him to bee whipt. For this con≈øideration, was Carneades wont to ≈øay, that Prince children learn't nothing aright but to mannage and ride hor≈øes; for ≈øomuch as in all other exerci≈øes, euery manyeeldeth, and giueth them the victory: but a hor≈øe who is neither a flatterer nor a Courtier, will as ≈øoone throw the childe of a king as the ≈øonne of a ba≈øe porter. Homer hath beene forced to con≈øent that Venus (≈øo ≈øweete a ≈øaint and delicate a Godde≈ø≈øe) ≈øhould be hurt at the ≈øiege of Troy, thereby to a≈øcribe courage and hardine≈ø≈øe vnto her qualities neuer ≈øeene in tho≈øe that are exempted from danger. The Gods them≈øelues are fained to bee angry, to feare, to bee jealous, to greeue, to ≈øhew pa≈ø≈øion, and bee ≈øubiect to mortall ≈øence, thereby to honour them with the vertues which Poets deui≈øe and Philo≈øophers inuent among≈øt vs: Nay, they are ≈øuppo≈øed to runne away‚ñ™ and to haue a feeling of all our imperfections. Who doth not participate both hazard and difficulties, cannot iu≈øtly pretend intere≈øt in the honour, or challenge ≈øhare in the plea≈øure, that followeth dangerous actions or hazardous attemps. It is pitty a man ≈øhould bee ≈øo powerfull, that all things mu≈øt yeeld and giue place vnto him. Such as are in ≈øo high eminencie of greatne≈ø≈øe, their fortune reiects ≈øociety and conuer≈øation too farre from them; ≈øhee placeth them in over remote and vncouth places. This ea≈øefull life and plau≈øible facilitie to bring all vnder, and ≈øubiect mens mindes, is an enemy to all manner of plea≈øure. It is a kinde of ≈øliding‚ñ™ and not a going‚ñ™ It is to ≈øleepe, and not to liue. Conceaue man accompanied with omnipotencie, you ouerwhelme him: hee mu≈øt in begging manner craue ≈øome empeachment and re≈øi≈øtance of you. His beeing and his good, is in want and indigence. Their good qualities are dead and lo≈øt: for, they are not heard but by compari≈øon, and they are excluded: they haue little knowledge of true prai≈øe, beeing beaten with ≈øo continuall and vniforme an approbation. Have they to doe with the ≈øimple≈øt of their ≈øubiects? thy haue no meane to take aduantage of him, if hee but ≈øay; It is becau≈øe hee is my King, hee ≈øuppo≈øeth to haue ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed, and you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that in ≈øo ≈øaying, hee hath lent a helping hand to ouerthrow him≈øelfe. This qualitie ≈øuppre≈ø≈øeth and con≈øumeth all other true and e≈ø≈øentiall qualities: they are euen drowned in the Royaltie; which gives them no leave, to make the offices of their charge to preuaile, except in ≈øuch actions as directly concerne and ≈øtead the ≈øame. To be a King, is a matter of that con≈øequence,
that onely by it he is ≈øo. That ≈øtrange glimmering and eye-dazeling light, which round about enuironeth, overca≈øteth and hideth him from vs: our weake ≈øight is thereby bleared and di≈ø≈øipated, as being filled and ob≈øcured by that greater and further-≈øpredding brightnes. The Senate allotted the honor and pri≈øe of eloquence vnto Tiberius; he refu≈øed it, ≈øuppo≈øing that if it had beene true, he could not revenge him≈øelfe of ≈øo limited and partiall iudgement. As we yeeld Princes all aduantages of honor, ≈øo we aucthorize their defects and ≈øooth-vp their vices: not onely by approbation, but al≈øo by imitation. All Alexanders followers bare their heads ≈øideling, as he did. And ≈øuch as flattered Diony≈øius, in his owne pre≈øence did run and iu≈øtle one another, and either ≈øtumbled at, or over-threw what euer ≈øtood before their feete, to inferre; that they were as ≈øhort-≈øighted or ≈øpur-blinde, as hee was. Naturall imperfections haue ≈øometimes ≈øerued for commendation and fauour. Nay I haue ≈øeene deafne≈øle affected. And becau≈øe the mai≈øter hated his wife, Plutarch hath ≈øeen courtiers to ≈øue a diuorce of theirs, whom they loued very well. And which is more paillardi≈øe and all maner of di≈ø≈øolution hath thereby beene held in credit; as al≈øo di≈øloyaltie, bla≈øphemy, cruelty, here≈øie, ≈øuper≈øtition, irreligion, wantonne≈ø≈øe and wor≈øe, if wor≈øe may be. Yea by an example more dangerous, then that of Mithridates his flatterers, who for≈øomuch as their mai≈øter pretended to haue skill in phi≈øicke, and a≈øpired to the honour of a good Phy≈øition, came to him to haue their members incized and cauterized. For, the≈øe others ≈øuffer to haue their ≈øoules cauterized; a much more precious and nobler part then the body. But to end where I began: Adrian the Emperor debating with Fauorinus the Philo≈øopher about the interpretation of ≈øome word; Fauorinus did ≈øoone yeeld the victory vnto him, his friends finding fault with him for it; you but je≈øt, my mai≈øters (quoth hee) would you not haue him to bee much wi≈øer then I, who hath the ab≈øolute command ouer thirty legions? Augu≈øtus writ ≈øome ver≈øes again≈øt A≈øinius Pollio, which Pollio hearing, he ≈øaid, I will hould my peace; for, it is no wi≈øedome to contend in writing with him, who may pro≈øcribe. And they had rea≈øon: For, Diony≈øius, becau≈øe he could not equall Philoxenus in Poe≈øie, nor match Plato in di≈øcour≈øe, condemned the one to the ≈øtone-quaries, and ≈øent the other to be ≈øould as a ≈ølave in the Ile of Aegina.

div.p: IT is a cu≈øtome of our law, to condemne ≈øome, for the warning of others. To condemne them becau≈øe they haue mi≈ødone, were folly, as ≈øaith Plato. For what is once done can neuer be vndone: but they are condemned to the end that they ≈øhould not offend againe, or that others may avoide the example of their offence. Hee who is hanged is not corrected, but others by him. Even ≈øo doe I. My errors are ≈øometimes naturall, incorrigible and remedile≈ø≈øe. But whereas hone≈øt men profit the Common-wealth in cau≈øing them≈øelues to be imitated. I ≈øhall happily benefit the ≈øame, in making my ≈øelfe to be evitated.

div.p:
By publi≈øhing and accu≈øing my imperfections, ≈øome man may peraduenture learne to feare them. The partes I mo≈øt e≈øteeme in my ≈øelfe, reape more honour by accu≈øing, then by commending my ≈øelfe. And that's the cau≈øe I more often fall into them againe, and re≈øt vpon them. But when all the cardes bee told, a man neuer ≈øpeakes of him≈øelfe, without lo≈ø≈øe. A mans own
condemnations are ever increa≈øed: prai≈øes ever decrea≈øed. There may be ≈øome of my complexion, who am better in≈øtructed by contrariety then by ≈øimilitude; and more by e≈øcaping then by following. Cato ≈øenior had a ≈øpeciall regard to this kind of di≈øcipline, when he ≈øaid, that wi≈øemen have more to learne of fooles, then fooles of wi≈øemen. And that ancient player on the Lyra, whom Pau≈øantas reporteth, to haue beene accu≈øtomed to compell his ≈øchollers ≈øometimes to goe heare a bad Player, who dwelt right over-again≈øt him; where they might learne to hate his di≈øcordes and fal≈øe mea≈øures. The horror of cruelty drawes me neerer vnto clemency, then any patterne of clemencie can po≈ø≈øibly win mee. A cunning rider or skilfull hor≈øeman doth not ≈øo properly teach mee, to ≈øit well on hor≈øe-backe, as doth one of our Lawyers, or a Venetian by ≈øeeing him ride. And an ill manner of ≈øpeech doth better reforme mine, then any well-poli≈øhed forme of ≈øpeaking. The ≈øotti≈øh countenance of another, doth dayly adverti≈øe and forewarne me. That which pricketh, toucheth and rouzeth better, then that which delighteth. The≈øe times are fit to reforme vs backward, more by di≈ø≈øenting, then by con≈øenting; more by difference then by accord. Being but little in≈øtructed by good examples, I make v≈øe of bad: the le≈ø≈øon of which is ordinary. I haue endeuoured, nay I have laboured to yeeld my ≈øelfe as plea≈øing and affable, as I ≈øaw others peevi≈øh and froward: as con≈øtant, as I ≈øaw others variable; as gentle and milde, as I perceived others intractable and wild: and as good and hone≈øt, as I di≈øcerned others wicked and di≈øhone≈øt. But I propo≈øed certaine invincible mea≈øures vnto my ≈øelfe. The mo≈øt fruitful and natural exerci≈øe of our ≈øpirit, is, in my ≈øelfe-plea ‚Ä¢ ing conceit, conference. The v≈øe whereof, I finde to bee more delight≈øome, then any other action of our life: And that's the rea≈øon, why, if I were now forced to choo≈øe, (being in the minde I now am in) I would rather yeeld to loo≈øe my ≈øight, then fogoe my hearing or my ≈øpeech. The Athenians and al≈øo the Romans, did ever hold this exerci≈øe in high honor and reputation, namely in their Academies. And at this day, the Italians doe yet keepe a kinde of forme and trace of it, to their great profit, as may apparantly bee di≈øcerned by comparing their wits vnto ours. The ≈øtudy and plodding on bookes, is a langui≈øhing and weake kinde of motion, and which heateth or earne≈øteth nothing; whereas conference doth both learne, teach and exerci≈øe at once. If I confer ‚Ä¢ e with a ≈øtubborne wit, and encounter a ≈øturdy wre≈øtler, he toucheth me to the quicke, hits me on the flanks, and pricks me both on the left and right ≈øide: his imaginations vanqui≈øh and confound mine. Ielou≈øie, glory and contention, driue, ca≈øt and rai≈øe me aboue my ≈øelfe. And an vni≈øon or con≈øent, is a qualitie altogether tedious and weari≈øome in conference. But as our minde is fortified by the communication of regular and vigorous ≈øpirits; it cannot well be expre≈ø≈øed, how much it loo≈øeth and is ba≈øtardized, by the continuall commerce and frequentation, we have with ba≈øe, weake and dull ≈øpirits. No contagion ≈øpreds it ≈øelfe further then that. I know by long experience what an ell of it is worth. I love to conte≈øt and di≈øcour≈øe, but not with many, and only for my ≈øelfe. For, to ≈øerue as a ≈øpectacle vnto great men, and by way of contention‚ñ™ for one to make a glorious ≈øhew of his ready wit and running tongue; I deeme it a profe≈ø≈øion farre vnfitting a man of honor. Sotti≈øhnes is an ill quality, but not to be able to endure it, and to fret and vex at it, as it hapneth to me, is another kinde of imperfection, which in opportunity is not much behinde ≈øotti≈øhnes: and that's it I will now accu≈øe in my ≈øelfe: I doe with great liberty and facilitie, enter into conference and di≈øputation: for≈øomuch as opinion findes but a hard ≈øoile to enter and take any deepe roote in me. No propo≈øitions amaze me, no conceit woundeth me, what contrarietie ≈øoever they have to mine. There is no fantazie ≈øo frivolous or humour ≈øo extravagant, that in mine opinion is not ≈øortable to the production, of humane wit. We others, who debarre our judgement of the right to make conclu≈øions, regard but negligently the diuer≈øe opinions: and if wee lend it not our judgement, wee ea≈øily affoord it our eares. Where one ≈øcale of the ballance is altogether empty. I let the other waver too and fro, vnder an old wiues dreames. And me ≈øeemeth, I may well be excu≈øed, if I rather accept an odde number, then an even: Thur≈øday in re≈øpect of Friday, if I had rather make a twelfth or fourteenth at a table, then a thirteenth: if when I am trauelling I would rather ≈øee a Hare coa≈øting, then cro≈ø≈øing my way: and rather reach my left, then my right foote, to be ≈øhod. All ≈øuch fond conceits, now in credit about vs, de≈øerue at fea≈øt to be li≈øtned vnto. As for me, they only beare away inanity, and ≈øurely they do ≈øo. Vulgar and ca≈øuall opinions are yet of ≈øome waight, which in nature are ≈øomthing els then nothing. And who wadeth not ≈øo far into them, to auoide the vice of ≈øuper≈øtition, falleth happily into the blame of wilfulne≈ø≈øe. The contradictions then of judgements,
doe neither offend nor moove, but awaken and exerci≈øe me. Wee commonly ≈øhunne correction whereas we ≈øhould rather ≈øeeke and pre≈øent our ≈øelves vnto it, chiefly when it commeth by the way of conference, and not of regency. At every oppo≈øition, wee con≈øider not whether it be iu≈øt; but be it right or wrong, how we may avoide it: In ≈øteede of reaching our armes, we ≈øtretch forth our clawes vnto it. I ≈øhould endure to be rudely handled and checked by my friends, though they ≈øhould call me foole, coxcombe or ≈øay I raved. I love a man that doth ≈øtoutly expre≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe, among≈øt hone≈øt and worthy men and who≈øe wordes an≈øwer his thoughts. We ≈øhould fortifie and harden our hearing, again≈øt the tenderne≈ø≈øe of the cerimonious ≈øound of wordes. I love a friendly ≈øociety and a virile and con≈øtant familiarity: An amitie, which in the earne≈øtne≈ø≈øe and vigor of it's commerce, flattereth it ≈øelfe: as love in bitings and bloody ≈øcratchings. It is not ≈øufficiently generous or vigorous, except it bee contentious and quarelous: If ≈øhe be civili≈øed and a skilfull arti≈øte: if it feare a ≈øhocke or free encounter, and have hir ≈øtarting hoales or forced by-wayes. Neque enim di≈øputari ≈øine repreher≈øione pote≈øt. Di≈øputation cannot be held without reprehen≈øion. When I am impugned or contraried, then is mine attention and not mine anger, ≈øtirred vp; I advance my ≈øelfe toward him, that doth gaine≈øay and in≈øtruct me. The cau≈øe of truth, ought to be the common cau≈øe, both to one and other: What can he an≈øwer? The pa≈ø≈øion of choller hath already wounded his iudgement: trouble, before rea≈øon hath ≈øeazed vpon it. It were both profitable and nece≈ø≈øary, that the determining of our di≈øputations, might be decided by way of wagers; and that there were a materiall marke of our lo≈ø≈øes: that we might better remember and make more accoumpt of it: and that my boy might ≈øay vnto me: Sir, if you call to minde; your conte≈øtation, your ignorance and your ≈øelfe-wilfulne≈ø≈øe, at ≈øeverall times, co≈øt you a hundred crownes the la≈øt yeare: I fea≈øt, I cherri≈øh and I embrace truth, where and in whom ≈øoever I finde it, and willingly and merily yeeld my ≈øelfe vnto hir; as ≈øoone as I ≈øee but hir approach, though it bee a farre-off, I lay downe my weapons and yeeld my ≈øelfe vanqui≈øhed. And alwayes provided, one per≈øi≈øt not or proceede therein, with an over imperious ≈øtiffne≈ø≈øe or commanding ≈øurline≈ø≈øe; I am well plea≈øed to be reprooved. And I often accomodate my ≈øelfe vnto my accu≈øers, more by rea≈øon of civilitie, then by occa≈øion of amendment: loving by the facilitie of yeelding, to gratifie and fo≈øter their liberty, to teach or adverti≈øe mee. It is notwith≈øtanding no ea≈øie matter to draw men of my times vnto it. They have not the courage to correct, becau≈øe they want the hart to endure correction: And ever ≈øpeake with di≈ø≈øimulation in pre≈øence one of another. If by ≈øo good markes and tokens, I had ever knowen or heard of any one man, that in this humour had beene an≈øwerable to mee, I would a≈ø≈øuredly have wandred very farre to finde him out: For, the exceeding joy of a ≈øortable and in one con≈øent agreeing company, cannot (in mine opinion) be ≈øufficiently endeared or purcha≈øed at too high a rate. But to returne to my former di≈øcour≈øe: There is then no great inconvenience in dying farre from home and abroad. To whom at la≈øt, proove they not them≈øelves tedious and intolerable? Common offices proceed not ≈øo farre. Perforce you teach crueltie vnto your be≈øt friends; obdurating by long v≈øe, both wife and children, not to feele, nor to conceive, nor to moane your evils any longer. The more I ≈øhould ≈øee them with a good heart to ≈øtraine them≈øelves for me, the more ≈øhould I bewaile their paine. The law of curte≈øie alloweth vs to leane vpon others, but not ≈øo vnmanerly to lie vpon them and vnderpropt our ≈øelves in their ruine. As hee who cau≈øed little infants to be ≈ølaine, that with their innocent blood he might be cured of a malady he had. I am ≈øociable even vnto exce≈ø≈øe, yet doe I thinke it rea≈øonable, at la≈øt to ≈øub≈øtract my opportunity from the ≈øight of the world, and hatch it in my ≈øelfe. But heere will ≈øome≈øay, that in the≈øefarre journies you may peradventure fall into ≈øome mi≈øerable dog-hole or poore cottage, where you ≈øhall want all needfull things. At the very beginning of my agues or ≈øickene≈ø≈øes that ca≈øt me downe, whil≈øt I am yet whole in my ≈øen≈øes and neere vnto health, I reconcile my ≈øelfe to God by the la≈øt duties of a Chri≈øtian; whereby I finde my ≈øelfe free and di≈øcharged; and thinke I have ≈øo much more rea≈øon and authoritie over my ≈øickene≈ø≈øe, I finde le≈ø≈øe want of Notaries and coun≈øell, then of Phy≈øitions. And if nothing be done, it is as much to ≈øay, that either ≈øome doubt hath delaide the choi≈øe: For, ≈øometimes it is a good choi≈øe, not to chu≈øe at all: Or that ab≈øolutely I never intended to doe any thing. div.p:
I leave nothing to bee de≈øired or divined of mee. If one mu≈øt entertaine him≈øelfe with them, I would have it to be truely and ju≈øtly. I would willingly come from the other world, to give him the lie, that ≈øhould frame me other then I had beene: were it he meant to honour mee. I ≈øee that of the living, men never ≈øpeake according to truth; and they are ever made to
he, what they are not. And if with might and maine, I had not vpheld a friend of mine whom I have lately lo≈øt, he had ≈øurely been mangled and torne in a thou≈øand contrrary ≈øhapes. I ≈øeeke to flatter death by the≈øe frivolous circum≈øtances: Or as I may rather ≈øay, to di≈øcharge my ≈øelfe from all other trouble or encombrance; that ≈øo I may wholly apply and attend her, who without that ≈øhall happily lie very heavy vpon me. I will have her take a full ≈øhare of my lives ea≈øes and commodities; it is a great part of it and of much con≈øequence, and I hope it ≈øhall not belie what is pa≈øt. Death hath ≈øome formes more ea≈øie then others, and a≈ø≈øumeth divers qualities; according to all mens fantazies. Among the naturall ones, that proceeding of weakene≈ø≈øe and heavy dulne≈ø≈øe, to me ≈øeemeth gentle and plea≈øant. Among the violent I imagine a precipice more hardly, then a ruine that overwhelmes me: and a cutting blow with a ≈øword, then a ≈øhot of an harquebu≈øe: and I would rather have cho≈øen to drinke the potion of Socrates, then wound my ≈øelfe as Cato did. And though it bee all one yet doth my imagination perceive a difference, as much as is betweene death and life, to ca≈øt my ≈øelfe into a burning furnace, or in the channell of a ≈øhallow river. Might not one al≈øo make it ≈øeeme voluptuous, as did tho≈øe who died with Anthonic and Cleopatra? I omit to ≈øpeake of the ≈øharpe and exemplar efforts, that philo≈øophy and religion produce. Might not wee imitate this manner of re≈øolution in more hone≈øt affaires and more commendable attempts? And ≈øince there are deaths good vnto wi≈øe men and good vnto fooles, let vs find ≈øome one that may be good vnto ≈øuch as are betweene both. My imagination pre≈øents me ≈øome ea≈øie and milde countenance thereof, and (≈øince we mu≈øt all die) to bee de≈øired. Potenti≈ø≈øimus e≈øt qui ≈øe habet in pote≈øtate. Hee is of mo≈øt power, that Sen. epi≈øt. 9. keepes him≈øelfe in his owne power.
